=== FILE: A different way to train your triceps [HpGj0vtLB6Y].txt ===

Here's a try step exercise that you can do with seated debt machine. The way that you're going to do this one is you want to pick a weight that's just about one plate more than you could actually push down with one arm. So you're going to need both arms to push it down, but then you're only going to lower it with one arm. So you're going to press it down with both arms and only lower with one. The key here is to not go too heavy because the tempo on your knee center is going to be too fast. So I recommend going about one plate at most two plates more than you could press down with one arm. I'll show you. Then when you can't take it on a negative five-pound, it's not got as many reps as you can do. You fail there. Hit a lockout, slight bend, and hold. Then you'll keep holding until you feel exactly on your back so then you're done.

=== FILE: Anaheim Ducks Mark Fitzgerald on Strength Training & Fighting [6lG2mCVrVf0].txt ===

My name is Marcus Gerald, I'm the head strength conditioning coach for the Anaheim Dubs. It's done. I have to go for it. Go for it. Go for it. Go for it. Go for it. Go for it. Go for it. You know what I got into it? I guess a number of different ways. I had some really great influences in my life. I have two older brothers. My middle brother really got me into weightlifting. I got a lot of money from bullying me and beat me up. But he introduced me to it. I remember I still remember to this day going to him. Going to the gym with him for the first time. He put the 45 bar in the bench and it pinned me harder than it had been pinned before. And that was kind of my introduction was, you know, this is how we left. It's hard and it's, you know, you got to, you got to click into a different mindset when you do it. So that's what kind of attracted me to it. And it was a, you know, as a busy kid play a lot of sports. So it was a kind of an escape to something I could do. And, you know, me and my brother did it a lot and what have you. Canada is hockey. So, you know, I did play hockey when I was growing up, but it was more, I was more suited for football, I had the bigger body. And, you know, just, I was drawn to it because again, because of my brothers influence and started playing and was lucky enough to be on a really good team in high school, Canadian speaking anyways. And I got recruited to play at a university. So I went up going there and that was when it really, you know, my eyes were open to. Wow, this is, you know, this is something I love, you know, it's, you, you really get into it and, you know, training five days a week and running track and, you know, it started to get good at it. So, you know, when you get good at something, it's, makes you want to do it even more. And then when I was finished school, I was supply teaching and kind of, honestly, didn't really know what I wanted to do. Even though I knew I loved this, but I didn't think you could make a job out of it. And, you know, I started training some football players as I was coaching football and got to introduce to some hockey athletes and then floodgates. Because I, I feel like I had that success early on because of my football background. Because really, a lot of this training is based from football. You know, or at least based in and around that, you know, there's a lot of the iron that comes from football. So I think I brought that to the hockey in my area anyways. And then I got introduced to a guy named Adam Foot, who was a NHL veteran Olympic gold medalist. He's from Wippie, which is my hometown. And that was he's the guy that really opened doors for me. And I was lucky enough to be able to work with him and help him for this last, last, almost half of his career, which was a big learning experience. For me, guy who had a lot of damage on his body, played for the Blue Jackets for a little while. Captain of the captain of them for a little while. And he really pushed me to be better and challenged me. And from there I started picking up jobs with any Ontario hockey league, which is like a big, the biggest feeder league that Canadian hockey league to the NHL. With the Oshwa generals. And then the Toronto Maple Leafs, Toronto Marlies. They hired me as the, as the Marlies head coach or head strength coach, sorry. And it was on from there. It was a really great experience there with a lot of great coaches and people that pushed me. And then I got an opportunity to kind of do my own thing. I started my summer program and it's kind of just kept on going from there. And then obviously the NHL thing. You know what I like I told you before. I retired or I resigned from the Marlies because my family grew pretty fast. I had twins. And you know, thought, okay, I'll stick to the private side and build my business and be home. And then I got this call mid July last year and are you interested? I said, well yeah, but you know, moved to California. I didn't really take it seriously, I guess. I know that sounds kind of dumb, but I really didn't. And then, you know, they flew me down. Had an interview. We want you. And it was like, okay. I went back to my wife. I said, what do you think? And she said, let's do it. I was just still young and what a great opportunity. And I had a lot of good people who are speaking for me and recommend to me, which is, you know, very grateful for that. And I said, you know what? It's a challenge. This is the time of my life that I'm probably going to be able to do it. I mean, the kids are young. Why not? So that's kind of the short and version of how it happened. You know what I think number one is just different bodies. Like, I do have some, I still train some football players at a pretty high level. And, you know, it's just, you know, both of them have wear and tear, but you're just, you're dealing with some very different body types with football players, very long levers. And I think, you know, training is still training at the end of the day. I don't really believe in the whole sports specific thing, but I still think you, you know, you do have to get specific to the individual and their needs and weaknesses. And that comes with a, you know, a good assessment and all that kind of stuff, which we all know. And I think with the hockey, unfortunately, it's a lot of, they spend way too much time on the ice. And that's something that even at the highest level that we fight or that I fight, because it's skating is very unnatural. And if you're not meant to do it, it's like squatting deep, you know, like some people just can't do it. And the more you force it, the more issues that are going to happen or that are going to occur. And, you know, I think there's, there's working with the individual body types and looking for individual needs. With hockey again, the, the, I try to really get our guys to stay off the ice as much as possible and get strong, you know, but, you know, speaking about the ducks, we usually go late into the playoffs. So that means we don't finish playing until June. So then that typically means for most guys, they have the month of July off the ice and then August, you guys start getting back on the ice. So you're skating for 300 plus days a year. You know, you can't put a heavy bar in your back and expect to have good results, you know, so you really have to be, it really comes down to planning and periodization of, okay, you know, in this block, we're going to work really hard. And we're going to, we're going to shift volume, we're going to shift all the, all the factors that we can and hopefully peak you to camp and to sustain it through the season. I think that's, that's the toughest part is really sitting down and going, okay, here's my 12 months of the hockey year. Whereas my time where I can get strong, whereas the time that I can, and you know, there's other variables too with injury and travel and our travel schedule surrenders because of the West Coast and, you know, those are all things that have to really come into play, especially in hockey. Yeah, I think first and foremost, you know, when I first came into the ducks and camp was open, I said, I have to get these guys to trust me and at the base of it, if they trust me, then, you know, when it comes to programming, when it comes to buy in all that kind of stuff, it's made that much easier when they, when that initial trust is there. So I have that now, with our team, because I listen to them, I don't baby them, but it's, you know, when it's time to work they work and I think I'm very fortunate in that regard, I got a really good group of guys. As far as when they, when they leave me, I think in my head, there's a lot of great coaches out there. We were talking about a few before of Defranco and, I don't scoff here in Columbus, a lot of brilliant guys. I'm not going to try and make a program and ask a guy like Defranco to do my program. I'm not, I'm not that type of person. What I will do though is, you know, ask our player, who's your strength coach, who are you working with? Give me the contact information. I'll have a number of conversations with them. On what I think is, you know, immediate needs, you know, what I saw during the season, nutritional needs, what have you, and I'll say, and I'll say, you know, I'll call you every three weeks and I expect a report on how my athlete is doing. And really, if you're a good coach, you'll like that. And I've always dealt with our players that way, even in the junior levels, you know, who are you working with? Okay. Oh yeah, they're really good. Okay. Well, let's see how good they are. I will come out and say that, I'm not arrogant, but, you know, it's also, hey, if this is somebody who's really good, wow, I just gained somebody that I can send more guys to. You know, and I think that's, I believe that that is the best way to do it. We have an online portal for guys who are far away, who don't have access to a gym or a coach. So we'll set up that for our guys that has, you know, video librarian, they'll do my program. But that's pretty rare now because like we were talking about before, there's a lot of great people out there. So, and it helps me network as well. If I can meet someone in Russia that train guys well and, and, and can, it can help me, then perfect. And he's going to be added to my contact list and, you know, we'll grow it from there. And at the same time, if somebody comes back and they didn't do a good job, well, then, you know, it ultimately, it's my responsibility, you know, if a guy doesn't come back and shape from now on, it's on me. So, I'm going to be hard on those coaches in the offseason, not hard, but I'm going to be expecting information and communication throughout the summer for sure. I think you just have to be aware of it that it happens and, and you all, everybody knows the guys who are going to do that. We have a very tough team in my opinion. We have most of the guys in our roster confite and fight pretty well, and we have a couple heavy weights. You know, so for them, I'm worried about their hands. First and foremost, so we do a ton of grip strength. We got the, you know, the old school rice bucket. We've had grips on absolutely everything. We do a lot of rope work. We'll do heavy bag work for them. I got a little bit of background in that. So we'll hit the heavy bag. If we're on a home stretch upwards of two, three times a week, we'll do some three-minute rounds. We'll do a whole bunch of stuff. And it's more about helping them with technique on punching as opposed to just, you know, conditioning, although it's sneaky conditioning at the same time, and they know that. And they like it, you know, because they know they need to do it. You know, fortunately or unfortunately, whatever you believe. You know, so it's something again, that's a trust element for me. You know, I'm going to condition them because they're typically bigger guys. But at the same time, I'm helping them with something that's part of their game. You know, so I like to say, grip work, shoulder stability and strength is obviously a big one. Hockey is a high occurrence of AC joint sprains and clavicles and all sorts of stuff because of the body checking. So we'll do a lot of shoulder stability work, which is, you know, carries overhead carries. I do a lot of bamboo bench with our guys in season because hockey typically not great ventures because of the shoulders in the contact. So we'll do a really a wide variety of that type of stuff, upper back work is huge. They got a lot of T-spline issues because of that hunched over position. So I think we try to keep them healthy with, you know, our pre-hab stuff and then our strength stuff when we can. And then the conditioning element is big, you know, so we'll do. I try to stay away from the bike rides just because again with the hip issues. So we do a lot of assault bikes. We do a lot of sprens on the curve treadmills, stuff like that. And then the boxing and skipping is huge. Well, I was saying to my training partner on the way here, like this is like my Disney land, you know, this is Dave is the guy that I first started following. You know, those training logs and the website when it was up I was in university at the time and it was just like, you know, it's it's guys like that who are humble and who admit mistakes and who aren't saying that they know it all. They just say, here's my experience and those are the typically who are the guys that I follow like different goes another one. Caldeeds in Minnesota is I think absolutely brilliant and humble and wherever we visit Minnesota I go spend some time with Cal. I love his programming. I love the way that I guess if you could put in in a category probably more under his his stuff just because I feel it's so adaptable to our schedule. You know, and I can really when I get a guy with a high training age or a really low one it still applies, you know, I can still mess with the eccentric concentric or eccentric isometric concentric. I think there's always I think it applies really well to sport. Mike Boyle again a guy that's humble. I was just in Boston spent some time with Mike. You know, I know there's that that's a pretty wide array of guys, but that's how I feel because I feel like I can, you know, when I meet an athlete it's, you know, where do they fit in that? What do I need to help these athletes with and I draw on those different influences for, you know, for the training and putting the program together. I don't want to be put into a specific category. Like I don't deal with a lot of power lifting and stuff like that. It's just not. Those aren't typically the people that come to me. However, you know, I can't let them as a colleague of mine and from my area at home and I've learned a ton from him. And, you know, so I think I'm a, I'm a lifelong learner. I'm always looking for, you know, new guys to follow and new ideas, but at the same time, like we just talked about this is like the old school. It's hard. It's boring, but it works. And if you can kind of stick with it and do it, I think that's, you know, that's the ultimate, that's the ultimate goal. The flashy stuff comes and goes and yeah, there's some new stuff that I like, but to be honest it's not not a whole lot has changed for me. It's it's hard. It's boring and you try to make it fun and. And I think two of the challenge for me is I've been fortunate now to have athletes who've been with me for eight, nine, ten years and they're still growing and they're still achieving, you know, every year, year after year. So it tells me that the way that I'm approaching it is is the right way. Because I feel like it's always evolving. You know, what can we do differently, you know, and a boy will says it all the time, you, he's like, I wouldn't want to show you what I was doing ten years ago. And I feel the same way, although I'm doing some of the same stuff, but it's it evolves. And if you're not up to learning that and there's a lot of young guys now in my field more in the hockey Kevin yield, air, the Kressy who are just, I think are just off the charts of the ideas that they're coming with. And because they're seeing a lot of what I'm seeing these younger athletes who are, you know, doing their sport 12 months a year. And there's a lot of early specialization and they're coming in with jacked up tea spines and hips out of whack and it's like, you can't sometimes fix that with a bar on your back. You have to get creative and yes, you can eventually get back to the bar. But I think you have to be more open to, okay, let's fix it with some movement first. And I mean, there's a lot of fluffy stuff. Don't get me wrong, but I think if you can navigate through that with some of the names that I mentioned, it's probably going to be a good spot.

=== FILE: Are Bands a Bad Idea for Rotator Cuff Strengthening？ ｜ elitefts.com [iNqKLSLRMfQ].txt ===

It's going on guys. Jordan Schallel here with the lead FTS. Just wanted to recap an article I wrote about using bands to strengthen the rotator cuff. Now, common practice we see in gyms a lot. It's a little bit better than describing plates and flopping your arms around, but it's something that you might want to think about reconsidering as putting as part of your warm-up. Now, every muscle has a strength curve. An ability to exert force across different lengths of the muscle. More often than not muscles are weak when it's fully lengthened and muscles are weak when they're fully short. Like a bicep isn't really strong. Here, nor is a bicep really strong here. It's kind of strong right in that middle part of that curve. So if we think of fully lengthened, fully short and most muscles operate from this, what's called that length tension relationship. Muscles of the rotator cuff are no different. So if we think about now the resistance profile, which is how this band is going to exert force against our rotator cuff, this band is going to get harder. It's going to exert more force as we approach that fully short and position of the muscles that externally rotate our shoulder. In this case, predominantly a muscle called your infraspinatus. This is one of your rotator cuff muscles. So if we think muscles are weak when they're short, we don't want resistance that increases into the position in where muscle gets weak. So if that infraspinatus is weakest as we externally rotate to that fully short and position, we don't then want to add resistance through that plane that's getting increasingly more difficult to overcome as our ability to overcome drops off. So rather than using a band to strengthen your rotator cuff, perhaps using an implement like a cable set up in a very similar way, we're just going to have a uniform distribution of force across that that strength curve of the muscles we're trying to train might be a better adaptation to put into our training to help build those muscles of stability around the shoulder.

I believe I'm a little biased, but this condition was probably the best on stage. My first goal being in. I got the second ball out. I would have had him in the first ball out. I got a couple guys for an off-road. The condition was off, and the judge's condition made those guys look way off. So, today, they pull them in the first ball out, we'll see. Please welcome John Manors, the Buddyfighter of the Hamilton.

=== FILE: Breaking The Deadlift Plateau - elitefts.com [MWFcrQ0EDyU].txt ===

If weights get stuck on the floor, it's usually not a factor of technique. Techniques usually more a factor once the bar gets moving a little bit, that's usually a more a factor of... This question is from E-Clip Show, and I excuse me as I'm looking at my notes over here because it was a very specific question. So I'm going to point out some of the specifics within the question. He's 65350. He just switched to Sumo about 15 months ago. He's been making gains pulling Sumo, but they're inconsistent, and he's wondering... He's actually wondering a few things. He's wondering if... Reading between the lines if he really should be pulling Sumo or conventional based upon his leverages, and he's wondering if the inconsistency is because the technique or some type of weak points. This is kind of one of those cases where video would be extremely helpful because you can be 65350 and have very, very big torso, or you can be 65350 and be really lean. So I don't know. I don't know the torso length or the femur length, but going off what I know, and that is... you switched from conventional as Sumo and you're making gains. Tell me that you... And I don't know how much the lift is. I mean, that's another factor as well. But you're making gains. So as long as you're moving forward and you're getting stronger, you're moving in the right direction. I really can't think of any lift or off the top of my head who, as they grew through weight classes, stayed with the same style of dead lifting. Based upon my torso size, which kind of fell in line with what weight class I was competing in in, and I competed in weight classes, keeping my night started when I was really young. From 181 all the way up to 308. Sometimes Sumo was the way to go, sometimes conventional was the way to go. The one thing that I found is when my torso became in the way, and that's the best way I know how to explain it. When I was going to sit down and grab the bar, I felt like I was sitting on my stomach. When it became in the way, is when my conventional seemed to always be the best bat. For me, in the leverages that I have, being 5, 5, 11. When it was no longer in the way where I was leaner, then Sumo was always the way to go because my legs were in quad's or stronger than my back for a very long time. So as long as you're making gains, that's where you want to stay. So what we're going to do is we're going to attack this inconsistency thing and try to see if I can help you with that. Because you mentioned it either moves or it gets stuck on the floor. I found if weights get stuck on the floor, it's usually not a factor of technique. Techniques usually are more a factor once the bar gets moving a little bit. That's usually a more a factor of you're just worn out. You're pulling too much, you know, whatever you did the day is proceeding, kind of drain you the last deadlift session, it was probably too much. So you're tired. That's kind of what happens. There are sometimes it can be technique. But usually not because I'm sure you've done this. I've done it almost everybody's done it. If you go up and you try to pull a bar and the fuckers glue to the floor, you end up getting pissed off about it and you go up and you try to get. And then you end up missing it again and you try to change something. It just stays there. It just doesn't go anywhere. So it's not really, I don't think it's really a weak point area. I think it's more overall programming problem. With that, I can sit here and tell you, you know, try to do deficit deadlifts and all this other kind of stuff. But I really don't think that's the issue and it would just be bullshitting you to try to make myself sound smarter than what I really am. You know, I think it's an overall programming thing to where maybe you're pulling too much. What I can suggest you try to do because 15 months really isn't a long time for a technical change. Some people will tell you that it's more than enough time with my experience. It's really not. It depends on how you train. So if you're only, if you're using a linear model or progressive over low model, block model or several other models, you just don't have enough volume in there to be able to reinforce any technical changes. So one thing that I can probably recommend with almost certainty if you started adding some speed poles with about 50% after your squat training and a sumo stance for 8 to 12 singles. So the weights really not enough is going to give you any kind of lower back pump. It's not going to be hard, but it's not going to be super hard. On a scale of one to 10 it's going to be like a five or six. But what that's going to do is it's going to give you 8 to 9, 10. If you work up to 12 you can go that high. 12 opportunities to work your set up into work your technique with that sumo deadlift without really tapping into your energy and your recovery stores that much. So with that in mind that's probably 12 more reps or 12, 48 more reps per month, then we already did a lifting now. So let's just say it's going to double if not triple the number of repetitions that you're doing per month right now over the 50% range, which is going to help kind of reinforce that technique. And it's also going to help you to determine if it really is a weak point or if it is a technical point because even at the 50% if you have some reps that feel like you're just tearing that shit off the floor and other ones that feel like you got to grind them up then you're going to know it's a technical thing. So that's what I was suggest to go that route to kind of dig a little bit deeper into what's going on here and get a little bit more diagnostic and a little more I guess you would call analytics to be able to really see if the shit is going on.

=== FILE: Build Your Main Lifts with These Band Progressions ｜ elitefts.com [keSQtmxhPlU].txt ===

Hey, this is Dave Tate with the table talk, but not really table talk, but kind of a table talk for now. What I wanted to do was to take a minute and talk about things that you can do, training wise that's a little bit above just a lot of the maintenance workouts that everybody's been doing. The maintenance workouts are great. Keep doing those. I'm not telling you to not do that, but I want to give you a few things that you can do to put with those maintenance workouts that are going to actually help you to progress forward instead of just maintaining. Without laying out a whole entire program, I'm just going to give you three different exercises that you can do, that you can progress on, that will have correspondence to dynamic correspondence or it's going to have a positive carry over to your main lifts. So the first one, I'm going to lay out, it's your basic push-up. Everybody's been doing a shit ton of push-ups. So with that, I'm going to lay all these out over four sessions. So these sessions can either be once a week for four weeks or it can be twice a week for two weeks. So it doesn't really matter because every one of these sessions are kind of what I would consider extra workouts that somebody would do. So if you're doing an extra workout and a normal programming standpoint, they could be as I just described once a week for four weeks or every other day or however you want to do it doesn't really matter. The key thing with these things are they're easy to recover from and they're going to help to advance and move you forward. So with the push-ups, and I got warm-ups sets that are you can do whatever you want for the warm-ups sets based upon where your own progression and your own strength is. So on session one, you're going to do one to three sets of five. Just working up, you're not really working up, you're just warming up. Then on the last set, just do a maximum number of repetitions you can do. That's it. Push-ups are done for that session. Next session you come back, for push-ups, you're going to do the same thing again. You're going to work up, you're going to do three or four sets of five as far as a warm-up. Then on the last set, you're going to use a band. And with the band, I want a strong, I want a heavy band. I want a strong band. I want the strongest band that you can use for five reps. So if you don't have one of our strong bands and you got three or four mini bands, use all the mini bands or use a light band or two light bands or an average band and a mini band. It doesn't matter. Just figure out what's hard for you to do for, let's say eight reps, ten reps, something like that. And if you don't have anything to be able to do that, just bring this tempo down. So five or six reps is going to be hard to do. There I want you to do five sets of five with whatever that band is. Don't change the band tension. If it's too hard to do, then press faster. If it's too easy, use a slower tempo. But I want the five sets of five. And then on the last set after that, so you got five worksets. Set after that, get rid of the band and just do set of pushups to failure again. The third session. One thing, you're going to warm up again and you're going to do the five sets of five again with either more band tension or the same band tension if it was really hard to do the time before. And then what you're going to do on this one is immediately after your last set of five with the band, you're going to throw the band off. And then you're going to do a max set to failure immediately after. And then the fourth session, it's going to be, I call it an open chain. So instead of doing the pushups on the floor, you're going to lean against the wall and brace your shoulder blades against the wall and then just push the band outward. So your hands are not connected to the floor. So it's more of an open chain. You're not going to have warm up reps on that because you're just going to go straight into the band and do five sets of five there with the same band that you were using on the last session. And then on the sixth set, do as many reps as you can. That would be for the pushups. Some things with doing pushups with bands that a lot of people screw up and forget, always cross the bands over. So you're going to make a figure eight of it, then throw it behind your back. That's going to keep the band from spreading out across your back, popping over your elbows and all the other stuff. You're going to make it easier to keep the tension where it needs to be. The second exercise is going to be good mornings. This is going to be a little easier than what I laid out for the pushups. With the good morning, it's just a first session. You're going to put the band, you're going to stand on the band, put the band around your traps. You don't want it directly on your neck. You're going to bring it lower. So it's still on your neck, obviously, but it's going to be more on the traps. Keeping it there, first session, you're going to do 30 reps. I don't care how you do it. I don't care if it's set to five, set to ten or set of 30. I don't care. You might get dizzy doing the set of 30, but I don't really care how it is. The second session, you're going to do 40 reps. The third session, you're going to do 60. Then the fourth session, you will do will do 80. So it's a very simple progression with that. The last exercise I have for you is just going to be a tricep band pushed down. I don't care how you attach the band, where you attach the band. It can be around a door. You can slip, not at over anything. There's a million ways to be able to attach a band from anything that's high up. Just don't put it on something that's going to break and fall in your head, obviously. Again, I'm going to have you start a little higher on the reps with this one. The second session, one, will be 60. Session two, will be 80. Session three, it will be 100. Then session four is going to be a little different because we're going to break it down and we're going to slow the tempo way down. On this one, you're only going to do three sets of five, but you're going to take ten seconds on the eccentric. I just couple seconds on the midpoint, where the contraction, and then ten seconds on the concentric. Roughly you're going to be looking at about 25 seconds, maybe 30 seconds for each repetition, that adds up over five repetitions. With that, you're going to do three sets of five. That's three exercises. You can actually progress on a little bit. These are exercises that I would actually put in somebody's training program to help bring up weak points that are associated with these things. It has an extra workout or at the end of a training session and so forth. They always have a correspondence to the lifts and I'm sure positive and no-for-effect. They're going to have a correspondence to what you're doing now. I know a lot of you guys are stuck and all you're doing is maintaining type things. That's fine if this whole quarantine thing was just two weeks or three weeks, but I think everybody's starting to realize now this could be, it could reach into two months, maybe even more. You need to start thinking a little bit about how you're going to make gains and how you're going to progress during this time off. Some won't be able to, and I'll make another video about that later, how to come back from long times off training. I wanted to put this one out there first, just to throw stuff out so people have something they can do immediately before I start talking about how to lay out a training program and then how to deal with being off for two, three months if need be and then how to come back from that. I hope you guys liked this. Let us know in the comments below if you want to see more of this. Make sure to subscribe and turn on the notifications on. === FILE: Casey Williams Discusses His Bench Press Methods - elitefts.com [u-fXBtH7tY8].txt ===

So the guy actually, the guy that I'm going to start it in power lifting was a bench only guy. He followed all the Louis stuff. So I went from the beginning, it was college, get jump right into it. I didn't understand it at that point and I made some really good gains, but it came to the point where he didn't understand it well enough and I was still too new and I didn't understand it. I kind of lost some traction and he was kind of towards the end of his career so he didn't really have a reason to change too much. All of his stuff was going to be pretty cut and dry as far as what he was going to do weekend a week out. So I got away from that. I had a bad meat. I got away from it. And I just did some high volume stuff, some volume and then peak and then things like that. And that worked for me for a couple of years, kind of plateaued again. So sorry to ask him around, talked a day, talked to Matt Winning, talked to some of the guys on the team. And Matt kind of steered me back toward college and it definitely, it's helped. I've hit PRs after hitting PR squats which can be tough things. Some guys will have trouble hitting their best. Like my deadlift, I can't hit my best deadlift after heavy squats. So I need to work on that. But as far as Ben and Che, I went back to college and get, and still feeling my way through it's a puzzle. As a 400 pound bencher, you can get a, well, as you get stronger, you can get away with fewer and fewer mistakes. You're putting yourself in harm's way, more often, even training at the same percentage as you're training at higher weights. So it's, again, you're, you're putting yourself in tough repositions. But the volume aspect, I can get away with higher volume on bench days, on upper days. I always seem to recover pretty well from that. So I've kept that. I'll always hit high dumbbell work, so it hit two sets of 20 and where I'm failing at the 20th rep almost every time. And that doesn't seem to hurt me too much. I'm still playing with what I need to do with my tricep work. Dave showed me a couple, I need to throw in some lying tricep extensions and need to throw in some quarter dips because my, my packs and my delts are taking over everything and I'm not getting the tricep development that I need for a bigger bench. So it's, that's come to light in the last couple, you know, in the last month or so. So figuring that out. It's the same as is upward back, middle back for a power lift. It's always not strong enough. It's never strong enough. I don't think you can have, I don't think your triceps can be too strong. So in that sense, yeah, I would say, even with that being said, it's probably my packs and my, my rear delts are overdeveloped compared to my triceps. And that's, I think that's holding me back at this point. I don't know, I always, I overhead press like through high school through college. I got away from it at the beginning of like five years ago when I first started powerlifting as a sport. So I probably got some of the early development that way. Just, you throw on a plate or two plates. You go overhead press it as much as you can. And that's, you know, that's how you train when you're younger and you're going to get stronger. Assuming that you're, you know, working hard and recovering. But as a, I haven't targeted those areas, at least on purpose. So I can't say that, I don't know why it's ended up that way. It probably genetics, I don't know. So first, Steve Bench, Dave and I actually had this conversation last weekend two weeks ago. And actually Steve Goggins brought it up too and Steve's not, you know, Steve's not a World Record Bench Presser but Steve knows how to bench and Steve knows how to program and do all the, do all the, I mean, he's a great coach, Mark's sort of short. So we, I agreed with both of them that I'm going to cut out speed bench the last four or five weeks of my training going into this cycle. I feel like I've always been fast so that's, I don't necessarily think I need speed, at least, you know, rather have myself recovered the last four or five weeks than, then get in the extra speed work. === FILE: Dan Green and Dave Tate Talk Powerlifting Training - elitefts.com [BNbDtlpPyyU].txt ===

All right, not a segue into your own training. As I was telling you earlier, a Jeremy Freight told me years ago that there came a time in his lifting career where, you know, it's like a light bulb just went off. He was using other people to help with programs and he was following other programs. He did block training for a while. He did, you know, West Side Style training for a while. And then he just kind of put the faith in himself and auto-regulated more or less of the training and his total one up 150, 200 pounds. And I remember that conversation with him because it was something that I was trying to tell him beforehand. This is where you want to try to strive to be, but it's hard to really tell somebody how to strive to be someplace that's really cerebral and not so physical. And then when he finally hit it, he was amazed with the progress. Biggest space to upon the numbers that you're lifting, you've been through that. So thinking back through, you know, all the years of your training, I'm sure like everybody else you started with some kind of linear base periodization, maybe block periodization, what are some of the takeaways, positive takeaways from each one of those things that helped to kind of develop the Dan Green Philosophy, meaning the philosophy that works for you, not a philosophy that you're going to take and try to tell everybody. But what are some of those takeaways that kind of carried over that you use now, but not in the full realm of that philosophy? Yeah, I think, you know, when I was first lifting, I was always just kind of following body building routines, you know, eventually like three sets of eight and a dumbbells and flies and all that stuff. And I think the good thing about that is you put on muscle, there's a lot of guys who come and I just want to lift heavy, but they don't fill out, and that's a problem. So learning how to not just how to lift for volume, but how to, when I think about lifting like a bodybuilder, I think about making sure that you feel that the muscles doing the work, you know, so you're feeling the motion, not just moving with power. You know, I spent, like when I first started training as a power lifter, most of what I was doing was kind of based on reading stuff off of elite and reading stuff off of the Westside page, you know, there's a ton of articles in both places that are all really great. You know, I went through probably two years of following kind of a Westside training model, and that kind of, that was working fine for me, but I still would see some places where I'm like, well, doing everything I think I was supposed to do. The results aren't quite there and everything I wanted. So the best thing for me is that I've gone to a lot of meats, and I've met a lot of people, I've seen some other, you know, styles of coaching, and I've given them all a try. I think there was a sort of article on elite about the finished editing program, which is all like based on doing deficit polls and stiff leg deadlifts and just a lot of volume like that. And so I tried that and worked great. I met another guy. The first time I came to the Arnold, he was a lifter, he competed in the deadlift me, and I saw him training one day, and he did kind of the same thing. He had a lot of block polls, he had a lot of deficits, and just like on deadlift day, he just deadlifted. It wasn't anything fancy. But the volume was there, the different heights and stuff, and you know, I had my main training partner followed training from Josh Bryant. And so I kind of followed along with some of the benching that he was doing, and some of the stuff made a lot of sense. So I kind of modified it to what felt good for me. I wanted to do more of certain things and, you know, less of other things. So I kind of just adapted it. I think in the end, what I kind of taken away from it is to be a good lifter. It's like a sport. Like any other sport, there's a skill to it. It's not just like the strongest guy. It doesn't just show up and win. You have to be the best. So being strong is half of it, but having the skill to actually execute the lifts. You know, that's really critical. Because if if the only thing that matters is who had the most muscle, you just show up and weigh in. Yeah, you know, and that's who it would win. That's not how it works though. So for me, like, becoming skillful means you have to practice. So one of the things I also looked at was as a way, the way that I looked at the Bulgarian way, the thing team, and their program is sort of an notorious for just training the main lifts. The reason being is that they're just getting really skillful on that main lift. So I started kind of doing that where I have a lot of the main lift competition lift I'm not training. But one of the things I learned from, you know, kind of the body building and the west side is the variations that really came for building just general strength. So to me, I wanted to get both. So that's kind of how I figure out the program for myself now. I have part of the space done, you know, the competition lifts. Part of it that's based on kind of variances that are that really target the right spots and body building. So kind of a blend of those three things. The key takeaway, the reason why I wanted to ask him this question, is as he was talking, he went through seven different training philosophies that he's gone through that's kind of matched up to become what he's doing right now. So if you're an intermediate or you're a beginner lifter, you don't want to do what he's doing now. You want to do what he did to get where he is. Because the key to all this is being able to figure out what works for yourself and certain things that he pointed out that he learned in the very beginning, the body building thing is a huge thing that that I struggle with with a lot of power lifters right now because to effectively work a muscle if all you want to do is to build your triceps or say it's an exercise you're doing at the end of your program. Is it really necessary to use a hundred pounds for dumbbell tricep extensions if you're just doing it for high productivity? You can use 40 pounds use a slower tempo and just focus on using the triceps or you can keep that shit up, you know what I'm saying? Yeah, I do a lot of shoulders and rows and it's like I see a lot of guys doing heavier shoulders and I don't do a lot of guys doing heavier rows. I've been training that for a long time but one thing when I do training with other guys and I try to show them like you know what to feel, what to do, they're just kind of like what they have a hard time understanding and then when they do it they're like holy shit that feels really good but I need to go later. Yeah, so that's a huge thing though because when you're talking about longevity and the sport, wear and tear the joints and the health aspect that you're talking about with your clients. If it's an exercise that isn't going to have the dynamic correspondence or like you're talking about carry over to the skill of the lift and it's just there to build muscle. Why beat the shit out of yourself if you can slower the tempo and do it like a bodybuilder to just build the muscle? You know it's now we're not talking about your main exercises here, you know with and when he's talking about the skill of the sport he's talking about the squat bench and deadlift as they're done in competition. Yeah and when I train those I do focus on like acceleration all the way through. You know one of the things you know from Westside training there's the concept of dynamic training but one of the things that I see that people kind of mess up with it is it's not just good like if you're dead the thing go to a meet and you see some guys just ripping the weight off the floor in the warm-up room and then they go out for their attempt on the floor and they grind to a halt right at the knees. So you could look at them and say wow they're super explosive and fast and they're in the warm-up room they're going to be awesome but then they can't grind at a slow speed but the problem is is you have to be able to accelerate the weight all the way through the lift not accelerate off the floor desolored past the knees that's not that's not the same thing. So I think a lot of guys messed that concept up sort of like the accelerate more but sort of like you know you see the the short lockouts yeah you know high hips you're sort of like shortening the range of motion and in terms of just physics if you go shorter distance but more force the power is sort of just equaled out because force and distance one one up one went down so the trick is like I think about like if you be like an Andy Bolton he does this when he's warming up he hits his lockout and the bar just kind of keep going because he's accelerating it all the way through the lift he's not sort of cutting the speed off at the top and so for me that's kind of what I think about accelerating off the floor but then accelerating even more past the knees and I think all the lifts are like that too what that tells you is that you're always in the right position to be powerful or forceful at any moment in the lift not like it's like the concept of just get speed to blast through your sticking point yeah that's fine of course you want to be fast but at the same time you want to be in the right position of this sticking point too yes so it's kind of it's not good enough to just do one if you want to be better exactly all right well I want to thank you for the interview this is a great information and if you want to get a hold of the interview and check out his training facility what's the website it is bossbarbo.com

=== FILE: Dave Tate on the Risks and Rewards of Powerlifting ｜ elitefts.com [N557nj_J778].txt ===

And you speak in the risk and rewards associated with lifting? Yeah. And this isn't just lifting again, all these things can apply to sports and can apply to everything else. There's a risk reward ratio to everything. And you hear people talk about it all this time. And it's become part of normal dialogue. You have to get comfortable being uncomfortable. We're not like that means because I never really understood that one because if you become comfortable, then you're not uncomfortable. It just doesn't make sense to me as far as how that whole things put together. But what I do know is when people do think about risk reward, they never look at the risk, seriously. It's like, OK, here's what the reward can be. And they're all about that. But they'll look at the risk and say, OK, here's all the things that could potentially happen, but not to me. Or I'm going to minimize all the risks. And that's fair. That's what we all do. You all want to minimize the risk. But the word minimize does not mean eliminating all of the risks. So there's a reason why there's the word risk and the word reward. There's always that price. And God forbid, you don't have to pay the price. But don't act like you didn't know what it was. Don't do something for several years. And 10 years, 20 years or whatever. What is this like, fuck, I didn't know. What do you mean you didn't know? You didn't know that this could be a potential risk. And in all cases, the people will tell me, well, yeah, I did, but what you didn't think it would happen to you. So you really didn't look at the risk reward. Because if you want to get rid of every risk associated with whatever activity you're doing, don't do it. Simple. Don't do it. Yes, you definitely want to minimize it. And that's not what I'm talking about. When I'm talking about is when it's a risk reward, you have to think about it. And understand that this is something that you're willing to erode your willing to go down, knowing that this is a potential impact of that. It's a potential result. That's an iron side effect. I don't know where to really look for risk. It's a potential risk. In business, we learn a little bit differently because the risk rewards always associate with the financial aspect. So it's like, OK, if we do this, what's the risk? Well, we lose everything. Fuck. Do we really want to do this? Or do we want to do this? So I'm going to do it. But it's there. And there's some things that you can do in business where you're not going to lose everything. You know that worst case scenario, you're not going to lose every dollar that you have in the bank. The worst case scenario. And that I don't think is what people look at if they make a decision to embark on a sport, a career, whatever it's going to be. They don't look at the risk from this standpoint of what is the worst thing that could happen in a mile, OK with it. In my OK if I'm not 1%. Here's the tricky thing with that is. No, I'm not OK if I'm OK. You don't do it. But on the other end of the coin, are you OK if you're going to be that 1% that gets the maximum benefit over and above everybody else? Of course, everybody is. So that's a balance. So it's something that I guess I learned very, very early on is with that. And it's probably one of the reasons why I don't have any real regrets except maybe except one. But that's it. And I even knew what I even knew the risk of the regret that I did earn from that is knowing that. And yeah, I fallen on the short end of that risk reward. So I was, I'm fucking OK with it because I knew this was something that could happen. But I'm not going to sit and say, fuck, holy me, I can't believe. But that I can't believe. You just, I don't get it. So from that standpoint, I think it's more an internal dialogue that needs to be expanded upon instead of ignored. And what would you call it when you don't pay attention to it in different, I think what most people really are is, they don't necessarily ignore it. They're just indifferent. They don't even think about it. And that's the biggest thing about being in different. That's the ultimate not given a fucking. Because you really don't give a fucking, they don't even know what it is. So I think if there's some cognitive to thought about that, then if that time comes to where you have to pay that price, you're going to be OK with that. And then you won't be asking the questions. Such as, you know, why did this happen to me? And all this kind of stuff. It doesn't matter. It's just pulled the shoulder and other sticks. Somebody has to pull the biggest step. Somebody's got to pull the shorter one. It's the name of the game. I can't frame the mud. Does that on my hands? Strow like a tree. This will trust in. Oh, I've been running from the Lord.

This is the chest training that we did on Sunday. I'm going to stay with this video format and actually, you know, ask you guys to give me some feedback on what you think about this type of format. And on these here, the goal was to work up to have you said eight, check mark represent, you know, the warm upsets and the work sets. So there were five, so you can have eight total warm upsets. After that, it was inclined shoulder-saver bar presses. It was scheduled to work up and do three sets of 10. I felt pretty good on this. So I kind of modified it a little bit where we're going to ramp up and do a heavy work set eight, one up to 295 for eight, which is the best I've done on that bar so far. So that was good. After that, we went on to the reverse band press. Five sets of five, the five sets of five are progressive. So when the way it starts to get heavy, it will take smaller jumps. Everything was being, when I pushed everything was going off to my right side, which is assigned for me that my packs and my rotator, my shoulder, it's starting to give out a little bit. So I called it there with the set of three and just moved on to the next exercise and said it trying to force it or lower the weight. As soon as that starts to fatigue and for me, when my bad shoulder starts to get real weak like that, it's pretty much time to move on, get away from that movement. From there, it was, we did, it's not listed here, but we did two sets of 20 on the machine flies and that was just to kind of make up for the set I was unable to finish with the reverse band. Then it was a super set of dumbbell side raises with face band or face poles, just basically band pull parts. Four sets there. Then we did a rear-doubt destroyer set. It's just activating the rear delts, keeping the arms really straight. 50 pounds for 60 reps with a drop to 1.5 to 1.5 to 1.25 pounds for 30 reps. Another drop to 1.5 pounds for 10 to 1.5 reps. === FILE: Elitefts.com - John Meadows Nutritional Update with Dave Tate (better audio) [Ixfdgx93Mrw].txt ===

All right guys, I'm here with John Meadows. He's does my training and diet and we thought it would be interesting to have him make the next round of adjustments on film so you can kind of see what's going on. It's the diet basically changed from not completely eating my crap, you know, probably before this I let my weight get out close to 275 out of six or seven meals were good. The other ones weren't so good. So we're locking it in to bring my body fat down a little bit. I've been following this plan here for two three weeks. Gone from 270 to 10.5 percent body fat using seven-site skin fold to 9.5 way into 66. So the training's already been changed. That's gone from five weight training days per week to seven so we'll not discuss that. And we'll just go over whatever changes if any need to be made with the diet protocol that we have here. So I'll let John kind of go on from here. The first question I have for him would be, since we have seven weight training days per week and this diet plan here has five days for training days and two days for non-training days is what am I going to do with that? Yeah, so the two days that we have for non-weight days is out the window. That doesn't exist anymore. So now our template is only a weight training day because again we're hitting seven days a week. === FILE: Elitefts.com - Table Talk Special Edition Part 2 [72XMwO3GuH8].txt ===

This is Dave Tate with a special edition of Table Talk. This is a special edition because this is filmed outside of the order of all the other table talks that have already done that are waiting in archive to be published. The reason I'm doing this one is instead of doing a social media tip of the week, I decided just to knock out this question from Adam instead. So Adam's got a two-part question here. In the first part is on a technical level, what is the favorite training template that I've ever used or the scheme or method? With that, it should be pretty cut and dry that. For me for strength, it's a concurrent or a conjugated type of training system. I personally feel that when done properly, that's the best training system that you can use for strength. It's the best way to focus on all the aspects of strength development from the maximal strength to hypertrophy to explosive strength. It trains and includes all aspects of that as well as focusing and bringing up and helping to determine what your weak points are. It can be modified to suit anybody's needs based upon their strength or weaknesses or however, or wherever the focus needs to be if it's a competitive schedule or if it's just a general strength training schedule. It can be modified for more hypertrophy, if that's what you're looking for or more strength. From a peer hypertrophy standpoint, my answer would be different. I think just more of a classic bodybuilding protocol with higher volume is going to be a better way to go, but you're going to sacrifice strength development in the process. So from a supporting standpoint, more of the concurrent conjugated standpoint from a powerlifting, obviously, that's standpoint from a bodybuilding and more of a typical training protocol. But it's all based upon the individual needs, time restraints and training age. The second part of the question involves training kids. There's an adombs asking about 2016 year old cousins, which pretty much spend most of their time playing video games, sitting on the couch, pretty much what a lot of people would consider your average kid in America. They're expressing interest in weightlifting, but at the same time, they can't do 20 push-ups. They can't hold a static squat. I'm sure there's a whole host of other bodyweight type movements that they can't do as well. They happen to be family, which puts another wrench in the equation. They're not sons, they're just their relatives, but it still puts a wrench in the equation. And wondering what my advice is for training them without them getting bored. And what I'm not seeing here at them is how you're going to do this without compromise in your own training as well, because if there is a trade out that needs to be considered, in fact, or into this, for all of us who are asked to help with programming or help to train somebody else be at youth or a friend or relative or not with what. There's always an opportunity to cost associated with each one of these things in that need to be factored in. If you're going to work with these kids, can they do or be in the gym at the same time that you are without negatively affecting your own training? Because if not, that means you're going to have to train them at a different time or you're a workout time that you're in the gym now is going to be extended. So there is a certain opportunity cost, like I said, that needs to be factored in to this. They are expressing interest, which is a good thing. So that should be a major, major consideration whenever anybody is working or considering working with any kids. They need to want to do it. If they don't want to do it, then I personally, from my standpoint, I wouldn't have them do that. It's a delicate balance when you're working with with kids because you want to see them embrace, you know, what we love so much, but it may not be their passion. So you don't want to burn them out or have them end up hating something that they really should make a part of their life forever. You know, exercise, not just weightlifting, weight training, powerlifting, or whatever they're going to get into or may not get into. Exercise has to be a part of their life so the last thing that we want to do is to destroy that and have them not ever want to go into the gym. What should they do? I mean, if they're that decanditioned, I would have them come into, I'd have them come into the gym and watch you train and see how that goes. You know, have them do maybe a couple things just to see what their interest is and nothing, nothing major, nothing like deadlift, surgery. I would stay with bodyweight movements. I would, however, you know, they can't do 20 push-ups. So I would, I would reinforce that with them that they have to build strength, you know, with their own bodyweight before they can start using external resistance because, you know, it kind of goes along with, I think goes along with a game, you know, if they can't do a push-up, then they have no business to a bench presses. And so I'd have them do bodyweight movements, but at the same time in a sled dragging, I mean, all the basic stuff, all the basic conditioning stuff that you would have anybody else do that came into the gym, D conditioned is what you're going to basically want to have them do. But what I would watch more so than anything else is how they interact. If they're having fun, if they're not having fun, and then I would throw more stuff in, if they are having fun with it, and I would pull stuff out, if they're not having fun with it or I'd have them come in fewer times, you know, start out with once a week, see how that goes, then work it up from there. It's a, it's a simple question to answer. I mean, we all know it's going to be bodyweight movements, but you made a very, very clear point here is how you're going to do this without them getting bored. You know, when they're in a gym and they're seeing you get an after it and you're doing the squats and the pulls and you're doing all the heavy training, you know, they're going to want to be a part of that. They're going to, so somehow or now that you've got to find a way to make them a part of that, to feel a part of that, to get that connection so they're going to want to come back, even if it's loading bars or pointing things out to them while the other lifters are lifting, showing them, you know, look at how John keeps his back arch, see how Steve's pushing his knees out, you know, point out what the technical things that the lifters are doing right and that they're not doing right, so they feel a part and they feel connected of what's going on. That would be the best advice I would give to them or to you as far as that goes.

=== FILE: Elitefts.com - Table Talk Special Edition Part 3 [eJJ6p926tKc].txt ===

Second part of this table talk, I want to continue answering the question that Adam asks, but I'm going to approach it from a different standpoint. Everybody's gonna have different chapters in the book. You know, but people need to think about that shit. You know, when they're out there running their mouth, you know, ambition to other people have been doing it for 15, 20 years. You know, trying to act like they know it all. You know, when they've only been really at it for three to five years, and they haven't really been tested, they haven't been injured. They haven't had to really sacrifice shit. You know, skipping lunch is not sacrificing a fucking for your sport. You know, taking a day off work doesn't sacrifice and for your sport. Using your vacation time to go to a meet is not sacrificing for your sport. You'll know when your sacrifice and for your sport because it's gonna hurt. You know, most of the people that are running their mouth and they're talking, they never hurt. They never hurt for their sport. And I'm talking physically hurt. Men only hurt. You know, and physically hurt. And knowing how to work hard. You know, as soon as the lot of these guys need to work hard, they're out. You know, yeah, they have passion. And I've always said passion trumps everything. And it does. When it's real and it's from the heart, you know, when it's from the head, it don't trumps shit. You know, so, yeah, it's work. It's work. And there's gonna be danger, not gonna wanna train. You still need to find a way to train. You know, those are the days you set PRs. You know, there's gonna be other days that you really, really wanna train and you get into the gym and the shit ain't clicking, man. It ain't feeling right. And then you need to back it down. Because you gotta listen to your body and more than you need to listen to your brain. You know, that's the key thing. If you're listening to your brain to try to overcome a lot of this shit and not listen to your body, then you're gonna get hurt. So sometimes your brain will play tricks on you. You won't wanna train, but then you go on the gym and you have a great workout. You know, and you have a great session and it moves you forward. You know, and that's exactly what you needed to do and what you were supposed to do. And what you're actually required to do because that's what makes great lifters great. But the other part that makes great lifters great is when they go on the gym and they feel awesome and they're working out and something doesn't feel right. And then they back it down or do something else or they cut today. So yeah, there's gonna be a day you're not gonna have a passion. But passion isn't supposed to be a full time thing. Passion is an emotional state. Happiness is an emotional state. It's not a full time emotion. Or it's not a full time outlook. If it was, then what would be happening? === FILE: How Tricep Extensions Can Improve Your Bench Press ｜ elitefts.com [1_Y7Uu5kFAY].txt ===

It's going on guys, Jordan here with EliteFDS.com. What we're going to do is go over a tricep accessory move that helps reinstate proper shoulder function. Going through the bench press, we're always retracted and depressed. There's conflicting fields of thought on whether or not we should be in the overhead plane and we're trying to be as specific as possible to get the most out of our bench press. So training the tricep and what we'll call a fully length and position in the overhead might have very little to do with actually strengthening the tricep because it doesn't have the specific carry over due to its position to the actual bench press itself. The benefit of training the overhead position is reintegrating that movement of the scapula that's lost in the bench and also being able to clear for any potential issues at the elbow or shoulder in this very advanced range of motion, usually to the turn of 90 degrees outside of the plane that we usually work within the bench. Now the carry over isn't directly from building strength. It's more so the benefit of this exercise is begin to keeping at bay potential dysfunction causing pain at the elbow as we come down from the overhead into the plane at the bench press. So a lot of guys do that have issues with overhead tricep extensions so what they do is they move down the line and they go to more neutral shoulder positions rather than actually fixing the underlying issue at the shoulder. So keeping exercise is in the overhead plane whether it's overhead press, whether it's tricep extensions, whether it's even like high cable bicep curls, keeping that shoulder mobile is going to help give us a functional buffer which will allow us to keep that bay and allow us to start to perceive potential dysfunction that could creep into the plane of the bench press. You know, elbow pain and power lifting is a very common melody that can be mitigated going into a prep by making cerebral choice is based around our supplemental and accessory movement. So this particular variation we're going to use a dumbbell in the full overhead position. Now I want you to think about the shoulder blade. I want you to rotate that shoulder blade, punch to the ceiling with the serratus, trying to get the elbow and shoulder in a straight line. As we lower this dumbbell down we're going to think about driving that elbow to the ceiling, creating as much stability in that shoulder blade as we can. Find that fully lengthened position. Stay there under that challenge. Keep this in a straight line as we drive up and extend. So this isn't really taxing our tricep until we're in that fully lengthened position. As we lower to find that fully lengthened position we're going to take that shoulder blade and we're really going to elevate and rotate it, activating that serratus that gets deprioritized when we execute a movement like the bench press because our rhomboid is going to take the wheel and it turns off the action of the serratus. So it has very little to do necessarily with building mass or strength, coarse bond and strength to the triceps as it pertains to the bench press, but being able to reinstate that shoulder function and integrate tricep action in that overhead position will better help us long-term. We'll be able to keep our elbows in shoulder healthy. So again, more cerebral choices based around our supplemental and accessory movements are going to see as well as we go into a meat prep and have to be more hyperspecific in our sort of competition lift.

=== FILE: How to Keep Strength While Adding Physique Training - elitefts.com [w89YOwg8RY4].txt ===

That's a great question and I think that's probably the easier of the two. When we're working towards strength muscular size is always going to benefit. So as I use myself as an example because years of power lifting, power lifting is we tend to neglect certain body parts. We build up a posterior chain. We build up our hamstrings. We build up our triceps and we tend to lack some things like shoulders, biceps, quads. So adding some of those aesthetic and those body building things in can enhance a lifter in their strengths and bring up some of those weaknesses. So I think in those regards by adding some body building into some strength work, it really does balance out nicely. So even though you're working towards strength goals for a period of say four or five months, it's easy to add in some extra volume at the end of your workout to add a body building day where all you come in and do is some extra recovery work and some extra body building work to add that volume in. So that's pretty easy to do. Now your next question might be to how to do the flip side, which is a little bit trickier because anytime you are working towards building serious size and mass, it gets a little trickier to keep strength work in. And I'm not saying you can't do the two. I have been working with Scott Palto's for the last year and he has done a phenomenal job of balancing that out where we focus on my strength work. My bench has gone up, my squat has gone up, my deadlifts have all gone up because we've been able to keep some of that body building work in. But when it's time to really focus in on the aesthetics, especially when you're talking about getting on stage, that's where that strength work is going to have to take a little bit of a back seat because if you're focusing solely on bringing up certain muscle groups and you're talking about bringing in the shoulder pectine or you're talking about bringing in the glute hamstring tie in. All of those things take a little bit of detail and so some of that strength work might need to be on hold for a little bit in order to bring up some of those details. So I hope that makes sense a little bit. But anytime you're dieting and anytime you're stepping on stage, you're going to have to sacrifice a little bit of that strength work simply because you're losing size and losing mass. Great question. I'm going to touch on a couple things here as far as technique goes. One being a geared power lifter using squat suits and ventures for 15 years transitioning out of that took some time. I don't think people realize the difference between the two when you're solely focusing on your raw strength. I'm technique is going to have to change. I went from a very wide power lifting style squat with a suit on and I had to bring that in which, of course, causes you to have to use more hamstring, have to use more glute. I was very dominant in my low back so I had to be able to take that out of it and actually get my posterior chain to really engage and get involved. Now so now you start talking about not just the power lifting side of things but talking about bodybuilding and feeling muscular contractions. There is a difference and I think that's where people tend to look at the difference between the two. People might automatically assume that, oh, maybe bodybuilders aren't very strong because they're using less weight. When really all they are doing is literally focusing on muscular contraction. They're focusing on making sure that the right muscles are being used. The right muscles are being contracted, a leg curl, a leg extension, a lap pulled down, anything like that. You can use heavy weight but at some point there has to be a given take of just heaving a weight and actually feeling it contract. I think that's a big difference between power lifting and bodybuilders. Power lifting is one to move weight. We don't care what it is. We don't care how we do it at some point technique may actually take a back seat in order to just move the weight. But even just in your big lifts but you're talking barbel grows, you're talking overhead presses, you're talking about some of those big accessory movements where all we're doing is looking to move weight. Bodybuilders going to take their time a little bit slow things down and actually feel a muscular contraction. That was a big change for me going from, let's just hammer some heavy weights. Let's do some heavy rows, let's move some weight, let's curl, let's, you know, try some extension, let's do all these things that are going to build my lifts and let's just move weight. I don't care what else happens. Now what I'm learning is that backtracking a little bit in order to bring up some weaknesses, not just strength-wise but aesthetically too. So a lot pulled down. How do I get my last wider? Maybe I need to lighten the weight and actually focus on squeezing those muscles. How am I going to make my arms bigger to match the tricep size that I had for powerlifting? I had to lower the weight and actually focus on feeling a contraction. There is a big difference in the big lifts most certainly as well. From my experience a lot of it has to come from the geared side towards the, towards the Ross side. So, because I'm not a true bodybuilder at heart, I still have that power lifter inside of me. I'm always going to go, my big lifts are always going to be geared towards strength. And then the way Scott and I build our program is to bring up my aesthetics and the physique side of things through a lot of my accessory work.

=== FILE: Into The Void - Do you have what it takes？ [bgBg7pJXLOo].txt ===

It was my place to build and grow mentally and physically. Which like other kids who came from similar situations, I built walls around me. By walls were built of past iron and steel. It was something I was good at. I went from the kid that got fucked with to be in the kid you don't want to fuck with. Everybody's human, there's a time in your mind when you're going to want to quit and you do another rep. Then you do another rep and yes it's going to burn. Yes it's going to hurt. Yes everything your body is going to tell you to quit. But you keep going that shuts down. It stops and your mind stops telling you anything. You just go. And within those seconds that's what I'm talking about. That's the void. That's earned. Not give it.

And then, you know, on Friday night, a lot of the coaches who go out together or, you know, on Saturday, hey, what are you guys doing? And that's, it's that family environment. So when we bring someone else in, whether it's just an intern or whether, like, we bring someone in as a, who has a lot of experience, so we have our professional internship for coaches who have more than three years experience. No matter who we bring in, we have to know through that process that we've created that they're going to positively impact and uphold our culture. Because if they don't, then that, that to us, I mean, that's the most important thing. And we turn people away, client who, you know, we start going through an assessment process. And, you know, they're either fighting us or arguing with us or just not being like who we feel are good people. And if they are, then we just tell them, you're not a good fit for us.
