=== FILE: Julia Ladewski Explains Powerbuilding - elitefts.com [LgdHFPsbx5I].txt ===

I've been a competitive power lifterist since 1999, so going on 16 years now, had a pretty successful career in that, started off. Kind of in the low ranks, just like anybody else, and worked my way up to a couple really good championships and national championships. Three years ago, I picked up some bodybuilding. I did one figure show, and then went on to physique to where I could build a little bit more muscle, be a little more muscular, so right now I'm doing a little dance of balancing the two. In my mind, powerbuilding is the idea of wanting to be a strong possible, but also wanting to be big and lean. So we have those two characteristics that we're trying to develop, and I've seen over the last three years, as you've mentioned, that there are a lot of people coming out who want to be these dual athletes, especially women. And want to be strong, but we also are vain, and we want to look at as well. So we have these two sides to us that we want both. So we have a lot of dual athletes out there, and there are some very successful women who are doing both. Is it impossible to serve two masters? It's not. It's difficult, and I think it takes a lot of planning in your year-long preparation. You have to know when you're training for powerlifting. You have to know when you're training for bodybuilding, and you have to know how to transition from the two. I've seen maybe one or two women who have gone from powerlifting to bodybuilding in less than a month, and it's pretty difficult, but it can be done. So powerbuilding in essence is being able to be as strong as possible, but also still have the mass and size of a bodybuilder. As far as what, in my experience, what we've been able to do with my programming is exactly that. It is to be able to transition out of bodybuilding. We built my raw strength back up. A lot of it had to do with taking our first couple exercises to build strength, just like a powerlifting would. You do your main exercise, you squat, you deadlift, you bench, you might do a big supplemental exercise, and then everything else is based off of what aesthetic areas need to be brought up for me. It was my quads, and my shoulders. So after I benched, I was still keeping my strength working with bench, and then we just hammered a ton of volume on my shoulders, which is what I was able to bring my delta. So a lot of it is just being able to balance that too and knowing what the person needs to work on for their strength, and then also what aesthetic and physique exercises are also going to help enhance not just their strength, but also their looks too. It's not difficult to balance the two. I think they go hand in hand pretty well, but we always have to be aware that when you're working towards one, say strength, something else is always going to give. So you may lose some size in certain areas. If you're working towards physique and dieting down, you're going to lose some strength. So there is a balance there, and one thing that I've learned over the last year, in which I've taken a considerable off-season, is to be able to take the time to work towards one or the other. In the past I had balanced back and forth, and four months of power lifting, four months of physique, four months of power lifting. So this off-season really gave me a chance to focus on one and one thing only, which this off-season has been towards physique and the aesthetic side of building some mass. We haven't incorporated a lot of strength work. I've been refining and retuning some of my technique and some of my raw lifts, which has been great. But you can balance it, you just have to be aware of what it is that your body needs, and give yourself plenty of time to be able to build one rather than trying to serve two masters, as we know it's always a little difficult to do that.

=== FILE: Live, Learn Pass, On - Dave Tate's Most Popular Lecture [3KqgE1AS2YI].txt ===

Chalking up is awesome, isn't it? All right, that's live and man, you chalk up and you go to a bar, that's when shit gets real. All right, your adrenaline's running, you have passion, you love it, you're looking at possibly breaking a PR, getting better. All right. To me, that's what you want to strive for in life. You want to strive for getting your hands in the chalk box and moving forward. You can spend all your life in the warm-up room talking about things and trying. But to me, that's not living. Living's chalk in your hands, getting ready and taking that step from the box to the bar. Because that's that one step. So a few people take. Because that step is an easy and with that step comes risk. You go to lift a heavy weight to or one, I'm sorry, one of three things are going to happen. You're going to make it, you're going to miss it or you're going to get hurt. Two or three are not good. But one is awesome. That's why you want to strive for the chalk box. Get the hell out of the warm-up room, find something that empowers you, like that chalk box, to be able to move forward with your career, relationship, family, business, whatever it is. Because that's where life happens. If you're too afraid to dig in, chalk up, that's fine. That's your choice. That's the majority of society. I'd like to empower you to be better. Learn, learning is extremely important in all levels. And trust me, I have the worst educational past, not the worst. There's people who didn't graduate and people who've lunged out and everything else. Mine's not so great. And I don't want to go into details about it, but it took me way too long to graduate from college. I barely got out of high school. We'll just leave it at that. One question that I'm asking routinely is, is a college degree worth it if you want to be a personal trainer or a strength coach? And I just was presented that question the other day when Mark brought out some interns. I might own answer to that, but what I usually ask back is, well, what do you think? Nine out of ten times, eight out of ten times, I'm told, actually, no. I don't use anything that I learned in college, now that I'm coaching or working in this profession. And I agree for the most part that's probably true. Then I'll ask the next question, what we're in a seminar or a lecture or reading a book or listening to somebody speak, does that bullshit detector ever come on? You know what I'm talking about? What are you speaking? And all of a sudden, you think, what is that? Bing, you think maybe that might relate back to anatomy, physiology, biomarkinit, all those courses that you learn through college, you may not know why that sounds like complete utter bullshit. But something inside you is telling you that's bullshit. So the follow-up question to that would be, do you think you would still have that same bullshit detector right out of high school? Think about that for a second. Now with this, I don't want to talk about like student loans and the cost of college, just a whole different issue. But things just think about that, ponder that, especially the people who are still in school. And this is one of the reasons why I motivate and try to empower people to continue with that education. Because we are in an industry that very well could be the biggest industry of bullshit in the world. I can't think of very many others outside of that, that, that, through a better job than we do. You know, of false claims, BS, and all those type of things. That's close. That's close, but they're much better lectures than I am. And they can hide it better. But I will flip that back out. We're in the fitness profession. If you were in political science or a history with that bullshit detector come on faster when you're listening to politics. Because we already know with politicians, actually we know this for a dead fact, most of the people who vote have to include what the hell they're voting on. They have no bullshit detector. You think they might if they were more educated. The reason I chose the image of a squat for this is education can come from many facets. When you're the guy under the bar, you're the one that's got to hold the load. Ultimately, you're the one in your life who's responsible. You're responsible for your education, you're responsible for your success. You're, I don't care what excuses you throw out. You give me any excuse in the world. Give me a couple of minutes. Let me search Google. I will find somebody who had to overcome far more shit than you did and is better than you. So excuses are meaningless. We all know that as coaches, trainers, we know. So don't use them because they don't work. First off, nobody cares. Secondly, all you're trying to do is to justify your own inadequacies. You should embrace them and try to make them better. With the squat, and I am a power lifter by trade, I can't compete anymore. But it's like you want your meat head, your stuck in meat head for your rest of your life, and you do stupid shit forever. Eric, remember that? It's ingrained. It doesn't go away. And I don't know why. I try. It doesn't go away. When you compete, you have a head judge. Side judges, spotters, and a backspotter. The judges, I see in this scenario of education as being your advisors, people in your life who help to advise the direction and the path that you're going. Even our lectures, college, any education that comes from a formal type of setting, books, lectures, degrees, those are the judges. They impact if you're going to make that lift or not. They set the base on how it's going to be judged. And if you don't think your judge based upon what your education is, think for a minute, when you submit your resume, what are people looking at? So you are judged based upon your education. If you're not judged by that, you're going to be judged by what comes out of your mouth. If what comes out of your mouth sounds like somebody who's a stupid idiot, well then obviously, you're going to be a stupid idiot. So education is going to determine how you are judged. Spotters, right-side's family, left-side's friends. Family and friends are influential in your education as well. Birds of a feather flock together at that whole kind of thing. You can move forward because with age comes wisdom only if you learn from where you screwed up and how you got yourself in the situation in the first place. My advice is as I've gotten older, you go through more shit. I think that just kind of comes with life. You can't try to take a path to avoid that. That's a path of avoiding getting on the platform and getting under the bar. That's avoiding the path of actually making the lift, having success. You will miss without a doubt. You will miss. You will screw up. You will make mistakes. You will have people sticking knife in your back. You'll have people screw you over. You're going to, we've all been through it. We've all, our life. We're no longer that innocent child. Innocence gets stripped away real quick. That's not bad. That's growth. When you can learn to take shit and turn it into gold, that's education. That's learning. Lastly, you're the guy under the bar to come back to the beginning. You're responsible for how much you want to load it. How much you want to try to push yourself. How far out of your comfort zone you want to be able to go to become better, to develop better athletes, to develop better clients. That's continual education and learning. That does not stop when you graduate. It's constant. It has to be across several platforms. As I said before, I've learned a lot from my experience as a power lifter that I've been able to take over into business. A road of book on it. At the same time, now after being in business for 15 years, I could write a book on what I've learned about business that can transfer over to training. Key point here. You get outside your realm of your education. There are definitely lessons you can learn and bring back to make you better at what you do. That's going to make you a better individual, a better trainer, a better coach. You're going to have a unique philosophy. Nobody else has. The interns that came out the other day, one of them at the table was a history major. Are you here? No. No. Okay. If he goes into the strength and conditioning realm, his perspective is going to be completely different than somebody who's only studied exercise science. He's going to be able to fall back and create things that may have never been seen before, but are unique that will become his own training philosophy because of that. When I had to start learning about business, which I didn't want to really do, you don't have a choice when you step out and start a business because at that time you've become an entrepreneur. Your technical days are kind of over. When I had to step out and start learning that, I didn't want to learn it, but after time I began to build up a passion for wanting to learn it, how to develop and how to move forward. And at the same time as with training, the more you learn and any trade and any genre, the more you realize you don't know. The best coaches I know and the best people I know in this industry will tell you they're astounded by the amount of information they don't know because you start studying down one course or you start tracking down one course and then bam, you're like whoa, your brain starts to hurt because you're not just fell into a whole domain, you didn't even know affected the athlete, the trainer or your own training. For example, do you know your body doesn't know the difference between a training stress and emotional stress? Does that take into consideration when you're doing your programming? Does that take into consideration when you're doing your own training? Do you back volume and workload if you're going through fighting with your spouse or whatever it is? Are you continue to try to press hard because you know, screw her, I'm going to train hard.

=== FILE: Online Coaching Red Flags - elitefts.com [M4bRm8zAETQ].txt ===

Training programs are a bitch. You know, for me to write, you know, a powerlifting training program for somebody that's going to be specific to their strengths, their weak points, with the full needs analysis, is going to take me at least. I've done very little online training. So I'm going to be upfront about that. I've done a lot of personal training. I've done a lot of coaching. I've done a lot of consulting. So I'm kind of familiar with what the red flags are. I have used, you know, nutrition coaches. And I have a feeling that I'm going to probably need one for the rest of my entire life. I don't have very good luck doing this shit by myself. And so I know my responsibilities going in. So let's go from the nutritional standpoint first. And when you hire somebody to help you with your nutrition, I'm going to assume that you've done your due diligence and you've hired to, you feel as the best person for you. That you're not just going off one blind referral or you're not going off, you know, before and after shot that you see on Facebook or some other shit, that you've actually done some due diligence to determine if this person is going to be the right fit for you. What you need to understand going in is this, this is a professional relationship. So if they're going to tell you to do something, they're not only agreeing to be able to work with you. They're putting their own reputation on the line to work with you, which means that there's a responsibility on your part to protect their reputation as well. So if they're telling you to do something and then you're going around and you're doing everything completely opposite of what they're telling you to do, that's extremely extremely disrespectful to that person. Don't hire them. You're not ready for an online coach. Bale don't work with them because it's a disservice, it's disrespectful and it's a waste of their time. Don't make excuses. If you fuck up, they can make adjustments if you screw up every now and again. They expect you to screw up every now and again. If you're going to go 10 weeks solid and never make a mistake, I'm going to tell you right now, they know you're lying. So now it's a matter of they got to figure out how to dial you in to wherever you want to end up being, knowing that you're not giving them the full truth. The more open you are and the more honest you are with them, the easier their job is going to be to be able to get you to whatever your end goal is. So you have to be transparent. You have to be honest. You can't, I mean if you sneak a chip, tell them you snuck a chip. It's not that big of a deal. But don't bullshit them. It doesn't even make sense to me. Why would you pay somebody to help you and then bullshit them in a way that they can't help you? It's ludicrous. So that's your responsibility from the nutritional standpoint. It's to kind of do what they tell you to do. And if you can't do what they're telling you to do, you don't like the food. You can't eat that much food. The meal time is not right. I mean there's hundreds of things that can go wrong. Just tell them. I mean if they're good at what they do, they've already heard it before. They know how to work around it. They're not going to come back and say, well, just suck it up and do what I say. And if they do, well, then you know what, maybe you need to find somebody else. It's not a good fit. Now the responsibility on their standpoint is from my perspective, is to make sure they are treating you as an individual. And they're not giving you some bullet point or bullet plate bullshit that they're given everybody else. Because while you may be similar to a lot of people and 90% of what they're given everybody else, they could probably give to you as well. There's that 10% that's going to be different. So they need to be, if they're taking your money, they need to be making sure that they're making it specific to you. From a training standpoint, it becomes even more complicated. And I do not feel this is because I am more educated in the training standpoint than I am the nutritional standpoint. Many programs are a bitch. For me to write a powerlifting training program for somebody that's going to be specific to their strengths, their weak points, with the full needs analysis is going to take me at least 15 hours to put together right and correctly. And that's before I even send the program out, before I get videos back, before we do any adjustments. And then I still don't see them. I got to see them and see them. And one to two top reps at the end of a set isn't going to do shit. So I need to see a whole training session, they're not know how the accessories are going to work. So there's a huge time investment when it comes to actually online training and my opinion somebody properly. So immediately, it's probably impossible to do it properly from my perspective. So any online training is going to be condensed down. It's going to be kind of shrink wrapped into a manageable package that they're able to manage and get to you that you can be able to do what you need to do and to provide the feedback. Once again, the same thing happens there. Don't bullshit the person. If the person tells you your squats are freaking high, put them lower next time, squat lower next time. Because if you keep squatting high for six weeks of the 12 weeks of their trying to help you, they can't fucking help you come meet time. They need to make adjustments based upon you doing the lifts properly. So that can be a good 40 pounds difference on your training. So the other thing is you need to provide them with whatever they ask you for. So if they want videos at a certain day at a certain time, you need to be able to do that. And you need to respect that because the guys who are good at what they do, they have more than one client. A lot of them have between 40, 60 and maybe even more. So they're telling you that they need this information on a certain day at a certain time because they're blocking time off for you to be able to get that done. Because they have to manage their time otherwise they can't get their own training and then or have a life. They can't just spend their whole life waiting for your freaking email all day long on Friday. And the other thing is, condensure questions in one email. So you're not sending them 15 emails every single day. Now what you should in turn expect from them is you should be getting your training on time. So if you're training weeks to start on Sunday, you shouldn't be getting it Sunday morning. You should be getting it Saturday night so at least you have time. Or something happens and they have to get it to you Sunday morning, you're at least going to have it before you get to the gym. So it has to be on time. Getting a training program a week late isn't going to do anybody any good. They need to be making adjustments based upon the feedback that they're getting. If you go through a whole training cycle and no adjustments been made then they're not really paying attention. And so I guess that's kind of a very fast, condensed way of what to look for. But the one thing to keep in mind with online training is you're always going to find good testimonials, great positive testimonials, great feedback on everybody. You're always going to hear everybody talk about how great all their clients are. You're never going to see anybody post, oh here's my client who bombed out in a meet. Or here's my client who went to a show and looked like a fat pig. You're never going to see that. But they all have clients like that. So keep in mind everything that you're seeing is still a little bit of a mirage of what's actually happening. So don't trust everything that you see. And you can ask for referrals just like anything else. And they're going to give you the referrals they know are going to give you the answers that you want to hear. If you really are questionable on somebody, ask them for referrals on clients that left them. And more than likely they're not going to give you anybody. But if they give you somebody and then you contact them, you'll know what their strengths and weaknesses are. And you know what, maybe it's not that big of a deal for you. Maybe the person left the guy because they got hurt, maybe they left the guy because that just wasn't they couldn't train five days a week and they needed to train five days a week. You know, that's the referral. I would want to know. You know, that's the referral. I want to know when I go to do business with somebody is I don't want the referral of the person that's happy. I want the referral of the person that had a bad experience because then I'm going to know what their weaknesses are and I'm also going to know what they did to try to correct it when it was going bad before it went too far south.

=== FILE: Should Bigger Lifters Pull Sumo or Conventional？ ｜ elitefts.com [Won7cJ_lHe8].txt ===

This guy said you talked about the deadlift conventional in this guy's case going down with weight gains. What is the first sign that you see of that happening in your form? What's this guy said he was 220 now he's 230 aiming for 240 too. You shouldn't notice it with that well I don't know because it's going to matter how tall you are. In that weight range I don't think you're going to notice that that much. The first place that people are typically going to see is going to be in their hands. They're going to get fat hands and they're not going to be able to hold the bar. So you're going to see it in the grip which I understand that if it's similar or conventional it's not going to make any difference. But my deadlift went back and forth so much based upon where I weighed. It seemed like the bigger my torso got, the more inclined I was to pull conventional because I could use my torso to drive into my legs to start the bar where when I was thinner if you want to say that when I was leaner then I didn't have the ability to do that but I did have the ability to get in a better position to where I could get my back and shoulders more upright my hips closer to the bar with the sumo stance. So it was more my leverages that changed based upon the weight gain. But the one thing that I always did from the very beginning is I always pulled both ways. So I always pulled sumo always pulled conventional now I might be a little bit stronger and one than the other. It's certain periods of my competitive career but it wasn't by that much maybe 30, 40 pounds. So I always kind of had the option during a meet that if I if my back got a little tweaked on the squat I could always switch it to sumo and it the very worst if I was more inclined to pull conventional then sumo with the very worst I might lose 20, 30 pounds on the pole but it was kind of a relevant because I went and been able to pull shit conventional if my back was tweaked or if my hips were worn out because I squatted wide then I probably wasn't going to be able to sumo pull and I would know after I wouldn't know before you even doing a warm-up on the deadlift you know where I was at so I was able to kind of bounce back and forth but one was always definitely stronger than the other based upon that but it was the leverage thing and the way that I knew was if I was able to use my torso or my stomach into my thighs it's a start of the lift if I could do that and conventional was always the best route to pull. Sumo you know it wasn't often that it was sumo but it was throughout the 275 for me anything over to anything over 280 it kind of started to slip back into conventional it was also during the I think 220s it was conventional it was better from leverage standpoint and the sumo just sucked so it if the wall is your train and both here and there you kind of have a good idea but they're both have different technical aspects so you can't just pull one and then pull the other and say well this feels better because your sumo form ages suck and you didn't take time you know to master what that form is and that takes time it takes a lot more time than people think you know even and advanced lift that really knows what the fuck you're doing if they're shifting from one style of deadlift to another style of deadlift it could take six months to a year to be able to hone that in and have it be exactly where they need it to be on the day of a meat where it matters so it's going to take longer than people think where if you're learning them both from the very beginning it's going to take less to be able to go from one to the other I can't from the moon desert on my hands strong like a tree there's roots rest in oh I've been running from the law

=== FILE: Swede Burns & Dave Tate Discuss Bar Position For The Squat ｜ elitefts.com [fZR-3Y8bpk0].txt ===

When trying to lower the bar on a back squat, it's hard to adjust my left arm because it's stiff. I end up doing high bar, recommendations or corrective exercises for my arm so I can lower the bar. Sounded to make sure that I understand the question correctly. Okay, so just tell me if I'm wrong, as I start to repeat this. We got somebody who is squatting high bar. Essentially because he doesn't have the shoulder mobility to get the bar lower. That's what it sounds like, yes. Okay. Specifically because it's left arm. Right, because something's going, it's always one shoulder or the other and that's why an end up looking helicoptered. You know, when you have somebody to steal them with that sort of thing where they're trying to progressively get the bar in a better position but. Stop and say. Yeah, so the one side has great mobility and one side's injured and doesn't end ends up looking like the whole time. My advice would be to do the mobility work that you need to get that bar where you need it but where you need it is really the question because I think I see most people putting the bar lower than it's benefiting them too. That's causing a lot of issues. There's obviously a lot of factors in terms of limb length and individual differences and so forth. Mass and a topical variance, like one person's not the same as the other but most people want to say most I'm looking at like 90% range or somewhere in the mid bar range. Like in mid between high and low in terms of what will be beneficial. And I see a lot of people putting the bar lower than they need to and that's one of the corrections I'm making is very common. It's bringing the bar up a couple inches and a matter of an inch in terms of your shoulders and elbows and the amount of the roundifications that are going to affect the rest of your training to get the bar an inch lower. It's actually gotten to the point where I have to ask myself, is it worth having this person to fight to get the bar that much lower considering how much of an impact is going to have on their squat. And then I figure how much of an impact is going to have on their bench having that bar lower because it always does cost. Have the bar a little bit lower and it's up effect in the bench and negative way training and it ends up affecting the pool. Yeah, so you have to ask yourself like, is it what's the best answer for the total? However, when you have a situation like where you're talking about where one shoulder doesn't have a range of motion that's necessary to get the bar where you want it and have it stable and have it be where it's not twisted on the squat. That needs to be addressed. So I would have them either talk to a PT or do whatever needs to be done in terms of mobility stuff. But soon when there's no structural impingement there to get that shoulder in the position they need to. And then with the way that we train, we're easily able to hammer this stuff out because you have the bar on your back every week. You're always doing that same kind of bar. We're always squat on where the squat bar. So we're really drilling that. We're really able to get into a position that's effective and learn to cue the upper back effectively, excuse me, trying to much so that. Learn to cue the upper back effectively so that you can keep the bar where you need it without having it like super high, super low and stable as in that bar is a big thing too. Something to you guys, a cue I see that seems to be pretty popular is wrecking people. Left and right. I'd do a pull in the bar down. And I'd do a pull in the bar down onto your back, wider squatting. You can be devastating, depending on the position. So if you're already in a position where you maxed out your shoulder mobility, your elbow mobility in terms of how much flex you have at the elbow and you're actively pulling down on that bar on the descent on the squat, during the reversal there's always some flex, even in a squat bar. But you have for better using a gym bar. So think about that flex and you're pulling down and helping with that flex. That flex is going to return on the reversal and you're essentially doing a max effort one inch negative. You know, when your elbow is in shoulders, every rep, every time you take it heavy squat. And for all lifters that tend to move a lot faster, that's even more of a consideration. So another big thing there is to make sure that people are wearing wrist wraps when they squat, because I can help a lot with the elbows, believe it or not, elbows in the shoulders. Because the weakest link in the chain to hold that bar on your back is your wrists. And the elbows in shoulders tend to try to accommodate, try to protect the wrist and causes more issues with elbow tendonitis and stuff like that, which affects the bench presses as well. And the shoulder stress and all the other stuff affects the bench press. So I try and take like a try to keep a holistic view of like all three lifts, like look at the total. Look at that. I don't just ask myself, what is this change going to affect on this lift? Ask myself, what is this change going to affect on this lift? There's total. Yeah, because sometimes one thing will be positive in one lift when I look at the big picture, which is actually a bad move. You know? So something to think about there, just a little additional stuff on top of the bar placement, but definitely address the shoulder mobility, any way you're able. === FILE: The Bulgarian Split Squat： Which Side Should You Load？ ｜ elitefts.com [1GkQNVWXBp4].txt ===

It's going on guys, Jordan Shallah here with the lead FTS. Just going to go through kind of a visual that helps us to see an article that I wrote about unilateral loads in the Bulgarian split squat. Now Bulgarians, what's what? Really good, gait cycle variation of an exercise. We use a supplemental accessory, especially if you're going to be squatting. It's nice to kind of get our hips into a bit of extension. Now, there's some sort of argument based around does it make a difference of where we load the dumbbell if we're going to load one side. We have what's called the center of mass, like an equilibrium point that allows us to stay balanced, given our certain positions. So, if we're here, we're going to be limiting what's called their base as support. So, how we apply weight to this position is going to dictate how we deviate our center of mass. And that's going to use different muscles to help stabilize and keep us upright. So, the two ways we can do it are obviously with the stance leg, in this case being the left leg, we can either have the dumbbell in the same hand, which is going to look like this. Or we're going to have the dumbbell in the opposite hand, which is going to look like this. Now, both of these are going to deviate this sort of hypothetical center of mass, this hypothetical equilibrium point, and cause different muscles to work. Now, if we want to be really specific, we can sort of break down how the dumbbell affects what planes of resistance we're going to have to stabilize through. So, let's start with same side as the stance leg. In this position, what we're going to be loading is we're going to be loading kind of more laterally. So, I'm put the dumbbell in the same side as the stance leg. What I want to default to is this. So, a glute mean, which is a muscle that laterally stabilizes this left hip right now, not working at all. QL, muscle that laterally stabilizes on the opposite side of the lumbar spine is not working at all. Get the most out of this loading parameter what we're going to do is we're going to try to get this forearm off the hip by straightening up and we're going to try and keep a tall spine through the lower back. Now, this QL laterally stabilizes the lumbar spine on the right, and this glute mean is laterally stabilizing the hip on the left. So, loading in this position is going to work more glute mean and stance leg. QL opposite side has we just send straight down and then back up. Now, switching over to the opposite. Let's go to the contrary load, which is now we have the dumbbell in the opposite side of the stance leg. This is going to be more rotational. If I let this dumbbell do its thing, it's just going to pull me like that. So, in order to stay stable, now we're going to use a whole new subset of muscles. We're going to use the external oblique to resist this movement from happening on the opposite side of the stance leg. And we're going to be using the high-eyed actors and growing muscles to complete what's called an anterior oblique sling, something we cover in the article. So in this position here, we want to stop that rotation from happening. In the first position, we want to stop the lateral flexion. Now we want to stop the rotation. Stability by definition is how well we can resist force. We're trying to resist these movements from happening as we apply the dumbbell, which is purposely going to deviate our center of mass to a position that we need to then resist. We need to be specific based off of where we find our imbalances and instability. So here, dumbbell goes straight down with the ground. And lower and come right back up. So I'm using my oblique here to stop that rotation from occurring. So small difference in theory, but in an application, makes the huge difference on what muscles we're going to recruit. So that's how we sort of pick out where we apply unilateral load to the exercise of Bulgarian slots. Let's go. Hey, wait. Alright guys, if you've been, I had a stupid shit. === FILE: The Highland Hornets Are Custom Built ｜ elitefts.com [VNw8YWQOXno].txt ===

I have a set of principles and I learned this from Reed and Jim Wendler's work and listening to him at some of the seminars and whatnot. He has his five principles within his five-three-one system. I have seven principles that I kind of change him out here and there when I need to, just based on what I've learned and how my experience has changed. But I always start people where they're at and too light. So I'd rather them start easy and work the way up. We're always going to look to progress slowly and regress one necessary. So if you've got a kid that's going through a mild injury but they're not seeing physical therapy or whatnot, we got to take him back to where they need to be. === FILE: Three Favorite Hamstring⧸Glute Exercises - elitefts.com [c8V2PuLDf40].txt ===

I have spent a lot of time the last year doing a lot of hamstring work. Those two things work my hamstrings phenomenally. And then I obviously also do a lot of leg curl variations. Specifically I like single leg curls just because for me it helps me to focus a little bit more on a deeper contraction. I can slow the movement down a little bit. One other variation that I shouldn't say a variation or an exercise. What we do a lot in my training is we tempo those exercises a lot. So a leg curl you could go in every week and do a leg curl machine. But how you switch that up can really make a big difference. So you can do slow tempo reps. You can do east centrics. You can do fast reps. You can do rest pause. You can drop set. So there's a lot of variations that you can throw in. They're taking that same exercise and just making it different from week to week in order to bring about a little bit of a different change in the muscle.

When the biggest thing the power of this can do is to get to the other diet. So diet plays a huge part not just in their strength and in their performance but also in their recovery as well. So especially when you're talking about going into a meat where they have to either cut weight, make weight, rehydrate, refuel, you know, for the next day. That's going to play a huge role in how they perform. So for a power lift they're looking to stay within their weight class, diet is by far going to be one of the biggest things that they can handle. Offseason conditioning is another thing that can help as well if they're far enough away from a meat, add in some conditioning work, some higher volume stuff that can help keep their weight down. Some tips for athletes dieting for a show. One of the biggest things is nutrition, yes, but it's preparation. You really have to be on point and prepared with what your coach gives you to eat. If you're on the road, if you travel, if you have a job, if you have kids, you have to know what you need to eat and how to balance that in with the rest of your life. It's not an easy task. It requires a lot of Tupperware and a lot of patients from, you know, the people around you that you live with. The other thing is to make sure that your food actually tastes good and this comes from my experience. I spent about eight months eating probably close to the same foods, the same meals day and day out. It varied in the amount of food I was eating, whether I was pre-contest or post-contest. By about month eight, I hit a wall where I literally had no appetite and could not stomach anything to where all I was doing was choking down, chicken and rice and drinking shakes and finally, my coach said to me, you need to change your food. And so we did and finally started to come back around again. So making sure that the food that you eat is enjoyable, but also when you're in that time period of being flexible, where you're off season or your post-show, have some flexibility in your foods. You can still eat, you can still stay on point, you can still stay lean, but just being able to mix in those foods that are good, that we know we should be eating and just have a little bit of variety and that'll help in a long run. How do you set up your diet four weeks before a competition? This is a great question and it's also very difficult to answer. Four weeks before a comp, you're really looking at and it doesn't specify whether it's powerlifting or bodybuilding. So I'll go from a little bit of both aspects there. From bodybuilding, four weeks out, it really depends on what we did the previous eight weeks. So for myself, most of my shows, I'm dieting for about 12 to 14 weeks. What happened those previous weeks sets me up for where I am four weeks out. Once I'm four weeks out, most everything should be dialed in. We should be almost to the leanness that we want to be, coach checks for tightness of the skin. We might play around with a little bit of water manipulation going into the show. But at that point, you're really looking at lowering the carbs, obviously, because we want to draw some of the body fat and some of the water out. Protein usually stays about the same. Typically, for most bodybuilders going into a show, fat is going to be relatively low as well. From the powerlifting side of things four week out, four weeks out, you want to make sure that you're in a good place for your weight class. So if you're too far above your weight class, that's when you should start really cleaning up your diet, making sure that you can settle in nicely and make a safe weight cut. At that point, again, just clean foods. Powerlifter should just clean it up about four weeks out. Good quality foods. Make sure they're close to your weight class. Make sure you're well hydrated. Again, so it makes for an easier weight cut.

=== FILE: Training Economy For The Washed-Up Meathead ｜ elitefts.com [nam1f2n8aTU].txt ===

uh... can date over training economy again for the older washed up meat yes uh... just do what you have to do you know it's is i wrote in the article it's it's gonna be easier for you to do because you're you're an older washed at me head so you kind of know what's important what's not important so when you're looking at your training session let's say you were you're gonna write it out before you go into the gym which most older washed up meatheads are not going to do but say that that's say you were right and let me let me reframe this let's say you you did a full training session and then you went home and wrote it down afterwards when you look at that training session how much of the shit did you do did you really have to do to meet whatever your training objectives are with most of us i'm gonna be willing to gas it's it's a third or a half of that whole training session so just get rid of the shit you know get rid of the shit that's not going to help move you forward and you can keep in some of the stuff that's fun like i get that i get that more than anybody you know keep that stuff in there but understand that some of that stuff maybe to the detriment of your ability to recover so there's a trade that you got to be able to make with yourself and sometimes that trade is definitely worth doing because you really like doing that sometimes it's not so you just have to look at it from a little bit different perspective and make that call based upon that so it's training economy is basically doing the least amount possible to get the greatest yield of the greatest result and keep in mind too that if you increase the training density in other words you you know lower the rest between sets from ten-fuck a minutes between sets down to to you know you're gonna increase the overall more than likely you're gonna increase the overall workload as well but you're gonna increase the the effort expanded during the training session so you're gonna actually be able to get more out of the training session that we're going to get I can't frame them up desert on my hands strong like a tree there's roots where I stand oh I've been running from the law

=== FILE: What are the best core exercises？ - TABLE TALK - elitefts.com [HcpmTYabfcw].txt ===

So rather than answer this in both ways, I'm just gonna assume that he's talking about, you know, the muscles that fall between your chest and your cock and kind of go from there. What core exercises do you use? And when in your training do you use that? Core exercises. Core needs to be defined because I think I know what big ginger Viking is talking about, that's actually a pretty cool name. I think it's, I think he's talking about abdominal lower back and oblique as far as being core. The other definition of core exercises would be what I would call supplemental exercises or the main exercises in your program. So rather than answer this in both ways, I'm just gonna assume that he's talking about, you know, the muscles that fall between your chest. And your cock and kind of go from there. If that's not the answer that you're looking for, you know, fire back, you know, the question and we'll go from there. And I'm also gonna assume that you're speaking from a strength training standpoint and not a bodybuilding standpoint, which is, I would have two different answers. But for both, I think the number one abdominal exercise is the hanging leg raise. And I've said that for years and I believe that whole part of the end, I think there's a better exercise that you can do for your abdominal region than the hanging leg raise. And I'll explain the reasons for that here in a second. The second exercise of the pull-down have movement, which I am the process of filming now. I already have one film, which is me correcting and properly to do it as a warm-up and the properly to do it as a warm-up, which I should be thrown up on my training log within the next couple days. What I need to film next is the way to do it during your training session. So part of this question is when do you do the core exercises for strength athlete? I like to do the core athletes or the core exercises, torso exercises before training and also during the main training session. So you can think of it as being part of part of the warm-up. Before training protocol, for almost every power of the drive-off, I've ever worked with would be pull-down abs or leg raises and reverse hypers or back raises. Typically it's going to be reverse hypers. When it's done beforehand, the repetitions are going to be higher somewhere in the 15 to 25 depending upon the conditioning. You don't want to wear yourself out and you don't even really want to get off. You just want to kind of loosen up the reason why I like to pull down abs is a warm-up exercise or as the first exercise. More than I like the heavy leg raise is it gives you the opportunity to stretch your hamstrings and to stretch your hip flexors and to stretch your abdominals. When you do the exercise right, you're going to be standing with a cable attachment strap hooked up under your neck, not weight out of your waist, but kind of under your neck. With your butt away from the machine, so you're not braised. If the top of the movement that cable is going to be pulling you up in an upward angle, so basically stretching and pulling and in a way kind of decompressing, it's a terrible decompression, but it still is kind of decompression and pulling you from the top. So if that point top position, you're actually being pulled back under your heels a little bit and your stance should be either deadlift or squat stance depending on the way you're training that day. But at that top, what you're doing is you are stretching the abdominals, you are stretching the hip flexors because you're standing in the full upright position or locked out that lift position. When you bend over, you don't want to snap it down explosively, you just want to bend over, it's not going to take a whole lot of weight to do this. You're going to bend over, it's going to, your lower back is going to round. So you're going to be trying to stretch your mid and lower back in the bottom position. At the same time, you'll have a slightly bent in, you're going to push your hips back. So you're going to try to stretch your hamstrings out at the same time. So in the bottom position, you should feel a hamstring stretch in the lower back stretch in the top position. You should feel your hip flexor stretching, your quad stretching a little bit and even your abdominal wall stretching a little bit. How many repetitions it really doesn't matter, you know, 10, 15, 20, and you don't want to produce, you know, you don't want it to become a strength training exercise. It's just warming up. How many sets, however many you think it takes to tell you, the first set is usually going to feel like crap. You're going to bend over, you're going to like, oh, man, my back's tight or my hamstrings are tight. Once everything starts to feel loose, then you're good. Then you move on to the reverse hypers, typically what I would do is the second exercise as the warm up. And on that, I would do reverse hypers with a slight swing to it. You know, I want to do a video on the reverse hypers, well, a few different ways to do those. There's there's a really loose heavy way that you can do it, which isn't probably going to be the best for the warm up because a real strict way that you can do it, which also isn't really that the greatest for warm up because it's going to make your way back to tight. And then there's just, you know, moving, you know, just swinging. So with the swinging you're going to use a lighter weight, you're going to pull up flat shukles, let it come down until the axis or the post that holds the plate is about midpoint between the front, between the front and the back leg of the machine. And then you're going to reverse it before it reverse the year on that we're talking to 10 repetitions. That would be the warm up protocol and on that with lifters that I've worked with. I have that perform four days a week. So even other bench days, it's been done before the training. Where to implement the four torso training into the program. That's going to fall in where I call the accessory exercises or even post accessory exercises, three have rehab, whatever you want to call it. So at the very end of the training is where it's going to fall. That's what I like to put it for most people unless it really, really is one of their biggest weaknesses. And it's going to fall more towards, you know, after the main movement of the day, which could be this lot deadlift bench, good morning board grass, whatever the main movement is towards the end of what exercises. For strength, I stick with the same things, you know, the hanging leg raise, the reverse hyper and the pull down has it. And when you find, and this is the thing when it comes to accessory exercises and movements, the light that they're going to be trained in higher rep ranges is you can make slight modifications to these and never really have to change the exercise ever. There's no reason to have to change them every four weeks, every six weeks, because you can change the way they're being done. So if you're going to do the hanging leg raise, for instance, if you want to do that is your abdominal strength exercise for the day, then do them with knees back with defense, how strong you are, but knees back with the dumbbell being held between your legs or the ankle weights on four, three sets of failure, you know, three sets of 10, 15, whatever it's going to be. And then the next week's a commensi, if you can get more repetitions out of the three sets, and that's where you can come in and see if you can get more repetitions out of the three sets. So since you can't do more repetitions, then you can switch the way you're doing the exercise. With this exercise, the way you would do that is you drop the ankle weights and then you just go to a straight leg version, or you try to kick the bar, you know, at the top of the rack or whatever you're doing the movement on. So you bring your feet up straight leg, and you do as many reps as that as you can for X number of weeks. Then you can go back down and do a bent knee version, you know, and put the weight someplace else. So there's always different ways to change it. The pull down abs is the same way you got different stances and you got different straps, we've been holding different positions. For me, these, those three movements, the pull down abs, the reverse hyper or four movements, the reverse hyper, the back raise and the straight leg raise were, and have always been the movements that had the highest correspondence to a squat bench and deadlift. But I always stayed with them, but I will change how they're done, how they're performed or like this, from the foot position, from the loading, from a repetition perspective, even from a tempo perspective, or from sometimes it could just be eccentric only. There's a million, not a million, but there's hundreds of ways that you can change each one of these exercises. So as soon as you stop progressing, change it, and then you'll circle back, and then you circle back to the way you were doing it before that you stop progressing, you're going to find that you're actually stronger at it than we were when you first started. That heavy training of the torso would be done, only on the squat and deadlift days, there's other accessories that need to be done on the bench days or the pressing days, that have to deal with the shoulders and rows, and things that need to be done there. I think the word pre-ad that need to be done there for pre-ad from that standpoint. === FILE: What's Missing From Younger Lifter's Approach To Training ｜ elitefts.com [aWAkfc4EKas].txt ===

What do you feel is missing from how lifters approach their lifting in today's strength world? I kind of know the answers. I don't know how I would hit the answer. I've been in this powerlifting thing in one form or another for this spring will be 40, 40, I've been around, I started training my first meat 40 years ago. That's fucking old. So I've seen things come, go, come back again, go, come back again. So many times, probably some things that are kind of big things. I'm now seeing like the third iteration of the same trend all over again. The first couple times you don't really know any better because you haven't really seen it. You don't pay that attention, no it's just touched it. Now you see it all over. It just doesn't even face me. It's like whatever you're going to get into round and around. Anyhow, the biggest thing, if I want to look way back to today and a lot of things have changed and most things have changed for the better. There's no doubt in my mind that's changed for the better. There's more information which I don't think is a bad thing. You just have to learn how to decipher the information. I don't think that's even that hard. I really don't. If you can't tell something's complete out of bullshit, then I don't know what to tell you. I really don't. If you're in the field and you're treated in it professionally, like you want to learn from it, you're going to be able to determine what's kind of bullshit and what's not bullshit. From that standpoint, I would rather have a whole lot of stuff to determine what's bullshit and what's not bullshit. And then have to wait every month for a new magazine to come out and then walk to the bookstore to get the magazine and you know, and text books and all the other stuff. Now it's so it's so much stuff that you see a lot of different viewpoints where coming up through for me during the younger times. Maybe I did see a lot of different viewpoints, but it wasn't at the same time. You know, say high intensity training was in Vogue. So that was the popular thing or high volume training. That was the popular thing. Or you stumble across something and then you do a deep dive on that. And so I guess in one aspect, it was probably easier for me to do deep dive on stuff because I wasn't exposed to so many different things at one time. We're now people exposed to so many different things that I don't think they do a deep dive. Really odd anything unless they decide, I want to try this. And then they start to do a little bit deep dive until it gets a little technical, then they don't want to do it anymore. But at least they do some, but I think most people just get stuck on the surface level of everything. And that kind of touches upon what I think is the biggest difference in that is personal and personal. Accountability. And this I think is began to become more of an issue in the last half decade. You know, since maybe 2010, 2015, decade half decade, kind of, and that's 10 of it. And then that range. And where we're, we're it just looking at a powerlifting perspective because that's where I have the greatest history at Strainth and Conditions. Maybe 10 years less than what that is. Pretty safely say that, Strainman, I don't know, but, you know, they come in and they don't think they can compete unless they have a coach, which means they're never going to compete in their life unless they have a coach, ever. And so all that accountability that they were going to take, now I get shifted to the coach. Now you're granted, yes, they still have to show up, they still have to do the work, they still have to do all those things. But somebody's telling them, you know, that's what you do, this is what you need to do. And if adjustments seem to be made, they're going to make the adjustments, so they're never going to learn how to make adjustments and all these different. And that's a huge part of the process. Maybe it's my biased, you know, maybe it's, you know, my age and the experience and how I came up shining through there, I'm not ignorant enough to not know that could be a big part of this. But I do think that there's a problem where people won't compete or think they won't compete unless they have a coach. And if we move that forward several years, which I think that we've seen in powerlifting over the past five, which is what I'm talking about. Now those people who are in the industry that used to be those people that would, you know, help other people in the gym show them how to power lift, you know, say, here, go read this, you know, program or do this program. And, you know, basically guide them, you know, on how to do their meat are now people that have never had anybody do that for them. They always had to pay. So now that they've been doing it for five years, there's no fucking way. They're going to help somebody else because they had to pay for everything that they know. So that's where we're at now is if somebody's coming into a sport, into the sport, it's very hard for them to find somebody that's going to help them. === FILE: Why You Should Pull the SSB Handles In While Squatting ｜ elitefts.com [0BbgycYEIRQ].txt ===

It's going on guys, Jordan Shallon here with the lead FTS. A little bit of clarification on an article I wrote about how to cue effectively the safety squat bar squat. To better overload your arrecters. Now, the arrecters are an interesting muscle group that help stabilize your spine. They kind of run vertically from your pelvis up through your thoracic spine. Now, if your power lift or having a strong upper back is going to be paramount and building a big total. And this is a great adjunct, a great accessory exercise to help overload the arrecters if loaded properly. So when you unwrapped the safety squat bar, the handles are going to be out in front of you. The common mistake that people make is that in the hole they start to push up on the handles this takes the load off the arrecters. Muscles for the most part, especially muscles of stability have a function and an action. We want to train the function. The function is how we're actually going to stabilize the spine. So a lot of people think that we want to train the arrecters like you train a bicep by shortening it, right? Shracking shorten. But what we actually want to do is we want to leave it in that unstable position. So it stabilizes the spine and the greatest degree possible under the heaviest load possible. So you set up your squat stance as you would for this particular center of mass. So a lot of people tend to go a little bit wider. It's been more of a hip dominant squat. But the key before you initiate, as we spoke about in the article, is actually tucking your ribcage down and pulling the handles into you. Now this causes a flexion in the upper back. So my low back is neutral. My upper back is flexed. Now the arrecters are turned on. This is where the arrecters function as anti flexors. So we want to maintain as much flexion in the upper back as we can with the long gesturation possible. That's how we're going to get the most bang for our buck when utilizing the safety squat bar to squat. So you take it in, hail, breath in. The ribcage is going to come up. That's fine. Now in this swing with the swing back we have it on this lead for back foot, so we don't get how much flexion they're going to serve. In this swing with this sleeve, it's from the 3.0 range in luk, then it sounds like you know how much flexion they're gonna turn down to the average cam, really. If your knee being visible, you don't have, it's at a high level. of that thoracic spine to make sure it doesn't go any further. So, breath in, rib cage up. Before you descend, rib cage down. That creates that flexion on the upper back. Go into your squat pad and then we're pulling the handles into us the entire way. And then even on the way up, we're most people would push up on the handles and extend the upper back. We want to keep those erected functioning, pull in and then leg drive up, keeping the handles pulled down the entire time and the upper back flex. This is going to allow for consistent or constant tension through the erectors and help you get the most out of building upper back strength when you're rising the safety squat button. Hey, wait. Alright guys, if you've been, I had a stupid shit. Alright guys, make sure to subscribe to our YouTube channel, select notifications, but also keep in mind we do have a website, the leadfts.com. On our website, we put up two new articles every single day, seven days a week. We also have training logs that are updated daily, coaching blogs which are updated daily, archived history of over a million Q&As that are on the website. And if I did, how much of a role I played, but I mean, I think, if you see what, you know, after Dave made those transformations, you know, almost 10 years ago now, I think the sports really changed. I mean, you can go to, you know, any of the powerlifting experiences, things that the lead does. And you look at the coaches there. And you can't tell the guy in our full wearing red shirts, the guy in the red shirt, the bodybuilder or power left, I mean, they look the same now. I think, you know, Dave showed the how important nutrition can play. And you tell your guy, I mean, I'm sure Dave was just as strong at 245 pounds as he was at 308 pounds. Well, now at 245 pounds, that same 308 strength he can repeat in the 242 pound weight class. You know, and I think that's, you see, it also, if you look at the World Record numbers, how much they shot up in the 222, 225 pound weight class, where you used to be, you know, the 308s and super heavies had the big numbers. You got to 220 and the numbers were respectable, but, you know, now those 242, 222 pound numbers are enormous. They're just as high as the, you know, with the 308s we're attending years ago.

And then you can have that last set as a burnout set. So, go ahead, just do a couple more. And again, same thing. If you want the athlete to tap, that's fine. If you want the athletes to have a longer pause, that's okay too. But what we're doing is we're working up. Now, we're on the three boarded, it's foam of foot. Now, we're working on the three board. Right. And again, as the athlete gets more fatigued, we're working up to a less range of motion. Okay. Now, basically, with your athletes, if you have a difference in arm length, you might have some athletes only go with, only go with, we don't have four boarders go to two two's. So, you can have the athlete with the longer arms, maybe they go up to a five, maybe they don't. But again, as the athlete gets more fatigued, they're going to have less range of emotion. So, they're going to go ahead and work their way up. You can do with that as far as progressing, you can add weight for the set. If you have a rep cap, where they're going to stop at a certain total amount of reps, and you can basically work your way up with that with the amount of weight that's being used in the amount of reps as well. So, again, that's really easy. If you have a lot of athletes, obviously you're going to have a set of at least three to four athletes, and maybe you have a spotter, and someone watching the board. But again, someone with one working your way up to four or five, depending on the athlete, really good way to get some high-purchary work with a minimal amount of time, and not a lot of logistical concerns, because again, the athletes in one place with one set of reps not changing any weights for that set. So, give that a try.

Mark Watts, leadFDS.com. I'm here at Showtime Strength and Performance in Newark, Ohio with owner Nick Schoeman. There's one of those obstacles we want to try to maybe help you overcome. In general, what we try to do with beginners is get them to the point when a first of this she's set up that they can actually their knees actually fall through. And eventually we want to get to the point where we're gravitating toward a better set up than that. For a most part, we start with their knees falling through and with the back post, the foot post, all the way down. What happens is their shins will be in a straight line across. Now, for most of your athletes, regardless of height, the difference in lower leg length, this and very much. So again, you can usually get where you need to in the adjustments. Now what happens from there is once the athlete can maintain proper form and progress to the rep range you want them to, the way that you can do it as far as progress them is obviously you can have external resistance. But you know, sometimes there's a better way to do that. So if you have an athlete that is ready to move forward, the one thing we like to do is just move that adjustment. There's two things. You can move the foot place up. Now, what that does is that'll get that foot higher, it'll get that shin and a downward angle. And really, what happens is the other thing with this set up too is that now you can have the athlete. I can still feel his knee, but he's getting pretty close. So again, the other thing that Nick talked about was controlling that eccentric, which is, which is usually important to get them, get ready. And if you have beginner athletes, this is a first time. Obviously you're going to be a little bit apprehensive. So we've been in a couple of methods, either you can just actually hold hands with the athlete or you can actually get your hands across, get your fist across so that they need to push, they can push all the way. Couple things technique wise. Tuck the chin, something we got from Joe Chilero as far as make it sure they're not using that upper back to gain momentum. The other thing we like to do is at the bottom, do one more at the bottom, make sure we can get our knees locked. Push your toes, snap your head back with your chin down. That'll help with the beginning athletes. And again, from here, instead of if they're not ready to move that adjustment forward, so their knees are into the side of the pad, just move the back of it, the back end up. And again, same thing. The biggest thing is making sure that his knees do not drop down too far at the beginning of that movement. So that's really a thing that we've seen a lot of is again, those knees come way down. And then all they're really doing is just, they're really just pushing those knees up to maintain that straight leg instead of really, they shorten the lever arm. You want that lever arm as long as possible. That's how you're going to get to most work for each individual rep. So try those adjustments. And again, when you're in general, try to get them, start them back, move the foot plate forward in progression and the foot plate up. And to get to a point where they can make this exercise as difficult as possible before you get into external resistance. External resistance.

=== FILE: elitefts.com - Back Building with Dave Tate and the Short Tsunami Bar [tyUWgqfMdd4].txt ===

This is something that we've been messing around with for a while. It's basically just a short tsunami bar. These are the comfort grips that if you've been following my log, I mean right in the bottle a little bit here and there. And then we have them attached on here with the crock block collar so they don't slide off. What the tsunami bar does is got a little bit of things to it. And then they come for grips also have some flex to it as well. So this allows during the pull down movement to try to bend the bar as you're pulling it down, which is causing a greater and a tighter contraction. I like to face a way on this movement to be able to get the upper middle back a little bit harder than what I typically can if I'm using a straight bar facing away. Because of the nature of the way that this whole thing bends and that set up, I try to pull with my middle two fingers and let the rest of the hand relax to be able to get that tighter contraction and the mid part of my back. For most of my back work, especially if it's going to be a vertical pull, that's about the tempo that I want to use. That's that there is what I would call training to failure. So I actually went to failure, wasn't one rep shot. Back work like this, I like to use slower tempo, train to failure, concentrate more than muscles instead of the movement to where I'm just pulling and trying to move weight. None of these products we have for sale yet, we're still kind of playing around with them a little bit, playing with the price points a little bit. But the key thing is with the movement, like this in my own training, for the purposes that I said, I was going to post these videos in my log. This is to show the tempo and it's showing that when I am trying to do with a lot of these movements is to try to bend the bar and try to do whatever I can do to get the greatest contraction and over the period of the set, try to extend the range of motion as much as I possibly can and get the emphasis off of the biceps to try to pull with the other of those bands.

And again, we have, we had a four-step system that we're not going to have time to go over today, but really when you're talking about, you look at everything from, you know, before the set, between the reps and so on, as far as what you should be doing, how you should be coaching, where you should be standing when you're coaching, and now you can address that when you're doing those exercise clinics. So, that's, that's important. So again, you have phase three, and that's basically generating the questions. === FILE: elitefts.com - Bob Youngs & Marshall ＂Freakshow＂ Johnson Talk Chains and Bands [2WJUN10etVM].txt ===

As I said, I got the West Side in 1995 and we started to really look in the chains first and that was 96, 97 and then bands came in maybe 97, 98. It was all about the same time but we were really trying to figure out how to use them in training and it was, you know, these were brand new. There were no training manuals out on how to use any of this stuff. So it really was really trial and error. Throw it on the bar and see what happened, throw combinations on the bar and see what happened. And so our science became us as guinea pigs and I think we figured some things out but I think, you know, I watched these guys today train and they really have how they're going to utilize the bands, you know, as a solid part of their program. They have it planned out. They're not, you know, bluntly yanking a couple of colored bands on something going, let's see how this feels and works. When I first started using chains, chains actually kept me in powerlifting. There was actually a point where I hit so many plethora's and I could not get the weight to move, I could not make gains and I went trained with the buddy and he was using chains on deadlift and just from that moment I was hooked because it took the number's game completely out of it for me. Instead of focusing on, you know, why can't I deadlift 500 pounds today? I should be able to deadlift 500 pounds today as opposed to, well, throw some bar weight on, throw some chain and you'll just work up to your, your heaviest triple. You won't worry about the weight, you'll worry about the work. And that's how, that's how chains and bands came to be with myself. I never, ever looked at it as accommodating resistance and ever looked at it as, you know, it's, it's going to give you a maximum load of the top but it's going to save your joints in the hole, you know, it's, it's going to help with your speed. To me, it was just a way to ignore the numbers and just work hard. So that's, that's how it changed in bands that played into my training. And it, it's helped me greatly with speed as well. I do a lot of explosive stuff with bands and different angles of the lifts, whether it be deficits or or a different widths on my grip on bench. It, it's helped me out probably more mentally than anything.

=== FILE: elitefts.com - Buddy Morris Parenting Advice [AWzeXBSluZc].txt ===

You've got already people here with problems. What is technology done? I could solve all the functional movement screen problems in this country right now. No, what is? Get rid of the computer, get rid of video games, let kids go outside and play again. Let the body solve complex motor problems in a chaotic environment, let the brain figure things out. The brain learns by getting things wrong. How many of you have to hear our new parents? New parents? Stop helping your kids. If a kid's in a bad scene and he can't clip the fucking seat belt, don't turn on, say, here, a lemon in the body help you. Let him figure it out. That's all the way. The fucking seat belt? Don't turn on, say, here, a lemon in the body help you. Let him figure it out.

=== FILE: elitefts.com - Chris ＂The Tank＂ Janek talks elitefts and Football Career [apUDjDFpN3M].txt ===

Everybody, Steve Colzcat here for Elite FTS. We are with Chris Jennings. First time meeting them today, he came out for the XPC Finals, which today is March 8. He lifted on March 7th, 2015. Didn't have the day you wanted. Before we get into that, let's step back, introduce people to you. You come from a football background. What came first, the lifting of the football? I started lifting heavy when I was probably 12. My dad just dropped me off with a gym. I just was surrounded by old school meatheads. So I'd lift the bench press to the dead of the squat.
