=== FILE: elitefts.com - How Ken and Sherri Whetham Changed Competitive Kettlebell Sport [ZYwSuaGUMC8].txt ===

We've been involved in the kettlebell sport probably since about 2007. It was something that we kind of get interested in just as a fitness aspect to start off with. And as we got more into it and started to train with them a little bit, we all get certified actually as a coach in the beginning and was exposed to the kettlebell sport. A lot of people don't really know what it is. It's a brutal sport. It's a 10 minute sets of the competition lifts are basically you can do long cycle, which is a clean and jerk style lift. Usually for the pro men you use 232 kg kettlebells and you do a 10 minute set of clean and jerks without button the bells down. It's probably the best tools that you can use as far as I'm concerned for for increasing your work capacity and conditioning and shedding some body fat. I guess the by-athlon you do two sets, two ten minutes sets. One is just with the top half of the clean and jerk, which is just the jerk and then you do a 10 minute set of snatches. You can only do one hand change in 10 minutes. So there's a lot of technique involved and you know to be able to last that long 10 minutes. It's an incredible amount of technique that you have to learn in order to be able to survive and it's basically survival. In my opinion if you incorporate some kind of strength training or like power lifting for example and you want to add kettlebells in for your conditioning and increasing your work capacity I don't think there's a better combination that you could you could ever use. So we both competed. We both done really well. We've competed all over the place Chicago, New York, Columbus at the Arnold's for a couple of years. Michigan, Niagara Falls all over so. It's quite a learning experience. I mean, well he was saying last night too that when I was training with kettlebells I waited when I went for my physical of the fire department at 202. So I'm about 275 and change right now. So it really does shred you up pretty good. I'll let you go for a little bit. Thanks. kettlebells are not only just good for the competition but they're good for rehabilitation as well. When Ken first started with the kettlebells I was actually injured. I had just over gone major back surgery. I had rods and bolts and started to my back. So after I had to go ahead from the doctor to start weight training again I started with kettlebells. Very quickly I became stronger resilient and using the sport kettlebell and the sport moves. I was quickly able to within six months I tried my first competition with kettlebells. That was with still my back still being in rehabilitation mode. So they're great too. They're great for your joints. They're great for your ligaments. I teach people kettlebells and if you've got a frozen shoulder kettlebells will help. There's a difference between fitness kettlebells as well as the competition kettlebells. I was approached a couple years ago if I wanted to teach kettlebells at the gym in a fitness environment. I was a bit hesitant because Ken and I like to go bigger stay home. We have that kind of mentality. So as far as a fitness kettlebell goes the difficulty is as people you're able to use the kettlebells without as much technique involved. So you're able to lift a lighter weight but not proper technique. So I was kind of hesitant at first but then I thought, you know I'm going to give this a shot and see what I can do with it. So I ran with the fitness classes but I still teach the kettlebell sport moves. I encourage my people to use a heavier kettlebell. I still teach the proper technique but with the fitness belts still allowing people to learn properly but not as strong people in the fitness environment is obviously as a sport. What the most grueling part of this kettlebell sport is this 10 minutes. You watch a power lifting lift watch somebody lift you know deadlift is 15 seconds. You watch so many compete for 10 minutes. It's long it's boring I'm not going to lie. So Ken and I decided that we need to change up the sport so we opened our own club called North American O'L'Cettable Club and we decided to run an event and our event was a five minute set. So we decided to let people try and lift a heavier weight but only go for half the time. That actually was very successful and we actually grew the sport and now some of the bigger federations are running a five minute event. So we were the first team first coupled to actually bring that five minute set into the kettlebell sport. So pretty proud of that. I teach Ken about probably six times a week. I have a team. We support compete. We coach, we've got a workshop. Ken and I do a lot of workshops for charity. Cancer this week we're doing a kettlebell workshop for benches for benefits. We're doing that for the youth, now some youth group. That's all everything we get donated to the youth and yeah it's a two hour workshop. So we just love to live and pass on. That's what I like what we do.

Instead, have those peripheral coaches, film the athletes, and give them some feedback. You'd be surprised, they could probably vote themselves, and they'll know right when you even need a coach. You'll know exactly what they did wrong. Your job as a coach is to make sure they know why they did it wrong and how it fits, there's a difference in that. So really, make sure you're in the fashion of how far they're going, those steps, filming those, and really, instead of a stopwatch, maybe get to a point where they can start to be in a position where they can race. I think that's the best thing we did as athletes get a competitive and have them race. Instead of measuring with the stopwatch, which you'd be, now you have an end-rider reliability issues, if you use the electronic time, or if you have some different different issues with that, again, if you have them race and times, now you can really, now you know who your fastest kids are. So we talk about that in a video that we did a webinar, we did about five ways to do more work and less time. So those are things to think about with the sprint, hopefully those will help you to get your athletes in better position, to gain speed and to really have that speed and translate on to the field.

=== FILE: elitefts.com - Metabolic Conditioning with the Double Kettlebell Snatch [dRi22J2dx1k].txt ===

So, we're going to demonstrate the double snatch now. It's not a competition move, but I use this all the time in my classes. For conditioning, metabolic conditioning, this is the best exercise. Now, what you've got to remember though about the snatch is, so this kettlebell here is 44 pounds at the top, 20 kgs. When you bring that kettlebell down, if you're not accepting that weight properly, your torque all of a sudden could be about 70 pounds torque. So, you're going to pair your shoulder. The most shoulder injuries I see are from CrossFit snatches because they're not accepting that weight down. They're just dropping that kettlebell straight down. So, you're going to torque your shoulder. So, you're going to bring that belt down. You're going to accept that weight. You're going to lead your elbow to your chest and accept that weight here and pop it back up. Now, it's especially hard for shorter, especially shorter women like me to get double kettlebell straight. You do everything. Double kettlebell snatch. This is a great tool. These will fry you really quick. So same thing, he gets them Bell straight when he's still going to use his hips. Squeeze his glutes. Breathing at the top. Out. And then in. Awesome. So, what you also want to remember about the snatches and my biggest fear is when I teach kettlebells, the snatches, the most technical move to teach, people want to take that kettlebell and they want to bring it out like this. Okay? No. Okay? Just no. Just don't do it. Fitness kettlebells because you got this fitness kettlebell here. I can muscle this bell up here and I can bring it out here. That's the disadvantage of fitness kettlebell. See? People think that's a snatch. That's not a snatch. You have to be able to, that weight has to be heavy enough that you need to use the proper techniques. You need to have to accept that weight here. You cannot bring that kettlebell out here. It has to come in and down and then back straight up that tube. Okay? We like to use this scenario. Either zip it up a hoodie, railroad track up your stomach. You want to bring that kettlebell up, not out because you're going to also shoulder torque or a tube up your stomach. So down the tube and back up the tube. I like to think of it at the top when you're sending your snatch. You want to snap your fingers at the top. That's one way I teach it. Snap your fingers, lends your elbow in and then turn your thumb in. Okay? When Ken does his snatch, he does not turn his thumb in. He just brings his down and goes in like this. Extremovate. I like to bring my thumbs in. So everybody's different. Just like everybody's different on their left or their bench. But this, he's still out of breath. Look at that. That was great conditioning. So you want to burn some fat. Get your heart rate. Get your conditioning up there. kettlebells.

=== FILE: elitefts.com - More Work in Less Time [OsRlsoiv8-o].txt ===

We're going to talk about more work in less time. And as a strength and conditioning coach, how you can get your athletes to improve that training session density. And there's two advantages of this. Number one, obviously, you're in a situation where you don't have enough equipment, enough space, enough time slots, the fit, all of your athletes. And you have too many athletes to train in the amount of space that you have. That's pretty common among strength coaches at the college and the high school levels. Even, there are some situations where you have some of the larger universities where they don't have that issue. But by and large, this is something that strength coaches are going to have to tackle this issue. Secondly, it gets our athletes in a situation where they're getting more work done, they're more engaged with the workout. The one thing that you have to try to avoid at all costs is downtime. And those periods where the athletes don't have anything to do. Number one, when sport coaches at sports coaches relate different things to success. For us, as strength coaches, we feel that if an athlete has adequate time to rest in between maximal sets or dynamic effort sets or a lifting technique, that's one thing that we know that is important. But for some sport coaches, a lot of times they associate that with not working very hard. Whether they're right or wrong, it's in a situation you're in. So can we get the most out of our workouts by getting those athletes more engaged in what they're doing? So hopefully today, I can give you a couple of pointers to help you out with this. So we're going to talk about basically five different things that will enable you as a strength and conditioning coach to get your athletes actively engaged in a better process within your training session. So the five things we're going to talk about is number one, dumbbell, kettlebell, set up, again, these are things that I've used in the past. If you have a better idea, obviously this is what these are for to encourage some dialogue with that. But this is something that really helped most of these that we came up with was either because of someone else's idea that we stole or because we messed it up to the point where we said, listen, we got to make a change. And that really has, was the birth of a lot of these ideas that hopefully can help you in your situation. Back assignments in rotations, that's something that I've talked about in the past. And again, three things with speed of competitive speed groups for linear speed. And then two, agility training modifications that we made in the past as well. So hopefully those will help you. So let's go through with the kettlebell and dumbbell set up. Now here's the issue. Here's the problem. Most weight reserves are set up. And since that the dumbbells or kettlebells are all in one section. So we have racks spread out all across the weight room where we have individual individuals and small groups assigned to each one of these racks. But when it comes down to dumbbell time, they all have to go into same area. Now I've been able to see a couple large weight rooms where their dumbbell area was big enough they could fit a whole team. Or they've been in a situation where all the dumbbells have racks on each side of the rooms and the dumbbells are down the middle. Very good set up that way. Or you even have it in a situation where you have small dumbbell racks associated with each platform. But for most situations, that's not the case. So one thing that we felt that was important for us was to get our dumbbells in a space that was more easily used. I think there's so many times where we have an athlete. Again, if you have two full sets of dumbbells, that's still going to give you two sets of each and maybe four of the same dumbbell at once. So one thing that we would be frustrated with was any time we hit athletes deal, who has a 25? Do you have a 20? Who has a 20? And they're just searching for these dumbbells. They never could put back and then you have a big log jam trying to get the dumbbells out of the rack. So what we do is we set the dumbbells anywhere about 10 feet apart, maybe a little less, and just set them in a line. So again, from lowest weight from 25s all the way up until whatever it was, again, depending on the team, depending on the athlete, depending on the exercise. So we have those set up in a linear fashion, and then basically had the athletes would have their weights on their workout sheets. So they would know exactly what weight they needed for each subsequent set. So if I have to start off with a 25, I would get a line behind the 25 pound dumbbell, or the 36 pound kettlebell, whatever it may be. So they would be in a situation where they could just line up behind executor movement. Now one thing we did that helped is that every single exercise we did with dumbbells will one arm. And the reason we did that was not just because, of course, you get some kind of, it's a unilateral movement, so you get some kind of stabilization. Obviously, the left hip is really associated with the right shoulder, but another thing was, not just the training benefits, but also the safety benefits. So if I'm doing something over here, if I'm doing a dumbbell snatch, I have that other hand there, and I can rotate myself out of arms way as opposed to let you're taking the time to get the athletes to learn how to drop out of a snatch, for example. So it helped with safety, but really the number one thing is that we were able to get more worked on a less time. And this is the now-jagos. If we have four athletes and they have a set of 50 pound dumbbells. Well, if I'm doing an exercise with the 50s, I have athlete A going, athlete B, F, E, C, F, E, D. So that's a one to three ratio from worth work to rest. Now if I could go ahead and give two of the athletes to 50, and the other two athletes to 50, now I have more of a one to one ratio. And even if I'm doing some explosive movements, really that, you know, if they were going to get a bigger weight, they would be able to do that. So I think that's a big thing that a matter of pace that still was manageable. And now it didn't save on time because they had to do obviously double the set because they're doing one arm at a time. But what it did was to keep the athletes more engaged. There was less downtime in between. So we ended up doing one dumbbell at a time. So we had our basically sometimes we'd have an entire workout with just the dumbbells, sometimes it would just be part of it. But we try to set up in that linear fashion, whether it be ketobos or dumbbells. So you know, obviously we would just put them out of your eye side to the weight room or the long along the track, whatever it may be, just to give us a more space. And maybe that can be applicable for your situation. The next thing that we talked about was again, some of these strategies would be, and this is for any time we're doing a training session where we're in the racks or platforms. So these strategies would be doing things in between sets. The way we'd set it up was either we would do mobility or pre-having between sets. Maybe flexibility, ankle mobility in between, you know, Olympic sets, something along that lines. Also doing some complex training, doing some of our explosive movements after a heavy movement. One of the things that was frustrating a lot of times, any time you have a medicine ball drill or a plial boxes. Again, you're limited on how many plial boxes you might be able to have in your facility, not just because of the cost, but also because of storage. So we would want to set up plial boxes, whether they're whatever random sizes, along with those racks so that athletes can engage in some kind of a movement after their actual heavy set. And another thing was just to match up and antagonist movement with whatever means that we have. So again, those are just some ideas and I'll go a little more specifics with those. So the rack assignments, and this is one thing that really helped us, and I talked about this previously, is just having making sure that you know again, how many athletes you have, how many racks you have, and how to incorporate those small groups within those racks. We've spent a little bit more time at the beginning of the session, too. Match up those athletes, sometimes by height, if you're doing, you know, whether it's a squat and overhead or a bench press, sometimes that would alleviate some issues, because again, you wouldn't have to really adjust those j-hooks. The other thing would be just to make sure that you have all those workout sheets that you have, they're training cards, and really put groups that were similar weight all together. So again, the disadvantage is you got all your strongest guys, all in one group, and maybe you want to have some of your stronger guys to bring up some of those guys that are a little bit behind, you know, depending on their strength levels. But from a logistic standpoint, it really helped the workout go much, much, much faster, because there's less changing weights. So any time that we would have per rack, I would much rather do athletes, all the athletes on one rack. I'd rather have, you know, seven-eight-aftly, it's on a rack and incorporate complexes than to split up that team. Because again, if you have an exercise in a specific order, you want the athletes to fall that order. So this is just a guideline that we use. Some of this we got off of Evan Simon at Oregon State. And really, if we had four athletes, excuse me, if we had four athletes again, we would have a spot, and again, we'll use the squad as an example, but it'd be basically you're either spotting, squatting, loading, and then you would, you know, again, you have two loaders, and you really wouldn't have any kind of prehab or extra exercise in there. If we had a five-aftly to be incorporate some kind of a plyometric ballistic type movement, some kind of, you know, again, a lot of talk about post activation, potential, type training. Secondly, again, we would also incorporate, if we had six athletes incorporated prehab, incorporated antagonists and so on and so forth, so they have a pattern. So here's how it looks, what it looks like. If we'd have a rack of somershons, and we'd just go from basically, if you're looking at athlete A through F, for this example, really what happens is, again, the order you would fall would be again, you would be in the rack, and then you would, you would spot, once you would spot, you would be the next one in line. So really what happens is, our loaders are below those, those that rack the bar, they would like a NASCAR pick crew. There's a terminology I like to compare it with, and really, you know, they're just all they're doing is waiting for the next lifter to say, I need this on the bar, and they would take care of it. So that lifter got his hands on the bar, or he's on the bench, he's waiting, the bar's loaded, and they're ready to go. Okay. And then they would rotate from there. So again, what happens is, for an example, and this will be more clear once we go to the next slide. So again, once that athlete A with squat, as soon as he's done squat, he would do some box jumps. Right? Athlete B will be now on the rack. Now these spotters and loaders, you can rotate sides if you want to, or keep on the same side. That's not, that kids will figure it out as soon as they go through once. But just knowing that I know who I follow. So I know that I follow this athlete, so I have to spot him. And that'll keep everything as soon as I'm done spotting, I'm getting in the rack. And I go from whatever it may be. I go from lifting to some kind of a speed or explosive movement to some kind of maybe a pre-hab or flexibility or some kind of antagonistic movement. So people I got this from Toby, Jacobi would want to do, for example, Bantiquees in between Benzzets, just to get that added or, and some athletes want to maybe say, no, I'm going to do some face pulls to activate the antagonist muscles for that particular exercise. That's up to you. That's up to your training philosophy. So that's one way to think about that. Moving on to speed training. Really, it's one of those. You have non-track athletes. So you really have a limit amount of time and how much you're going to be able to run with them. So I'll give you three different drills that will do the first. We're going to be a linear speed. And again, the way we'd set this up and again, hearing this, a lot of people, about 10% would be really on the mechanics. And that's a topic for a different lecture. And really, the number one thing we did, if we did a resisted starts, we would make sure they were in a short distance, make sure that the weight was applicable. So it didn't inhibit the actual, you know, the mechanics of the sprint. And we would follow it up with some kind of sprint that was unweighted. So we would do it, have that contrast involved. And that was probably about 10%. So really, the most effective thing that we've done was to get athletes in a competitive speedgrip. === FILE: elitefts.com - POWERBUILDING with Justin Harris [Ej836kHJeuk].txt ===

My training over the years, when it's evolved, is when I first started training it was for football or to get bigger and for football in high school. And really that's how I trained until I played two college. So until I was 22, that's all my focus was, which was for so many more. I do things like Hank Leane's, Cleane's, Jurks, Power Shrugs, and I would a lot of agility, type things or explosive, sprint type work, mixed in with the workout, real core training, squats, dead lifts, you know, always did, you know, curls for the girls and stuff. But really it was just, it was sports oriented training. And then after football, it really transitioned to, I decided I wanted to do bodybuild. And the only problem was I never, I mean at that point I've been training for eight years. I know I wanted to be a bodybuilder, but the only way I knew what a train was to train heavy, try to get stronger every workout and train like kind of a mix between powerlifting and strong man. And so I really struggled with trying to train like a bodybuilder because I couldn't do, I just couldn't do like pump workouts and cable stuff. And so I still always trained heavy. But I'd started splitting my body into bodybuild, you know, like a leg day, a chest day, a back day, instead of like a push pull type thing. And so it's, it's struggle. And I mean even when I still just always kind of train like a powerlifting, eventually I think I wrote a couple articles and they titled the name Power Bodybuilding or Power Building or something. I guess that's, I still have always trained that way. I mean I did my first powerlifting meet, I didn't do any, I trained the exact same way all the way up to the day of the meet as I trained for a bodybuilding show. And I guess kind of the way my training is now if I had described the power bodybuilding as I pretty much go in in my first movement for any of the major group back or chest or legs is I'm a powerlifting. I go in, I leg day and I squat and I warm up slowly like a powerlifting does and I build up 1-35, 2-25, 3-15, 4-5 and eventually leads out to my max effort whatever it is. It might be more or less one set when I might try to get 585 or 6. And that's, you know, that whole workout is I'm a powerlifting trying to get stronger. And after that, I think I kind of transitioned to kind of switch gears. Well maybe for something like legs that would do something like stiff leg dead lifts or good mornings also, which I'm still kind of in the mindset of a powerlifting. But after those core movements, then I kind of switch gears and I'm not worried about the weight as much in a trained bodybuilder. And I kind of, I guess I'll use chest as an example, I kind of finish with like at the end kind of a combination muscle group exercise. So for example, for chest I come in and I do bench and I warm up my shoulders and do all the stuff just like a foam roller or whatever like I would be a powerlifting like it's my bench day. Now instead of spending all day in bench and maybe doing 20 sets of really low reps over the course of two hours, I move through a quicker. But I'll do 135, 225, 235, 315 and then maybe when I'm stronger, 4-5 for one set of, I'm going to be 45 with bands for a set of six with red bands and then that's it for bench. But I trained that whole point was I was a powerlifting and then from there I'll go and I maybe do incline barbell for, and then I'm three to four sets of 10 to 12 and then maybe flat dumbbell three sets of 12 reps and then maybe cable cross overs and I kind of do a couple more power movements, you know, compound movements like incline bench flat dumbbell and then I'll do kind of a pump movement where I do the cable cross over nine, I might do three or four sets, I don't even really count on sometimes I might do five sets and those reps are like 10, 12, 15 even all the way up to 20 reps and the whole point is what all the bodybuilders always talk about like blood volume and then at the end I'll finish for something like dips almost always and I think dips, you know, when I'm when I'm thinking dips is I'm hitting chest hit a little bit shoulders and getting blood in the triceps also and that's kind of my finishing thing and then really there's never intended to be that way but that's just how kind of how my workouts go so you know I'm back it would be I come in I'm doing dead lifts and I'm basically a power lift I'm having a goal I'm on hit a PI I want to hit it whatever my === FILE: elitefts.com - Preparatory Exercises for Throwing the Shot-Put [onhDDtt7WYw].txt ===

Okay, what we're going to go through is a series of preparatory exercises for throwing the shop foot for a beginner. So the first exercise that we're going to do is it is a two-handed between the legs backwards, overhead, shop foot, throw. What they're all doing, we'll take the shop foot both hands, use kind of a used kind of kettlebell, swinging motion, dropping the hips, and then throwing the shop foot, exploding it up backwards over her head. What this exercise, what this exercise will do, it'll get the handle used to being explosive from the hips and in a long and long range of motion. So the next exercise that we're going to do is similar to the underhand backwards dough, is the underhand forward throw. The stance will be the same except the throw will be facing the direction of the throw. Once again, just a shop foot, both hands, squat down, bring the shop up between the legs, and then using an explosive jumping motion, we'll swing the ball and throw the ball away from her forwards. That direction. One thing to remember is that when doing these exercises, is that how the distance is you can throw overhead backwards, be as close as as far as you can throw, overhand forwards. Now the next exercise we're going to do is we're going to do a square stance standing shop foot throw, without using the legs. So the throw will take the shop foot, place the hand, about where the pads are, place the shop foot onto her neck. From here, you're going to raise your left arm and the direction that she wants to throw, and then she will show fire from the shoulder exploding through the wrist and then flicking the ball out at the end. This takes the legs out of the motion, so you really get to work as to get to really focus on the release of the throw. Now the next exercise, the progression from the square stance is a staggered stance, shop foot throw. So from this position the shop foot will take the power foot, which is opposite the throwing hand, put that front of the body step back with the leg of the same hand, use the throw. Once again, placing the shop foot onto the neck, we will drive from the hip forward, keep from the left arm up, and then driving the shop foot out of the direction of the throw. This step in the progression adds a little bit more lower body action to the throw, and you should notice that once you use a staggered stance, you're able to deliver the shop foot one lot more explosive fashion, where your shop will also go a lot farther. Now the last step up for the gaze in this progression is a regular standing throw. Now a position of the throw will be more of a sideways stance with a feet being staggered, so the power foot, which is the front that's behind the shop foot. If you're right handed to be a right leg, we'll be facing it approximately 90 degrees of the left foot. The toes are left foot will be even with the end step of your right foot, so that when you actually turn your hips in the direction of the throw, your feet should be at a position where you can take a step forward and walk in a straight line. Now for here you'll take the shop foot and place it up on your neck. You'll put your weight on your right leg, twist it to your right. So you twist it to the right. Do you want to drop your shoulders? So the kind of like you're picking up something heavy from the ground. From this position you're going to drive your hips forward and the direction of the throw, and then you'll drive your shoulder elbow and foot into the ball finally with the wrist. Keep in mind the athletes pull of water, not a shop foot or the first time to do this. Well coach, cool question, what weight are you using the same weight as they would normally throw with? Do you change the weight? For a female athletes, most female athletes are strong enough to be able to use a 4K shop foot, which is what the women throw in international competition. If you're working with high school, high school boys, you can use a 12 pound shot, and if you're working with athletes more in college, you may not be throwers. If they're not multi-benters, you can use it. You can use a 12 pound shot for teaching for them because it's a little bit heavier, but if they're going to be multi-benters, then you want to get them used to using the heavier, the 16 pound shot, because this is the International League. Okay, so it shouldn't be any different than what they would normally use in college. That's correct. Okay, good, thank you.

So that's one thing. So when we take that out, we want to explain to them that they understand so that movement pattern stays great, but now it is a little bit of different of a pattern. So one of the big things with the front squat, I think, is that people, again, you know, one of my biggest concerns and butty biggest issues with with young athletes, no posterior chain. So what we want to do, we put them in that front squat position, they have to keep their chest up. They have to keep their chest up. So Nick, when we see kids front squats, what are a couple of issues that you see that we have to fix? Coalition that we usually see with the front squat, it is getting them in a position of comfort too. The Canadian comfort one of the bar, they don't, there's two ways to do it. So, really they do the hands cross position or we have to be teaching a good rack position. We don't like to fight on with it because they're not Olympic lifters. So if they don't are in a comfortable and a rack position, we'll put them in an arms cross position. And then another thing is just getting that weight in a good position up here because when they, if they have the bar sit too low, that one they go down in the bars and a poem forward. Biggest thing is keeping the cues consistent from the wall all the way through and just having the kids just chest up and he's out, hips back, gets a dab and then come up. One thing we did, I know that for, especially for beginning athletes that never squad before, we had to use it at PVC by her hands free just because a lot of times when they had their elbows bent they didn't. So we'd have them the same thing with her hands up like they're driving a car, with their steering wheel. Now that was a visual cue because if they did come down, if their chest came forward, their arms come forward, it's really now they can keep that and wherever that PVC pipe would roll, they would actually keep that up. And so I know that we use that too as in. So when you're talking about like, and this is just, obviously we all have our different things, but like I don't like that drill. So one of the reasons I don't like that drill is because I can put, if I'm already to the point in the progression where I'm doing a friend's spot, I can put for a 12 year old exact, I can put a 25 pound bar in his front, or 45 pound. Now we can get some sets of 10 with some decent volume. So now you just practice. That's almost a regression back. That might be somewhere that goes to the wall. Exactly. That would be something you know, you could start with a seven year old, but again, anything where I can moderately load and get a training effect in the same type of drill where I would use PVC. I think that's one of my big issues today in today's world. Everybody's so worried about these progressions and we're glad you hear it all the time. At a certain point, you just got to lift weights. And a lot of these kids, there's a lot of issues. Strength fixes a ton of things, especially for younger athletes. If you're talking about you know, 17, 18 year olds and younger. Now if we're talking about you know, 30 year old NFL players, we're talking that's different. But for younger athletes, strength fixes a lot. We a lot of people that do a lot of technique work with a PVC pipe and it's almost like that, you know, how you can throw a whiffable ball farther than a baseball. And it's one of those things that it's almost inhibits technique because of just not enough load to do it. So. And that's the thing is it's we talk about fire fire mechanics. So, you know, if I'm going to swing a golf club and I'm going to wait the end of it with 10 pounds. Now it just shows up my whole firing pattern. So the same thing here, I need you know, my young athletes to put that 25 pounds on their shoulders and feel what it's like to keep their or chest up to keep everything tight. And a PVC, they don't have to keep everything tight, because especially a young athlete with great lack, you know, flexibility, great shoulder mobility, they can go like this and bend over like this and still keep it up. With a 25 pound bar, now all of a sudden we got a little more skin in the game. They're getting a decent amount of volume out of that. === FILE: elitefts.com - Swiss Press Bar (Five Grip Drop Set) [zoyhXiccjCc].txt ===

Mark Walsh truck, Kimmelano, EADFDS.com. We're going to talk about today a couple of mechanical drop sets for the bench press. So we talked about the 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 board press. And now we're going to talk about using the Swiss press bar as a way to use different grips and really increase the advantage throughout the set as fatigue sets in. With the group of athletes, the benefits of this is obviously there's not going to be a lot of change you can weight in between sets because of the difficulty is decreased as the set goes on. And also a lot of the athletes, if you're doing these for high-purchary work, you can get a lot of work sets in a minimal amount of time. So the way we'll do this is you can either have the athletes do a set where they have a rep cap so again every grip they're going to do a certain amount of rep. For today, Chuss is going to do, we don't have a lot of weight on just for demonstration purposes and we're just going to use three reps at a time. Normally you might want to use whatever it might be up to 10. The one thing I would avoid is that if you're going all out on every single set with the rest intervals, even if you have it up to 10, 20, 30 seconds, what happens is you get probably a lot of double-digit reps on the first set, 14 reps on the first set and maybe 3 than 2 than 2 a lot of times, even if you have some higher athletes with higher work capacity. So one thing to do is just maybe cap those reps and you can always work your way back down or out another set. So the first grip we're going to do is we're going to do the inside grip as a reverse grip. This will be the most difficult of all and then what's going to happen is again the athletes are going to go ahead and just press. And with this again, obviously we're working our way from the inside all the way to the outside. If you have some of those that are going to be a little bit athletes that have maybe you want to skip somebody's grips depending on who you're working with. So now the athletes are going to turn the Swiss power around again. So from here now the athlete has the same grip but now obviously it hits his hands are going to be in a different position. They're not going to be super ready they're going to be pronated. So he's going to go ahead and do the next set. So again it's going to be basically a closed grip and again that inside grip can kind of alleviate some pressure on the wrist. So now it will rack it up. And then from there now we'll work our way out like I said before if you have certain grips you want to move. You want to skip a whatnot or if you want to stop you can. So again now we're going to go to the neutral grip. This is a grip if we have an athlete that's working any kind of max effort type work or a certain max effort type work that first neutral grip with the thicker handles that's the one we prefer to use some of our max effort work. So again it's the most advantageous position of my opinion to bruise enough force. So again now the athlete is working his way out. So again these rest might be anywhere between 5 to 10. The rest of it will maybe 5 seconds, 10 seconds, whatnot but as you can see obviously as the grip gets wider the mechanical advantage increases and then the athlete can get more work without after get off the bench at all. So you get a lot of athletes get that work done in middle amount of time and high intensity set and they get them out. So again so those are the grips if we want to do that last could be can you go work your way back in. It's just basically up to you. So you have a little bit of variety using that Swiss press bar for a mechanical drop set really good for high purge for work and in group setting and a team setting.

What do you think that exercise is going to do for my triceps at 680 just didn't? You know, and so that kind of ties in a little bit to, you know... So when I'm asked that question, you know, it's kind of like asking me what would I change if I could go back during those times based upon what I've learned right now and do differently and you would think that it's a lot, you really would, you know, and that I've learned a lot and I have learned a lot but what I've learned is it's different. It's, you know, what I've learned isn't all powerlifting focus to get ready for that next meet, you know, what I've learned's been more, you know, health conditioning, you know, weight loss, fat loss, muscle building, high-perchemy, you know, a lot of the things that weren't that important to me at the time when it was all 100% strength-based. So I can sit here and say that, you know, I may have done the accessory work different and to be able to understand the answer, you need to be able to understand how we were trained in the time and the eight keys article which is on elitefts.com explains that pretty thoroughly but essentially we did our, you know, our core exercise which was a max effort or dynamic effort exercise first, then after that we did what I call a supplemental exercise which was the main exercise to build that core exercise and then everything that followed after that were accessories. So if I was to change anything it would be how we trained our accessories because everything else cycled, everything else had waves on how it would cycle, you know, a max effort wave would be one to three weeks, the dynamic wave could be anywhere between three to five weeks, the supplemental movements may change, um, every one to three, sometimes four weeks, you know, it, it, it pen it upon what the movement was and how, how long you could keep breaking records before you were doing. And the accessory exercises really didn't change how a lot. I mean it was just kind of the ship, we threw at the end, you know, shoulder raises and band push downs and it's just, ship, we felt that we had to do but there really wasn't a whole lot of thought, you know, kind of put into it, you just did whatever the else did or whatever you thought you needed to do because for the, for the most part the training's done, you know, you're just trying to train the stableizers and, you know, train other body parts to, to help them get in injured. But an example would be dumbbell rows that we'd throw at the end of the training, you know, not as the second movement, but just dumbbell rows essentially just to work your lats. You know, looking back, you know, doing 150 pound dumbbells for 15 reps or whatever the hell I would do just slam in the shit up and down, it wasn't working the lats anywhere in here as effectively as what I could work the lats now, if I was using, you know, a 70 pound dumbbell and really focusing on trying to get the muscle to stretch and get any good contraction. Theoretically, when I look back, I think to myself, the lighter dumbbell would actually develop more muscle would have increased the range of motion a little bit more, which I think was lacking with us some, I would ease with me because powerlifting essentially is a short range of motion sport, with everything that you're doing, you're trying to shorten the stroke on squat bench to that lift, you know, across the board. So it would have opened some joints up that I think, you know, weren't being worked through the full range at the time, and I wouldn't have lost anything strength wise because we weren't really doing them for strength in the first place. But, and this is where there's that big pause at the beginning, what I did worked, you know, it worked for me and it worked really well for me, and it worked for everybody else who was in the gym. So who am I to say that if we would have changed the way that we did accessories, it was going to work better, you know, you don't know. So I don't know. The on the other end, now you're dealing with how do you know if you're in the competitive side, how do you know what the optimal weight is going to be? Pretty fucking simple. Whatever weight class you're in, look around the best lifters in that weight class. If you're like seven inches taller than they are, you probably need to gain weight. You know, you're not going to be the outlier. I think guarantee that. Even the outliers didn't know they were the outliers until they became the outliers. So as I've always said before, you know, power lifting and bodybuilding and all this, yes, they are very heavily genetically weighted sports. But how do you know if you have good genetics or not, if you never fucking try? And never really try hard. How do you know? You know, because a lot of the guys that I've seen that have great genetics, I've seen there before pictures. You know, yeah, they had great genetics, but they had to do some work before those genetics really started to kick in. So a lot of people quit too soon. So go based upon the height and what everybody else looks like this in your weight class and base it on that. Should you try to get up there as fast as you can? I don't think so. You know, I think that you need to actually, you need to keep a calorie surplus to be able to gain weight. You know, you need to be making a conscious effort to keep trying to move up. The dumbest thing you can do is to die it down. You know, to try to make weight. If you're under an elite total, you know, to me it just makes no sense to me whatsoever. On why anybody would want to cut weight, you know, to for any reason, you know, unless they're going to break a world record or they're competing for a title that actually matters. It just, I don't know, boom, home I had, don't comprehend it. But keep moving up, you know, that's the, that what I was always told was, you know, keep gaining weight until you can't get stronger anymore. Because the fastest way to get stronger is the gain weight. So keep gaining weight until you can't get stronger anymore and you get stuck. Then when that happens, drop a weight class. Well, with all the, as I was training with, we all ended up over 300 pounds. So it didn't matter if they were 5-4, they were, you know, 6-4. They're all ended up over 300 pounds. So gain slow. So one of the things that you'll notice is that it's different is that these kettlebells here are competition kettlebells. You'll notice that they're all the same size, all the bell diameter is the same. It's all the same handle size, 35 millimeter handles on them. So when you're doing the sport, as you progress up and weight and you're progression with your lifting, you can go up to a different size bell. So these kettlebells are like 12 kgs for the blue ones, 16 kgs, 20 kgs, 24 kgs, up to 53 pounds. So we have them in home up to sets up to 40 kgs, 88 pounds, and we have some heavier ones in that as well too. So you'll notice that when you start to get into utilizing proper technique, that instead of changing bell diameter size and handle size and everything that your hand fits in the same way in every handle and your bell diameter is the same so you can continue with the same technique. One of the things that you want to do when you're lifting a kettlebell is a lot of people want to just grab it in the middle like a dumbbell. But you'll notice that if you pick the kettlebell up it will slide back and it puts a lot of pressure on your wrist if you go up into an overhead pressing movement. So what you're trying to do, what the optimum thing to do when you land the kettlebell is you put it up into the horseshoe of your hand and you press the kettlebell against your forearm. So your long bone takes a pressure instead of putting it all in your wrist. So when you put it up over hand, you're actually your hand is relaxed and all the weight is on the long bone and you're trying to keep all the weight on your skeletal system versus your muscular system. Because once you start to use your muscular system it starts to break down and you start to fatigue a lot faster. So sure as just doing some overhead jerks there to show you. So every time whether you're cleaning the bell, if you want to clean it, you clean the bell, you're bringing up. You're always going to try and land it so it's the same all the time. So it takes a little bit of technique to get to using it properly. And like we said, if you're using it for fitness, there's different things that you can do that doesn't require as much technique if you're only doing a few reps. But when you get into the sport training, the biggest thing is that you're starting to train for time and reps per minute versus just doing 10 reps at a time. So sure as just doing a double hand swing there and you notice that we don't like to go any times past the shoulder. You see some of the crossfit people elect to bring your bell right over top of their head and they hyper extend their back. It's kind of a dangerous movement. So what she's doing here though with one hand is everything is used for the hips. So you're always generating power through your heels and your feet up into your hips. So you're never lifting anything just with your shoulder. You're not pulling it up. All you're doing with your hand is just keeping that kettlebell in the position that you want it to be in. So she's just doing alternating, alternating at one arm swings there. And the thing with the kettlebell is that you'll notice is that when you get training with them as a, there's no, there's no downtime. You're continuously moving. You're continuously breathing. You can see that she's breathing. She's not holding your breath because if you hold your breath at any time, especially when you get into longer sets and it's going to impair your ability to go for your 10 minute set. So there's a lot of different movements that you can do. If we wanted to sport training, we'll show you, Sherry is going to show you how to do that the females do the long cycle. But you see when she brings it down, she's absorbing it with her body and using your hips to bring it back up. And then it's just the jerk movement where she accepts the weight on the way up with her knee bend. So she would do this for five minutes on one side and then switch and go to the other side. So lots of fun. Definitely a great workout. === FILE: elitefts.com - Whethams Demonstrate the Kettlebell Snatch [6kfdLbOP9pQ].txt ===

Can and Sherry Weddham from EliteFDS.com and today we're going to try and teach you a little bit of kettlebell technique as far as the snatch goes. Snatch is probably the most technical movement to learn properly and efficiently. What we're going to do is we're going to try and go over a few of the pointers that are really important to try and get some dial in some good technique. We'll cover a little bit of the mechanics and the trajectory and hopefully it will help you improve your kettlebell technique. So my lovely assistant Sherry here, we're going to get her to just first of all we'll just take the snatch and we'll just do a few snatches just to show what the actual technique is. So into a lock-up position straight up. Good. All right. So you can see if you watched our last kettlebell video on the hip movement as far as the kettlebell clean goes with the shoulder and the hip relationship going back and forth, it's going to be very similar to the way that the snatch goes. What we need to do when we're stretching the kettlebell up is you're basically going to try and stay connected with the inside of your quad and when you propel your hips forward and you're going to pull your shoulder back, you're going to try and get as much extension as you can in your shoulder to really fire that kettlebell up. And what you're trying to do with your arm basically is to just the guy that kettlebell up as close as you can to your center of gravity and you're also going to keep it straight up and you don't want to have the kettlebell out at all because it's going to put a lot of torque on your shoulder so you want to keep it nice and close so you're almost touching your bicep on your ear. So once we get into the lock-up position straight up is that one of the first movements that we want to do is just to kind of twist that kettlebell a little bit, we're going to bring it around forward because it will be hanging in behind. So you want to bring it around forward and you're going to lead with your elbow down nice and straight through and then there's going to be the transition that goes down and thumb back and you can see how she read bent her knees and got her hips back. Her shoulders forward to accept that weight and then she's basically going to bend her knees and load and she's going to extend that kettlebell straight up. And so this is a full body movement. So what we're trying to do is we don't want the kettlebell to come out far away from your body. We're always going to try and keep it as close as close your body and as close as to the front as you can and the same thing when we drop it down. This kettlebell for sure you're up at the top. I mean, this kettlebell is what 30 pounds, Sherry. So by the time it gets down to the bottom here, if you just drop it down there, it's going to weigh a lot more at the bottom. This is where you're susceptible to your grip strength because that's the most, it's going to be the portion of the movement that is in the most jeopardy. So when she goes down, she's going to try and twist that kettlebell down. We're just going to do it in slow motion. Bring her elbow down. She's going to do that transition which comes down, bring it through. You're going to load up the hips and then fire it straight back up again. So we'll just do a couple again, Sherry, just a little bit in fast motion there a little bit. She's trying to make that kettlebell as light as she can from the top of the movement down in the bottom. So up at the top, so it's almost like a slow motion movement as much as you can to try and descend it as slowly and control it and fire it back up. Then you can see the heavier that the kettlebell gets, basically you're going to try and really want to get, fire with as much emphasis out of your hips as you can and you're going to really try and pull your shoulders back to really get that extension and stay connected as long as you can. If you get disconnected from the snatch, I don't know if you can try and do one that's not proper, if you can kind of just not say you're going to see that she's going to be pulling that kettlebell up with her shoulder versus using your strong muscles which is your bottom end. So it makes it a lot tougher and you're really going to wear out a lot faster. So we'll do a couple more like that. One of the things that Sherry doesn't do that I do because I'm a lot taller so I'm over six feet when I have the kettlebell overhead. It's almost eight feet off the ground. One of the movements that you can do is what she just did right there is to lean back. You can almost drop that kettlebell back, drop it down about three or four inches even before you start to descent just by leaning back. You can see and then you get a nice path to drop it down right and forward again so you can just drop it back. Yeah. Perfect. And just fire it back up. Now, one of the things that it's hard to see here, let's just see the kettlebell for a second Sherry. One of the things that's hard to see because it's going between Sherry's legs is that you've always seen the overhead hook grip when you're doing the deadlift and she is actually when you pinch that kettlebell underneath, you're actually pinching it into a lock position so you're locking your finger in your thumb in an old caposition underneath there. So when that kettlebell goes underneath your legs, you're actually pinching that to try and improve your grip on the bottom, just like you would in a deadlift with an overhead thumb lock. So if you're snatching a kettlebell properly, you're really grabbing it for the most part between your four finger and your thumb and you're going to start to get a really good call us on the inside of your front hand. Shouldn't be a call us to turn up in the middle of your hand if you're doing it properly because you're going to be grabbing it basically on the edge up in the horseshoe of that kettlebell like so and then you're going to be propelling it up with your hips and going from there. Okay, one of the things that you can do if you get into lifting a heavier kettlebell is it's obviously harder with a heavier weight to get it up as high or propellant as high. So one of the things that you can do before she gets into the lock out, she can bend her knees to accept that weight up at the top. So if you start to train with a heavier kettlebell with a snatch, is that you can always propel that kettlebell up and if it's a lot heavier than you're used to, when you first start to get into it, you can bend your knees to accept it into a lock-up position at the top. So that's another thing that and if you start to get fatigued into a longer set, that's also one of the things that you can go to to try and help you get through that set as well. So hopefully that'll help you a little bit in some of the pointers that we use for teaching people how to use the snatch properly, but definitely you want to get away from casting the kettlebell out and bringing it up far away from your body. You want to really propel it up, you know, as close to your body as you can and bring it down as close to your body as you can. So hopefully that'll help you out.

Mark Watts, leadFDS.com. We're going to talk about straps today and one of the questions people says, well, who doesn't know how to use straps? Well, you'd be surprised. So, the old school straps are basically set up like a tear drop. Now, we have two kinds of orange and then we have our super heavies, which obviously are the next step up. Now, there's no left or right on these. So, we get a lot of questions about that. The stitching is the way it is. And remember, this part's not going to really be in contact with your hand anyway. It's going to be contact with the bar. So, that doesn't matter. There's no right or left with these. The advantage of these straps, again, putting your hand through and then wrapping around the bar, is a lot of times for Olympic lifts. You have a quick transition. It's a really quick release. If you're doing poles or whatnot and you've got to go ahead and drop the weight, you can actually let go of your hand and that ball just roll out. The second one is if you're doing a lot of circuit type work and you're doing some back work going from the machine to the machine, exercise exercise. You want to save that grip a little bit. This is a really quick, easy transition to get your to be able to utilize this. So, again, those are our two types of old school straps. So, really good for Olympic lifting and some quick in and out. So, the other straps we have will go over each one of these. Talk about this is our basic, we have two basic kinds of reds in the blues. Now, there's no real differences. One is about five cents. More expensive. One's $10.1.9.5 on sale. And there's no reason for that. We just do that to message you. But with these, the way to do is you pull one end through the other. And then how you have it set up is if you have it set on the ground, when you have these straps, you want to have put your hand through with the strap laying down. And now that'll be in that same direction between your finger and your thumb. So, again, some people like to do it the opposite, but this is probably the easiest way to get used to putting straps on. As far as utilization with this, and again, easiest way to do this is obviously if this is a barbell is a wrap your to wrap it around. And then once you have that, and again, if you want to have it so that it's not over top of itself, so that again, the the more it's over top of yourself, the more uneven it's you're going to have. And the thicker that bar actually becomes. Once you grab that, you want to kind of rev it the opposite of a motorcycle, re-grab rev, re-grab, and that way it's going to be tight on the wrist. If you're utilizing this with any kind of pulls or back movements, obviously you want to tie as possible. If you're one of those coaches that utilize straps for Olympic lifts, and I'm not judging, if that's what you want to do, make sure that that strap is not so tight. So if they catch the clean, again, you see most high schools in America, they use the straps for the clean. If you make sure that it's not so tight that inhibits the wrist and that catch position. So, again, that's going to be based on your philosophy. So, that's a quick way to do that as far as some of the differences between these. Again, a regular blue, we have the orange stripe, which it actually has rubber in that stitched into the actual strap itself. And it just really adds as far as grip on your hand and grip on the bar as well too. So that's kind of the next step bump. We do have the leather. Now, the leather is unique. Some people like it, some people hate it. The one thing I'll just caution you about the leather is that sometimes if you use a lot of chalk, sometimes that can actually inhibit your grip a little bit. So if you're using the leather, a lot of straw men sometimes use this, I would probably incorporate some kind of some kind of grip, some kind of tacky or some liquid grip whatnot for this. So that's the only drawback, but it is a different feel. And again, the leather we have is soft. It's a little bit more pliable than most. The next step bump from the blue straps is the super heavy duty. And again, same basic scenario. Most of our straps are going to be about an inch and a half in width. We do have some that are two inches in width. So that'll add a little bit to that surface area. So I'm talking about this is our yellow jacks. This is probably our most heavy duty wrap in this series. And this is the yellow jack. It's our, they're going to be more of a clock material. It's going to be thicker and it's also wider. So it's at two inches in width. We also have the orange stripe in two inches with too. And again, the one thing to be cautioned about for again, this is for people with big hands, for people that are doing some heavy pulls, some 18 inch deadless whatnot. And again, the only thing to caution about with these with the thicker straps is that when it wraps around the bar, obviously that surface area of this that strap's going to take on the bar is going to be a little bit, it's going to take more room. So again, make sure that if you're going to double up and have the strap rolling on top of each other, make sure that you know that, again, that's going to basically thicken the width of that bar. So that's pretty basic with those. So again, again, if you have any questions about how to use straps, or with straps or best few, don't forget to give it a call. 888-854-8006 or visit us at elitefts.com. Thanks.

Not I'm not going to make the team which ironically I never made the team. Well, I was never at the level that I should have been but I kept on training. So football put aside. I was like well I'm going to stay in the gym. I'm going to keep on working out. Well, I'm probably like fitness seems like a good venue for me. I'm like I'll work towards that. So I trained a lot a lot. I had coaches, they helped me out. I trained with some of the best guys in Montreal in terms of bodybuilding. I started integrating that style of training, the blockpureization or the concurrents or I started mixing it up with what I knew. And that's pretty much how I work my things today. Like, one aspect that helps everybody, yeah, just put in work. That's it. === FILE: elitefts.com — Chad Aichs Interview (Part 2) [zfUHZBAeYB0].txt ===

Hey there there's Steve Coltscotts for aletefts.com. We're talking again with Chad Aix and Chad. My question for you this time out is what traits make a champion, Litter? That's a good question. For me it's heart. I know a lot of people that I've seen that I've trained or that I wanted to train, that have great genetics. And I'm like, man, I could make this guy. Freak. They never make it because they don't have any heart. So I've gotten to the point where when I'm looking to train somebody, if I see somebody with a potential, I'm looking more for heart and will over genetics. I don't give a crap about genetics anymore. I don't feel like I had amazing genetics. I didn't have horrible genetics, but the only thing the reasons I did what I did is because I got heart and I got a crap little will. Some of my best lifts are done. My best official squat was done with my hamstring shredded because I wasn't going to quit. I didn't give a f what happened. I was going to lift and I was going to get that lift no matter what. And I think that's one of the best traits of a champion. A champion is not going to worry about anybody else. They're not going to worry about what's wrong. And they're on the field, on the platform. It's a battlefield. And they're going to rip shit up. I mean, they're not going to stop. They're not going to quit. They're going to go into their dead or they get you what they want. So I think the mental aspect, heart, will, that's all. That's what makes a champion. Can you see that in some of the eyes that wrote some of our? Yeah. More than anything I can see when they don't have it. I've seen a live lifted with a lot of people. And I considered stronger than me, especially when I was coming up. And I would watch him go up to the barn. I'm like, nope. They should get this, but there's no way they will. And they never did. What were some names that impressed you as far as they're willing? They're 19. Brett Myxel impressed me a lot. When I came up, he was one of the first guys that I actually saw squad of thousand. And then he broke the record. I think at a thousand 41. And then kept breaking it up to like 1171. And a guy who comes out into platform and goes, I don't give a shit. What anyone else ever did, I'm going to do this. That's will. That's a guy that's saying screw everyone. I know I can do it and I'm going to do it. And he basically did that with that record, which was hugely impressive to me. I mean, anybody that goes out there and does that Ryan Cannelly was a strong, strong competitor and did like people would say, you can't do that. He'd be like middle finger, watch me. And that's the kind of attitude I respect a lot. A lot of these guys, they seem to their careers are not long lived. No. What was that? Because I think this sport destroys your body. The things we do are crazy. I mean, my natural body weight, I usually walk around before I started a power lift and was anywhere from 240 to 270. And I was competing, I was 385. Even now I'm at 330. I mean, that's still even though I'm not fat, at least not hugely fat. That's a lot of weight to carry. And in the amount of weights we're lifting, the stress on our something nervous system, the stress on our adrenal system, I mean, it takes a lot of wear out of you. I saw an interview with, I think, was Magnus from Magnus one time, who said basically, you got 10 years. Because I don't care when you start, you got 10 years. It's like the stress and beating that we put on our body. It's just a lot. But then you got guys like Chuck Vogelpool, who I go, I don't know how the hell this dude keeps doing this. He's an animal. Because he just keeps going and doing it. Me, I'm at about 11 or 12. And I'm struggling to tell you. It's trying to rework everything at this point. Appreciate it, Thomas. No problem.
