=== FILE: elitefts.com — Chad Aichs Interview (Part 4) [2V_mDuCsTwQ].txt ===

I'm here with Chad Ike's, my name is Steve Colzkott, so you're a content manager for leadfts.com. And Chad, I wanted to brush up on a question about the biggest obstacle that you had to overcome in your lifting career. Without a doubt, the biggest obstacle is my sleep, which I've written a lot about and some people complain about hearing it. But when I started my log, one of the things I talked to David about is I want to write down everything that affects my lifting. So that somebody can read my log and go, hey, I had these problems or hey Chad adjusted it for this. So I always wrote about it. And for those that don't know, it basically, when my sleep's good, I don't get states here for it else to sleep. I've had a bunch of sleep studies and I think I got 30 seconds of stage 3 at one point. And it ranges from that to complete insomnia where the most, I think I did, was a 2007. The year I crashed with like 1170 something, I had been up for nine days before that meet. And then I was up another three or four after it was, I think it was a total of 14 days with no sleep. And that also turns into some dealing with some severe depression at times. That was always my biggest obstacle. And the biggest effect that it had on me was my recovery is horrible. I mean, absolutely horrible. And I can tell, especially looking back, being in a position I'm now looking back at what I did, I go, wow, I screwed a lot of things up and I made it actually worse because I wouldn't back off. Or if I would have backed off, I probably would have recovered a little faster. I would have had to take less time off training, but I would have recovered faster and probably would have got stronger. So dealing with that was really tough and also having my own team of guys, it's like, you got to kind of none of them have sleep problems. So they recover way faster than me. So I got to set up a program where we can all, we're all making the best gains we can. And we're all in there for each other in heavy days and it's helping with gear and spotting and all that stuff. So it's kind of like a puzzle trying to put everything together and fit it. And still to this day, I'm a super aggressive person and I hate not lifting heavy. And I hate not going to the gym. So it's a struggle for me to go to a chat. You better off just going in and helping today. And that's even worse. Going in and helping my partners lift heavy, he's like, just hate it. But I had to look at it as word do I want to be and what am I going to be and what's going to get me that it fastest? I did the drop in body weight, make your sleep any better. No, because I've had sleep problems since I was in about fifth grade as the best I can pinpoint when it started to happen. And I've been skinny, chubby, like everything in between. The only thing it does make it easier to deal with. I mean, if you don't sleep all night or you have a really bad night and I get up at 330 body weight, it's all at easier to deal with than being 385 or 390. What do you think? What did they find it to be? Is it like something nervous system? You're not able to amp down to sleep or what? Actually, they have not been able to figure it out completely. There is a syndrome called alpha delta wave intrusion. Or basically your brains and alpha waves. Then when you sleep, it'll kick down in the delta waves, which puts you in the delta sleep. And there's a disorder where it'll shoot. Your brain will kind of start going into delta. It'll start shooting out of a wave sporadically, which kicks you back out. The best thing they had for that was GHB, which is basically the date rate drug. Doctors are pretty picky about giving prescriptions for that. But I obtained some and tried it and it really didn't do much. Try to understand yourself. Yeah. I'm myself. I don't need it for dating. But I do notice that on the subject, dropping weight and backing off a little bit, trying to let my body kind of heal up so I can start ramping up again. I have noticed that one of the few drugs I found that worked as Sarah Quill. I'm one lower doses than I've ever been on in getting the same result, which is not awesome sleep. It doesn't knock me out and I wake up in the morning. That doesn't happen. My best nights, I'm probably up 30 times. But on that, I'm taking way less doses than I have, which I kind of attribute to letting my system heal up. What type of injuries have you had to deal with your career? I don't know if I'm talking about Dave, my injuries don't seem that bad, because my joints are actually really healthy. I had a guy helped me out with my hip, because I've had a hip injury for a long, long time. Many videos you see me pulling. I'm hurting bad by the time I'm pulling. We actually went and did an MRI and the doctor asked me, is that can I keep the MRI your hip and I'm like, yeah, why? Because I'm going to show people what a hip's supposed to look like. Because you lift this massive weight and you got the hips of a 19-year-old. So my joints are actually really good, but my muscles are just right. I have an enormous hole in this hamstring, my left hamstring, which I tore. I think it was the old, oh, seven Arnold, maybe. Something like that. I tore like six weeks before and then I tore it again on my opener. I've torn this pack like three times, which it's pretty much nothing right here now. I tore this tricep head pretty good where you can actually see the inner heads missing that bunch of meat, little tears in both biceps, I've strained my back pretty good a couple times, which could have had slight tears, I'm not totally sure. I just hurt and I figured, I do what you got to do. What's your key to getting past those? That's nice. I think with torn muscles, one of the biggest things is first of all, Ice immediately and continue icing. I'm a huge, huge fan of ice just because it gets swelling out. I'm smelling is going to slow recovery. I know a lot of people, oh yeah, Ice at last night. Ice it, Ice at every day, a couple times a day for a month, until it's better, just keep icing it. With torn muscles, I find stretching, light stretching, right away. When I tore my pack, I go, Ice and I start doing some light stretching and work it a little bit because you want to keep that muscle long and straight and you don't want scar tissue laying down in a wrong way. As long as you don't over stretch it, you're really not going to do any damage to it. Any more that's already done anyway. Ice it, thank you.

=== FILE: elitefts.com — Chad Aichs Interview (Part 5) [Q9vBija5evc].txt ===

See if cool Scott here, Chad Aix. We're talking the topic for this segment. It's going to be a Chad someone that kind of puts everything into what he's doing. You have learned, you mentioned to me, I think last time you're out, that you've learned that you need to do a little bit less. Can you speak to that? Yeah, I think I actually overtraining and people bagging me sometimes because I talk about overtraining so much, but I think overtraining is basically like a plague in strength sports. You have two types of people. You have the lazy people that you're going to have to push and push and push and push and push. Those are people that don't have heart, which is what we talked about earlier. They're never going to be champions. And then you have the people that are aggressive as hell and they push and push and push. And these people, you got to hold back. And most top athletes are this type of person. And a lot of guys, I know a lot of guys that never get to the level they could get because they keep overtraining. And we had this mindset in America that more is better and push harder and push further. And I'm definitely that type of person, but through my sleep which we also talked about, my sleep being bad, I just don't recover for shit. And if you beat yourself up and you don't recover and you go back and beat yourself up again, you're not getting stronger. I say very often, we break ourselves down in the gym. We basically beat ourselves up. We do not get stronger in the gym. We get stronger when we're out of the gym, when we recover from the gym. And a lot of people as simple as that is, a lot of people don't understand that or they refuse to accept that they haven't really recovered. So I found out when I started training and I started off a basic Westside template and about every four weeks, everybody, everybody on my team would go to shit. I mean, we would be beat up, our speed would drop, our max lifts would drop, and I'm like, this is not right. And it was funny because Mark Bartley, I was reading about Mark Bartley who was kind of having similar problems at the same time. And what he did is he had everybody do a D-load week and a fourth week. Well, my aggressive mentality was like, no, I don't want to take a week off. So I'd rather spread this out so I'm still lifting more continuously, but there's more days off in between there. And then, you know, I spread it out a little bit, I'd get stronger, okay? Maybe we need to go a little more. Maybe we need to go in like the first couple of times I'm doubting myself. Because nobody else is doing it, everybody else is like killed themselves, go to the gym, be to crap with themselves. And but I'm like, my goal is to be the best I can be, and this isn't working. So then as I got stronger and stronger, I kept having to take more time off. And George Haber was actually one of the first people I heard mentioned that. As you get stronger, you're going to need more time off. And you are. You're stressing your drugs in your whatever. Yeah, you're stressing your center nervous system. You have a greater ability to recruit more muscle fibers. You have a greater ability to push your body, your technique at that point is more efficient. So you're lifting more weight, which is stressing your center nervous system. I mean, it makes sense if you think about it. And one of the best notes I had on that is my partner was squatting around nine, nine and a half. And I said, that's it. I go, I need to spread it out. And I think we were spreading out the basically I 14 days at that point. And we got into a big fight and he's like, fine, and I'll train on my own and I go fine. Whatever. I go, we're doing this. I go, I always do what the team needs and try to meet a middle point. And right now we need to do this. And so I finally he gave in. And I knew he would. And man, it was within like two or three months. He squatted its first thousand and a meat. And I kind of say, Scott, how about that idea I had? This entire topic makes me think of the importance of having a coach because a lot of people they can't Sop regulate and they need somebody that hasn't and outside perspective. Do you find that the fact that you act as a coach is a part of why you're able to kind of regulate yourself a little bit better? Yes and no, I think with me it boils down to I'm a very gold oriented person. And if my goal is to squat this amount of weight, I'm going to do whatever the hell it takes for that to happen. And sometimes even if that's me like putting myself in check going chat, yeah, you think you're recovering but you're not. That's what I'll do. But from a coach and team standpoint, it helps a bunch. I even know to this point when I started my team, it was a requirement that like you're going to learn technique. You're going to speak the hell up. You're going to help load plates, you know, everybody, we're a team. Everybody's going to do everything. And if I see somebody doing something wrong, somebody else doesn't say something, I'm going to jump their shit for not saying it. You know, and when a guy comes in new, I'm always like, what did you do wrong? Until I know the guy starts getting it, you know, and it got to the point where my guys are like, Chad, you're done. You're done today. You know, we can tell, we can see your speed, we can see how you look. Because there's a lot of science for me when my sleep gets bad and there's a lot of science to overtraining. And you know, when any one of us starts getting down there, you'll start hearing, hey, how's your appetite? How are you sleeping? You know, how are you feeling, how's your flexibility? And like you hear all these questions start getting the asking, it's like, yeah, you're done, dude. And like, well, are you it? I've argued it. I've had time. There's times where I've went to the bathroom and those guys unload the bar and I come back pissed off and reload it. And they're like, you're done. I'm like, you know, I'm not, you know, I'll do it. And then we get into big argument at you of how it looks and I say, it looks like shit. And usually they're right, but I still like to argue sometimes. So I think I think having a team and guys that are on board and that actually know is a huge thing. And I think that helped me a lot. Because I mean, I think I do have a lot of self-control, but like I said, I do stupid things all the time. And it took me longer and longer to this point and my partners go, Chad, knock it off. I'm like, crap. All right, I'm done. I don't like it, but at least I listen now. And one of the other things that I just thought of where we were talking, the sleek thing. When my sleep set is best, like I wake up a lot. And what I found with watching my partners and their overtraining, if they do overtraining, their sleep will start getting screwed up too. And it starts very similar to my, my word, my regular nights, you know, like mine just won't get. Going to bed and waking up in the morning is not, it's actually unfathomable to me. I can't even imagine it. I'm rarely asleep longer than a couple hours at one time. But my partners all sleep normal. And we found out from, like I said, the conversations, I mean, things are going wrong. Well, like everybody sits on the gym, why is it going wrong? And what's going, what's happening? And we'll have big discussions about it. And we found out over time that when they do start overtraining, they're sleeping bad. And it always starts by them being really restless and having trouble falling asleep and waking up a lot during a night. And it's like when I first catch that, next week you're either de-load or take it completely off. I don't really care, but you're not lifting heavy. And then within four or five days, our sleep goes back to normal. And I'm like, I don't want anyone to experience the crap I have with my sleep. So I'm like, no, that's it. You're done. If you're not sleeping, you're not recovering. You're just going to make everything worse. You're not getting stronger. So stop. Just stop till it gets right. Okay. Okay. The wisdom of doing less. Thank you, Jen.

Everybody here, me, okay? Now you realize, they're clapping after you said that you would have killed yourself. I just want you to take note of that. You know, All right, just to kind of get a general sense of who I'm speaking to here. How many of you guys are a power lifters? Hands up. Competitive power lifters. Okay, trainers. Coaches. Olympic weight lifters. Good, can't help you to hold a lot. A strong man. Bodybuilding. CrossFit. Can't help you that much either, but I'll try my best, you know? Okay, so, Well, I wanted to, how many of you have been one of the learned to train seminars before? That's another question that I have. All right, so you guys have seen Skinny Day, Fat Day, Mediandave, Big Day, Small Day, Hip Replacement Day. If you've seen me in and doing many different forms, I like, Murph myself with every seminar. So you never know what you're going to expect. The, I'm trying to think here which direction I want to go. Because this is going to be the last learn to train. I want to try to do something a little bit different. You know what? We're going to go off the grid. How do I kill this? All right. All right. Okay. I'm going to talk about some things that Normally you want to hear Spoken about, Spoken about. My grandmother's not always the best, my English major. I'm in meathead. All right. The topic I'm still going to keep a supplemental and accessory movements. I'm not going to change that. But I'm going to change how I approach it a little bit more and take some of the structure and some of the bullshit that would normally come with an normal presentation out of it. So you can actually use what the hell I'm going to give you. And instead of going through point by point, all this crap that you can see in any, you know, Conference or seminar or whatnot. So with that in mind, what I've seen and have seen, I started competing in 82 or 83. And I retired in 2005. Let's just say it was a 50 50 retirement 50% because I couldn't do it anymore physically 50% because I really didn't have the desire or the passion that I had to be on the platform that I used to. So I don't want to say that the car was forced for me while it kind of was, but at the same time I knew it was time to kind of move on a little bit. There were a lot of things and I, this is why I wanted to kill this. There's a lot of things that I've never spoke of before because I don't like to be that person that says, if I was to go back and do it all over again, I would do this. If you've heard me speak before you've always heard me say things like, I wouldn't change anything. I would have kept it all the same because that's what made me who I am and that's generally how I feel. But at the same time, no presenter or anybody who is in strength and conditioning wants to go back and expose all their mistakes and say why did this wrong, I did this wrong, but I've come to the conclusion that I've done 90% of the shit my life wrong anyhow. So what do I got to lose? So there are some things that I would do differently. Training wise, if I was to go back and do it all over again for powerlifting and it's good that many of you raised your hands when I asked about powerlifting because that's the example that I'm going to use. When your powerlifting and the objective is very simple to get a better squat, bench and deadlift. That is your sport, that's the technique. So... That's the most important thing. That's why you do what you do. To have the best squat, bench and deadlift, I suck at the deadlift, that's why I can't say it very well. Always have always well. Now, if you're to flip this around a little bit and think of this in terms of coaching, everybody has the goal of whatever your coaching. I've consulted with a lot of coaches over the years. I cannot tell them as I can't tell CrossFit or Olympic weightlifting. I can't tell them how to train. I've never done that. I refuse to tell or teach or coach anything I've never personally done. I don't know the skills behind it. I don't know the technique behind it. I can tell how to increase maximal strength, but is that going to have a dynamic correspondence to what you're doing or carry over? I don't know. I don't like to speak about things I don't know. I want to speak about things I do know. So, if you are a coach and you're looking at an athlete, say a football player, one of the things that I would ask, the coach who I would be consulting with, are what are the top three exercises you feel have the highest correspondence to the sport. Everybody's answer is going to be different because everybody's got a different training philosophy. They could say clean, they could say 40, they could say squat, whatever it is. To me, that's going to follow up on this high end. It's going to follow in the technical end. So while I'm going through this, keep that in mind if you're not strictly a power lifter. Keep in mind that the squat, bench and deadlift merely only represent the goal that you're trying to achieve. Whatever it would be, even if it was a decrease in body fat or whatnot. Those under those would fall and everybody's got different names for these things. The main, this is getting breaking down a training session. Underneath that would follow the main exercise. Now, I don't care how you train. I don't care if you use a linear approach and nonlinear approach, conjugate approach or if you don't know what I'm talking about. I don't know if you, I don't care if you train the cube. West side. Give me some other ones. Jugg or not. Dog, grab, 531. All of them are going to follow all of these programs follow some type of progression. All be it linear, nonlinear, concurrent. That's really much it or block. One of those four. Every program you see out there is going to follow one of those four. Unless it's just a half-ass hazard program that's just thrown together without any thought, then it just falls off into never, never land. I would say that's not even a program. That's just a bunch of shit. Slap together or just waiting for somebody waiting to get hurt. Because it's got to be some type of approach. The reason I am saying that is because this main lift here is going to change based upon what philosophy or what type of program you're training. If you're using a program that would be more concurrent based or west side based, this main lift may be any max effort exercise or dynamic exercise. Or in the case of west side, it could be good mornings, low-box, wide-board press, two-board press, lower-press, or for speed-work, box-squat, dynamic bench presses. This is just the main movement and how it's being trained to correspond to the technical movement, which is out there. In a concurrent approach, those movements are not the same. They're usually different. Everybody understand that? I trained at west side for 14 years and the only time we did the technical list were when we were in a meet. That's kind of one of the differences between a concurrent-style of training compared to a block or linear or non-linear. If it is a block or one of the other styles, that main lift will actually be the squat, the bench press, or the deadlift. Those lifts are going to be cycled based upon whatever program you're using. Some of them may use a linear, which will start like in a 50% and then drive up to a 95, some of them may wave. Some of them may go in a progression like that. I'm not getting really detailed in this because I want to talk about the stuff that falls underneath this. I'm giving you this as background for your own training programs to be thinking about how you train now and what you do. What is the first movement? Is that first movement for you a max effort of dynamic exercise and within your views and more of a concurrent type of approach? If you're using the squat-benture deadlift, does it follow a linear progression? Does it follow a non-linear? Where it kind of creeps up and down? I mean, as long as there's all of them to be honest, no matter what it is, all of them are linear because they're all going to work up over time. It's just how it gets there. I can answer questions on this after I'm done babbling about the other stuff. But this is very complex. I can do a whole day seminar just on each one of these. But that would be the main lift. Usually that's the first lift when you're in the gym. And that lift has the highest dynamic correspondence or carryover to the technical lifts that you're going to be doing when you compete or you're going for a max model. Everybody understand that. Okay, if you were to take these completely out of your strength training program and your power lifter, how much success do you think you would have? None. You would suck. Let me put it that way. So this has a very, very, very large importance. Number one, most important thing is that and how that's being cycle. Now the cool thing between today with everybody wanting to bitch about the internet and when I came up, you're access to this segment of a program is so available, it's unbelievable. When I in 83, I had to figure this shit out. I had to have people tell me what to do, you know, that I was trained in with. You didn't just find the meat of a program anywhere. To be honest, and I don't want to give credit if it's not due, I think Louie's the one that actually broke the bubble on this. And he's the first one that actually started writing about how a program is actually put together. And then from that, people started to share how they were actually training in the program we now. Now you have access to linear models, not linear models. I mean, you can just Google search any of this crap and you're going to find this part of a training program like that. I don't think anybody in here questions this part. Now they do bounce around a lot. You know, they won't stay with the same program, but they don't question the importance of it. Nor do they question the ability to be able to find what it is. This actually, in my opinion, is the easiest part to program. All right, because it is pretty cut and dry pretty straightforward. Under that, would be what I call, I call it a couple of metal. The subtle metal exercise. Now we're going to start to get into a lot of my philosophy and a lot of the things where I say, I would have done differently. I believe strongly that there is a difference between training and movement and training in a muscle. And that's been more ingrained since I've been training in pretty much like a bodybuilder since 2005 or 2006, and have seen and felt the difference. An example that everybody can relate to would be think about doing a maximal bench press or a heavy set of five on the bench press. And then, what the arm movement pattern looks like. And then picture a crock row, which is a heavy short row. That's basically the same thing in reverse. So that's training a movement. That's training the movement of the bench press. It's helping to make that movement stronger. Now let's picture a dumbbell row where you let the scapula relax and stretch your lat at the bottom. And you drive your elbow as high as you can at the top and contract. So you have maximal stretch to maximal contraction. Now you're training a muscle. You're not going to be able to use as much weight training the muscle as you can training the movement. I think both are vital when it comes to power lifting. Through my years as a power lifter, all my movements were based on training movement, not muscle. As a result of that, I think I've accumulated joint damage in other injuries because most of the lifts the power lifter does are trying to find ways to make a front movement. The shortest range movement that you possibly can. You know, you want to try to take a squat that may be 18 inches and shorten it down to nine. You want to try to take a bench that may be 12 inches and make it eight. Why? You lift more weight. Traveling the shorter distance. And while the core spawned and to get that carry over, your accessories are going to follow the same pattern. You may not even know it until you start looking and thinking about the accessories you're currently doing now to train your main lifts. Those accessory movements are probably things like board presses, JAM presses, short, try to set extensions, shoulders to elbows back up. Short range, don't movements. I'm trying to think of other examples. I mean, you guys, I could just ask examples. You guys could just blow them all out. And what you're trying to do is you're trying to find those movements that are going to directly clear over to this first one. To make this easier to understand, I'm going to use a concurrent approach. For me, the floor press, two board press and closed grip inclined press had dynamic correspondence to my bench press. I always knew my floor press was going to be 90% of what my raw bench was going to be. Always knew my two board press was going to be 92% of what my raw bench was going to be. My closed grip inclined press was always going to be 64% of what my raw bench was going to be. To me, a raw bench back then was usually whatever I could hit on on one board. We never really did straight wall, raw presses, but on one board to your chest is damn near the same. It's just breathing more. When I trained for the bench press, I did not put myself in a competitive position in the gym. I only did that in a meat to keep some of the pressure off my low back. So I could get that extra inch from the board, just with body position. I know these percentages for a fact because I tracked them for 14 years. Because I wanted to know what carried over to what? Because to me, I wanted an indicator because I needed to know what I was going to open my bench with because we, honest to God, never benched in the gym. The shirts and gear were different than two. So now there's a whole other factor which changes the rules a little bit. But that allowed me and gave me a clue of where I actually stood. These exercises, I would use closer to a meat. Why am I telling you about those? Because when it came to supplemental work from my upper body, I wasn't working in triceps. I wasn't working in packs. I was working movements to make my close grip. I wanted to make these stronger. Not this. I didn't give a shit about making that stronger. I cared about making those stronger because I knew for a fact when those went up, that went up. So what did I have to do to make those better? That's where I put my focus when it came to the supplemental movements. Through trial and error, you figure those out. Because you're currently doing these would rotate in my cycle, in my training plan, at least once every eight weeks or so. So if I started doing JM presses and my close grip in client at the time was 415. And I started doing JM presses and everything else pretty much stays the same. I rotate back four or five weeks later the close grip in client and now it's 455. Now I know that JM press has a correspondence to my close grip bench. That drove that up. Now if whatever I'm doing here doesn't drive these up, I'm changing this shit. Because this is the main goal. I'm not going to waste my time doing exercises that are not going to bring up the movements that I want to bring up. So over time I found JM press floor extensions, chain extensions on the floor. Just barbell, you know, tries to extend just on the floor using a bunch of chain. I put like a quarter each side and just start loading chain up less stretch or less damage to the elbow, but still ton of force on the tries up at the top. Those all carried over. So over time I began to build a list of supplemental exercises that were bringing up my main movement, which in turn brought up my technical skill. And I can fuse in everybody yet. You're all with me. Okay. Throughout this I'm going to skip back and forth because I know most of you probably don't use a concurrent style of training. So now if you're using a different style of training to where this main exercise here is always the squat bench or deadlift. Rules are still the same. You will notice through your training when you're doing certain movements to supplemental movements, you will feel better when you're doing the main movement. Those are movements you need to put brackets around and start them and make sure they become in your program more frequently. Now you don't want to live and die by them because every movement's got limited strength potentials the way I like to explain it. You will become to use to it to where it won't have the effect that you're looking for anymore. So a lot of these movements here I would only save before a meet. And the non-meat time when there's no meat going on I would try all kinds of different things to see if it had any correspondents and a lot of times the stuff would go down. So those I would put in there for that. So one of them is going to be based upon actually watching the max effort exercise go up. Others are going to be on how you feel. For example, going back to the bench, you know I had a dynamic bench day and a max effort bench day. This close grip incline really had more benefit on my speed work than it did my max most strength. I had a close grip incline presses into my speed on the bench went through the roof every single time. All right. The floor press had more of an impact on the max or my max effort work the heavier stuff. But a lot of this that I'm speaking about is coming about because I stuck with the same philosophy or the same program for 14 years. When you start jumping around from program to program you're never going to be able to find two things. And that's where the supple metal and the accessory work comes in as being able to find two and these little details. We already know this is this is the big big stuff right here. This stuff is probably going to get 90% of you in this room where you want to go. But what if you want to go that one extra step nobody else can go. You need to fine tune the shit underneath it. All right. And that's what I'm talking about here you know with and that's why I killed what I was going to talk about. Because I want to give you the stuff that we give you that extra 10% that most people are never going to see. Because they don't think this deep into a program. They think here that's it. You know I'm going to do this we're going to you know use this program we're going to do this and everything think. It all of what movements will make the movement that makes my squat stronger. They never think down that level they will think to the level of saying well. Good hand raises are supposed to make my squat and deadlift stronger so I'm going to do those. First off you're making an assumption that may not be true for you. Why not find out. Do it in there and pay attention. Does your squat and deadlift feel better. You will know within three or four weeks if it feels better or not. You may be able to stand up stronger. Maybe you have to stay tighter. You may be able to sit back further. You will notice something. If you don't then it's not having any correspondence to carry over. Get it the hell out and put something else in. What I'm saying here is what makes the glue ham stronger. If you if you already figure out the glue ham raise. Mace those lifts go up. Well how do we now make that glue ham raise better. That's the trick. That's the role of the supplemental movements. Now when you look at a supplemental exercise these are generally going to be trained like a movement. You're not going to be focusing on what the hell the triceps feel like or what the chest feels like. These are going to be trained heavy. These are probably going to be trained more in a three to five set range of. Three to six reps. It's heavy. It's heavy shit. You're working here. You're pushing hard and you're probably going to be pushing these to try to break. G-Rs you know I don't buy this PR shit. You know a PR is something that's an all time thing. === FILE: elitefts.com — Dr. Bryan Mann Interview (Part 3) [sRP-8XqvsKk].txt ===

Everybody, Steve Polskut for leadfts.com. Well, the main thing to me that I have to get up on a soap box of is I call scope of practice. So whenever you are a strength and conditioning coach, you're supposed to understand how to get somebody stronger, more powerful and a better condition. Now there's been a big shift to the more of the functional training. And as the way that I see it, it's like a carpenter trying to do plumbing. So they know what they know and they know it very well, but they're trying to go do things that they have no experience, no knowledge of and they really, since they don't understand the application of how things are supposed to be working, it's not good. A lot of them are trying to go out and be physical therapists. And they're trying to just, they see, oh, this person has done the clamp shelves for that person's group media. And even within that, I think that so many people just fail to recognize the science behind the things and how to use that to their advantage, like the understanding of the sports conditioning. I know that, you know, buddy Morse, I think Gabe did an interview with Buddy Morse, and he was talking about how people are always still talking about football being anaerobic. Is it technically anaerobic, since anaerobic means absence of oxygen? Yeah, but it's also the absence of lactate as well. So football is really a lactic aerobic and not anaerobic. So people need to just stop doing what the one person told them to do and what it was 15 years ago and actually go and research for themselves and find that there's better way to do things. If your athlete's aren't improving, it's because you're doing the wrong things. Okay. Thank you, Brian.

So I would, if I could go back and do the two things flexibility mobility and then also just general nutrition just eating more for the outcome and performance than so much a way class gain.

So basically we did a lot of volume work with him first, built him back up to where he was just strong and the program he was familiar with was like we talked about earlier the Westside Method when he was a Seattle. So he had his own cardio that we would complimented the gym with a problem worker of a sled who would do his own mobility and flexibility and then nutrition wise is diet's pretty spot on. He doesn't eat any junk food, he's not a drinker or a smoker. So his diet's pretty ideal and he's really a big guy but he's a lean big guy. And then the power of things what he would do with us. So it's kind of all those things combined. But again, you know, with the conjugate method and the speed work, it did develop more speed with him and he is fast anyway. Like if you see him off a box wide, he's the fastest guy in the gym even as big as he is. It's really scary how fast of a human being he is. But the other thing we wanted to do was just build him up so physically strong that when the season started, let's say he's starting up here, strength wise, everybody else is doing their thing over the summer. But then as the season tears these guys down, like I said, he came to us about 285. As everybody else is getting weaker, he is too. But he started at such a higher strength and conditioning level that it's like the 200 meters. So the fastest guy is the fastest guy who slows down the least. So we wanted him to be as muscular and as powerful as them. But because the training was so good that he would maintain that as other guys would lose that quicker. So that was really those are kind of the components of training.

=== FILE: elitefts.com — JL Holdsworth Competes at 2014 WPC Worlds [FQl_9_C09No].txt ===

The WPC World Championship is really to me. It's a chance to really say, okay, where do you stack up in the world? And so I wanted to kind of come on the stage. I've never been to a meet with this in many international lifters, you know, doing, going back, doing, you know, WPO and things like that. There's obviously guys from a lot of countries, but not as many as is on an enemy like this. So this is something that, you know, I'd like to do again next year and continue to do because it's really a great experience to say, okay, this is where I stack up in the world. And one of the guys, my director strength edition Nick Bronco, you know, he competed here and it's his first real big meet. And he unfortunately bombed out in the deadlift, had a great squat and bench day. And it was funny because, you know, I was up in Ohio and the first thing when he called me, I said, now you see why, guys, I say do it in a big meet. And, you know, everybody says, all I did this at my local meet, I do it because it's close, but to me, unless you can go to a big meet like WPC worlds and put up big numbers, then your numbers are worthless. The judge's consistent here, you know if someone gets a lift, it's real. And you know that all the equipment's the same, you know, plates way with their supposed to weigh. It's really everything at the highest level. And going away from home, so you don't have all the comforts at home. You know, I had to write a rough flight, flat tire, you know, forgot my belt, I had to throw my aqua block away because I couldn't check my bag on the plane. There was a lot of things that didn't go right, but you know, at the end of the day, it's just shut up and lift weights and get it done. And I think that, you know, the longer in this, better you're able to do that. But you got to comment and you got to lift on these big stages to even save that you are good. And I think until you've done that, you know, you have an earn the right to say that you're at a high level. At the competition for this, you know, I'm really excited. Obviously tons people from different countries. It's fun to walk through and just hear all the different languages going on. You know, see all the shirts, Austria, Russia, Portugal. And it's great to just meet people from other countries. Some you can talk to, some you just smile at. But it's great to really see everybody kind of mix and in together and see the different cultures. Thanks. Adding size gets stronger but it is not a simply a one-to-one ratio. We have also in the body builder that we expect to lift a ton of weight but it is not nearly as strong as we think he is going to be. There are two primary mechanisms that get stronger. The first one is gaining muscle, a larger cross-sectional muscle fibers are built for just more force. The second way is with neural adaptations that means getting better at the movement. So for instance, if you are a Olympic lifter you perform the frame clean correctly you improve your coordination of the movement. It is like the old same repetition as in Mother of Skill. For parallel lifting we want to improve our neural adaptations with each weight class. Ed Co. is a primary example. It is just below through each weight class going from 148 to 228 to 222. I would say the most common mistake is they're not starting to move over their hips. They're trying to squat straight down. And what's weird about that is when you squat, just to sit down and share something, actually sit your butt back. But then all of a sudden you weigh on your back. It's like people think it's very different. And just going straight down. So a lot of times all do just have them squat on a box. Without any weight just keep you sitting back. With a more seasoned lifter, generally the problem squatting. I'm going to find initially is not so much like a technical cue. Let's say they have it technique pretty good. It's not performing the squat in compensatory accelerations. Technique style of training. What that means is you're performing the rep putting back some force in the bar. So as your leverage improves, you compensate by accelerating or putting more force in the bar. You think about it if you set a five in the squat with a four hundred pounds. You know the hardest part of the squat is going to be out of the bottom. So initially you might be producing four or ten pounds of force together. The bottom of the hole. Then you see come up. You know you could you're capable of thinking how to improve the quarter squat. So you can do it in a quarter squat. Seven hundred pounds. But you're only when you come out of the hole. It's hard to get pretty some force to come out with four hundred pounds. But at the top as you climb up. And you could be doing seven hundred pounds. You just kind of set the brakes on and go and cruise control. So obviously without getting hurt and you know, hyper-centered knees or something like that. You want to continually accelerate the weight. And produce more force. So like body builders, a lot of times we'll talk about muscle intention for instance. So when they're going to fly, they're really focusing and feeling and contracting their pet. Packs. I close movement attention. Where you have an intention to move the weight with maximum force. Because you're going to get the benefit. A lot of benefits and the heavier weights. Recruiting your high threshold motor units. By producing more force rapidly. With so maximum weights and it dependsatory acceleration style. So even with a 7x1 weight or a maximum weight, you want to attempt to lift that. === FILE: elitefts.com — LTT7 Q&A (Part 1) [5r0Wuf5xyIc].txt ===

We're on the strategy you use to bounce everyday nutrition and particular when you travel. I've tried a number of different approaches when it comes to nutrition, low carb, a few years back when I had to get down to 202 pounds when that was the weight limit in the Olympia. And low carb served me well. I found that you know, guys like Branch Warren can eat a thousand grams of carbs and I eat 50 in my ankle, start to swell. So it served me well and until I started training under John Meadows and then I realized recovery is impossible from his workouts without more carbs. So I switched over to consuming more carbs during my training sessions, particularly plasma and made a huge difference in recovery. I still go pretty low carb throughout the rest of the day. I cook often and it's just a matter of planning your meals and storing them up in the fridge. And notice it's almost as much of a full-time job as training and you have to have a plan and you have to prepare because if you just go on the fly, you're not going to find the food that you need traveling. I don't actually travel a whole lot and if I do, I'll cook food ahead of time. If I can, otherwise I'm living on protein powders that I'll take on the plane. And then not, and stuff like that because I keep my fats fairly high when I'm not consuming carbs. So yeah, that's my nutrition approach.

=== FILE: elitefts.com — Questions with Clint (Part 1) [90nCd3Bm3Xs].txt ===

Everybody see Colstgaard here for EliteFTS.com. We have a special guest today. All the way from Cyprus. We have the leader of the Bicep Nation, Clint Darden. Nice to be here. And we're just going to win the interview. We're going to go with a little bit about your background. A lot of people you've answered so many questions online. People have a good grasp of your knowledge base, which is pretty extensive. But we want to know where that comes from. There's been numerous theories about your background. You've been linked to international spiderman. That's true. You're ALS, Mr. Eastwood. Yeah. We'll have to link that down here somewhere. How far do we go back? Let's start off. I'm guessing you probably have that story of the concrete weight set. Is that where you started? Where did you begin? I began probably my first love in sports as martial arts. I was an national level competitor for a long time. I tore all the muscles across my lower back. I just began going to the gym as rehab. I would have been 16. We began to rehab when I was 16. I learned that as I did get stronger in the gym, I don't even get bigger and I got to show off for the ladies. But then I got better at sports. That was a big thing for me in the gym. I trained in the gym for several years before I actually moved to an actual garage gym because I'm like most gyms didn't really have even then what I wanted to do or when I wanted to do it. But you know that really got me started. When did it become more serious? It's crazy that sounds I can't remember a time where I went to the gym and just played. The first day I went to the gym. I squatted in the Smith machine with the empty Smith machine bar and I went down and didn't come back up. I benched press. We didn't have boards back then so we used a towel on the bench press. On I took 95 pounds down and then the guy pulled it off of me. That was my first day in the gym. Then right after that I mean every single training session was just going as hard as you can. When I began working on my own it became about a flex magazine and what I read here and there. All this was way before the internet. There wasn't there any resources. There was nobody to talk to about actual strength training in that respect. But I think probably in college once I started realizing that I was getting a little bit stronger. Even though I wanted to be a bodybuilder per se and be bigger there was nothing that made up for the feeling that I got when I squatted or bench pressed or once I finally deadlifted. Even heavy rows or chins or overhead presses. You just fell in love with it. And slowly but surely I got older. I fought less and less and the gym was right there. What did you get involved in the competitive strength sports? I think there was a time through college and I think everyone's going to go on through this. And I went to college for a long time. We discussed this earlier. I mean I had my bachelor's was the greatest eight years of my life. That four year degree was an amazing eight year process. There was a certain point where I was really really poor and broke and I worked all the time and went to school. I didn't have the money for a gym or to go to the gym. I didn't have the time to go to the gym. So I built a place that trained in my parents garage. My squat rack was 255 gallons steel drums. I laid a bar across it. Good morning the bar up. Step back. Squatted. Put it back and that was my gym for a long time. I've competed in sports all my life. Whether it's baseball, basketball, martial arts. So that's not just enough for me just to go in the gym and train. I've got to have a goal of purpose. There's got to be something really going on important with what I'm doing. So I picked up an old mile of magazine and I'm flipping through there and I got more involved and just what I could do at home. That was kind of what got me involved in strong man. I'd blown it up. I wanted to weigh 300 pounds. I'd bulked up to I think 306. I promised myself once I did that. I was going to get in shape. There was kind of a transition period where I wanted to do something other than just training at home. I didn't want to be a big fat slob that got out of breath walking to the kitchen. I wanted to do something more productive and in this magazine it showed Tennessee Strongest Man which was like 45 minutes away from my house. Signed up, went, competed, took dead last, absolute dead last. I think in every single event, much less overall and there were so few competitors that I still qualified for nationals. So at that point, my parents were hooked because it was like we were back in Marshall Arts again. The family were going places to compete. Nationals were in Texas. We all got in the car and drove and as a family we were competing and all were all staying and one whole tail together. Because when I was in Marshall Arts we had a big full-size conversion van. So every Friday we all got in the van and we would drive 16, 20, 24 hours to a competition. You compete all day Saturday, drive back Sunday. So it was the family was all back together. I went to nationals and I got second my weight class and then you just get addicted. It's what can I do next. You hang on that idea that tomorrow is going to be better and better and better. The rest was just one contest at a time. Training for something bigger and having a whole lot of fun on the process. Did you have any mentors along the way or did you have to kind of find your own path? As far as with strong men, Bubba Melton held the Tennessee Strongest Man contest that I first went to and he was the closest he had the closest strong man gym at the time. That was 45 minutes away and they trained at eight o'clock on Saturday mornings. So right after the competition, right after his first competition getting prepared for nationals, I decided that, hey, if I'm going to get better at this, I've got to travel, I've got to go train, I've got to learn, and he had everything there. So every other Saturday I drove down to train with him. And he actually has a pretty bad medical conditions and I trained with him on the morning that he passed away. He passed away the night after we had trained together. But I mean, he was really probably the first person in Strongman and if for the people who are watching us, if they ever met Bubba Melton, they know that he was a big inspiration for a lot of people. He was North America Strongest Man for many years. And seeing him and having someone like that at a point, I think in my strength career where nobody was helping me. You're literally on your own. And a lot of guys watching this again, they know what I'm talking about because you're in a garage gym. There's nobody helping you. This was before internet really and it's just you and a bar in a rack and you need help and there's no one to help you. And he was really the first guy to step up and say, here, do this. This is technique for stones. This is the log. Let's look at your deadlift and make corrections. And his passing was really tough for everybody in the sport. And I remember Nationals that year was really, really tough. Not from me, but for everybody. He was obviously the predicted winner again. So it was kind of, it was tough. And he was probably my first real mentor when it came to Strong Sports. And tell people kind of briefly how you got to Cyprus from you know, if I tell you once or my wife can tell you another version of this, but you know, the short, short version of my wife and I met at school and she had to go back to Cyprus for work. And I really had nothing major going on here, work wise and career wise. So it was a great opportunity for me to go over there and be with her. So, you know, to make myself sound great, you know, it's the ultimate of romance. I mean, you give up everything. And I'm from a really, really small town in Kentucky. I was not looking for a short little foreign girl. And she did not like American people. And she did not like big people at all. And, you know, but the first one that we met, it was just, you know, it really was magic. And from our first date, we saw each other every day for, I mean, for ever as long as I can, as long as I can remember. So, you know, I mean, she would have given up anything to be here with me and I would have given up anything to be there with her. So, move there and the rest of being a trophy husband is just, you know, that's cake right there. And what is the lifting scene like there in Cyprus? You know, I want to say mostly everything is bodybuilding, but there, you know, we're looking at maybe 15, 20 people that actually compete in bodybuilding. So, it's just, yeah, everybody goes to the gym. I mean, everybody I know goes to a gym. That's just part of life. And in a large part of Europe, that is a large part of your being culture, that's like saying, you know, you know, you know, it's like asking someone, you know what ESPN is. Everyone knows what ESPN is. You know, everybody knows how to go to the gym, or at least that you're supposed to go to the gym. So, you know, fitness is at least something that everybody does. As far as strength sports, there's really nothing when it comes to power lifting. There's nothing when it comes to strong man. So, if you want to compete, you've got to get on an airplane and fly somewhere. You can't just get in your car and drive. And I've been really, really blessed this year with, you know, being a five-minute drive away from our national gym and training with some amazing Olympic weight lifters. The idea is that Olympic weight lifting is in everything sport. It is a coordination sport. It is a skill sport. You know, in power lifting, if you want to, if you're having squat issues, you know, we can, we can look at your squat and say, okay, we got to fix this and fix this and try this and you know, someone could look at your technique and make, you know, 50 pound increases in a day, you know, and making small technical things. But the majority of the time, the answer is just get stronger. And with Olympic weight lifting, it's not just get stronger. The answer is very rarely just get stronger. And people want to use the case of a couple of American athletes that, you know, they have, they have full squat, you know, 700 pounds plus raw. Well, that's great. Because there are a whole lot of Europeans that can't do that, but they're also at the Olympics, holding medals. So that big, raw squat you just did for the YouTube's means absolutely nothing. If you don't have the technique and the training to back everything up. So Olympic weight lifting, it is an everything sport. But it comes down to skill and technique and finesse on the bar. So I don't know, you know, with these guys with their podcast, if they happen to be watching this, I would love to go on their podcast and at least be able to give my advice because I don't hate on anybody. But I brought all of my power lifting gear in my bag. So I'm just as bad. But the toughest thing about Olympic lifting is that you have to be mentally sharp, perfect mentally all the time. And it's a crazy mental game. And Dave and I talked about this yesterday, we see an athlete swuck up to the bar and they get into position with their hands on the bar and they get all set and they will pull it up to their knees and just drop the bar and walk away. And everyone else watching is like, like, I was a chicken. Why don't you just pull the weight? You didn't finish the lift. You just chickened out. And that's not what happened at all. I mean, mentally they were thinking about, you know, shoulders back, tight arch, the positioning of the weight on the heels. There's so many details to think about for a lift to happen. And when you're just thinking about that, it literally is paralysis because of analysis. And you can't do anything once you were thinking about, it has to be second nature. When someone is yelling at you, when you're making the lift, you know, keep the bar close, you know, all of the, all of the cues that you hear in power lifting, you know, back, back, back and ease out. When someone is yelling at you like that with the Olympic lifts, it throws everything off and you cannot. And there's no time to cross-practin and let the lift. Absolutely. There's no time. It's not a slow lift. It's amazing. And you've, you know, at least once a week I go home and say, that's it. I'm quitting. I'm going to take up golf. I want to pick up something. I'm going to do anything besides this. You know, there's always tomorrow or this afternoon to go back in and do it again. And that's when some of the best training sessions happen. You know, Dave and I talked about this yesterday, getting into the, the mental side of the Olympic lifter, you see the lifter walked from the side of the platform in a straight line and turn and walked up to the bar. And that's nothing more than having that soldier mentality. Or whatever, whatever you've convinced yourself, it is in your mind to where you're thinking nothing but just the bar. And you have the respect for the bar. You would never kick the bar or the plate. You would never throw a plate. You know, they talk about it. And over time, just as I've spent more time around all these guys and everything, I just meet more people that I'm able to bounce ideas off of that are able to teach me a lot. So it's just great because more time I spent around all these guys, the more the network grows of people that can help me get better and teach me what I need to know. So right now, it's just continuing to grow. I still learn a lot from Jail and starting to learn more from these guys. Every time I talk to somebody, I get a different perspective on things. And then also now I'm training with another crew of people in Ohio at Duke Siren Zoo. So they've been helping me too. So it's as the more time goes on, just getting more opportunities to learn from different people. So that's been really helpful. My experience with lifting has always been training for football through maybe the end of middle school high school college. I was loved lifting but it was not the means to an end. The purpose was football. So my college strength coach, John Field was a, he was an expert at lifting. So we always talked about it a little bit here and there. And I never competed until I just got out of college. Mike Barrevecchio, good friend of mine, back home, got me into the sport. He's kind of been my mentor through all of it. We were fortunate enough to meet Steve Goggins at the 2011 IPA Nationals. He gave me his phone number and I think we've talked at least once a month ever since then. He's a wealth and knowledge and he's probably one of the best people in power lifting. I was fortunate enough to train at Westside on the weekends for three or four months. That blew me was a big help. And just recently Brian Carroll in the last meet was a big help for me. And I'm looking forward to working with him in the offseason also. Okay, there's never been more information available on training. I'm going to toss it back to Casey and work it back reverse. Tell us basically if you could describe your training and system and what elements it entails. So I went to a Mike Barrevecchio was a bench specialist. My bench is pretty good for, I consider pretty good for how long I've been doing it. But that also means my squat and deadlift has been lagging just because he's never, he wasn't a squat, squat or deadlift or so. I've had to play catch up there. For two years, I trained the conjugate system. It worked a lot of box squats, Joe and I were talking about that earlier. I got stronger, but on meet day, sometimes it didn't translate. It wasn't kind of sure how to get the most out of my training. After the past year, I moved to a Russian peak cycle, just more volume and reps and things like that. I much more comfortable on the platform on meet day because I'm handling heavier weights without a common energy resistance and those kinds of things. So that's been the biggest change for me learning what style is going to translate best for me on meet day. And then probably for the last little over year, maybe a year and a half, I started changing using a conjugate system. I used that for the last year and a half to get stronger raw. And I tried to conjugate before a couple of years ago and I was trained by myself and I basically kind of like what Casey and I was talking about was basically figured out all these things that I was just assuming and doing wrong. And then as I understood the system better, I learned how to make it work for raw lifting and then now as I'm starting to train and gear, learning the differences, the things that need to change. === FILE: elitefts.com — Shelby Starnes： Video Inquisition (Part 1) [B9em9EDXA2E].txt ===

Everybody, Steve Polska at here, we're doing a segment of video inquisitions with Shelby Starns. I'm going to hit the Shelby with a few questions. Our first question is going to be about, Shelby, you recently won your IFV Pro Card at the NPC Master's Nationals. We hear a lot about Olympic athletes at once they win the gold medal. They tend to be kind of depressed because they achieve their goal and they don't know what to do. So tell me a little bit, what did it feel like the week after you won your pro card? Not a whole lot different to be honest. Turning pro, it basically just means that I have to compete against a lot better guys now. The competition gets a lot tougher on the pro stage. Everyone has achieved pro stage. Everyone is a champion. So it's just kind of a quantum leap in terms of competition. But otherwise, you know, everything is still pretty much the same. I'm still the same bodybuilder I was, you know, the day before I turned pro. I still have the same strengths and weaknesses that I did before. I'm still pursuing bodybuilding in the same way that I was before. It's just that now I do it on a pro stage instead of an amateur stage. It's a little bit of a paradigm shift, but basically everything is still the same. As a follow up, Shelby, how did winning your pro card at change your career in business strategy? Again, not much different. I get to include IFBB pro on my resume now, which is nice, but in terms of data, data operations, not much has changed. And let me ask you about training and nutrition. Having one your pro card, what did you feel you have to change there to take it to the next level? I'll be competing in the two 12 class now. The IFBB has an open class, which is unlimited weight, and then also a two 12 class, which is anyone that's under 212 pounds. And that fits me well. I won my pro card in the light heavyweight class, which is an upper limit of 198 pounds. So I've got a little bit of room to grow into that 212 limit. I don't expect to be 212 anytime soon. It'll take a few years to get up there. But I don't expect to ever compete over 212. I'm not one of the mass monsters by any means. So things are basically the same. I'm still working in the same ways that I was before in terms of filling out my physique with nutrition training recovery in just more time.

=== FILE: elitefts.com — Shelby Starnes： Video Inquisition (Part 2) [lW4VRS6DZ7A].txt ===

Music Steve Colzcat here for elitefts.com. We are doing video inquisitions with Shelby Starns. Shelby sponsorships are something they're fairly new and powerlifting but they've been around in bodybuilding for about two decades. You have a little bit of experience with this. What would you recommend people do in order to get a supplement sponsorship? How can they increase their odds? You know, my advice on sponsorship so it really comes down to what value you can provide to the company that's sponsoring you. You know, all the time we see guys that have accomplished big things, one big contest placed well at contests and they don't have a sponsor. And that's because they haven't figured out a way to provide value to their sponsor to the company. You know, companies don't just have a bunch of money that they want to throw out at people that have one contest that doesn't make good business sense. It needs to provide value to them. It's just like any other job you might have. No one's going to pay you to work for the company if you're not doing anything for the company. And to follow up on that, what's when your sponsor by a company? What are the responsibilities that the athlete has to that company? And what responsibility does the company have to the athlete? And how does the sponsor athlete know that he's getting a fair deal? What type of things do we be looking for? So what responsibilities does the athlete have? It's all spelled out in the individual contract. It will vary from one sponsorship contract to another. You know, some might require you to do in store supplement. You know, showcases once a month for four hours or whatever. And another might not require you to do that at all. They might require you to write articles for their website or do training videos or something else. It's all spelled out in the contract. So that's what will determine your responsibilities both for the athlete and for the company. The contract will also spell out what you'll get in return. You know, what your sponsorship is. Maybe you get $500 a month in supplements in return for doing, you know, whatever it is. Or maybe they pay you a small amount each month. It's also, it should all be spelled out in the contract. That's what determines what both parties responsibilities are. And finally, what should the athlete do to ensure that he has a long term career. Obviously, companies don't always stick to the athlete. He might be with someone for one year. Do you think that their value decreases if they bounce from company to company and what can they do to ensure that someone's going to keep them? Yes, for making it a long term relationship, making sure you keep your sponsorship. It's just a matter of continuing to provide value to them, you know, meeting your responsibilities and, you know, maybe exceeding your responsibilities. You know, constantly trying to come up with ways and doing things that will help promote their company. Whatever it is.

=== FILE: elitefts.com — Shelby Starnes： Video Inquisition (Part 3) [CfQy2TdJBbY].txt ===

Everybody, Steve Coltscott, we're doing a segment of video inquisitions this time where we're shooting questions at Shelby Stars. Shelby, we hear a lot about people that are, they'll say, that they're a carb sensitive, they're insulin sensitive, or insulin resistance. It seems like a very individualized metabolic setting. So, if we're looking at this from a scientific point of view, how should someone go about determining where they fall in that range? Is there anything that you could recommend that people, things people could look for or measure in some way to see where they fall? In relation to carb sensitivity, how does one determine if one is carb sensitive? You know, it's a very great scale. It's not black and white. You know, you don't just have people that are carb sensitive and people that are not. It's a great scale. How do you determine? Some people after they have a big carb meal, get real sleepy and feel uncomfortable and just don't feel good with a heavy carb meal. Those people probably aren't very tolerant. Whereas other people have a big carb meal and they feel great. You know, those people obviously aren't carb sensitive. So that's an easy way to tell. I mean, metabolism plays a good role. You know, people that generally put out a lot of fat, put fat on easily, have a slow metabolism. They're probably not very carb sensitive, or they're probably not very tarp tolerant. If I say, someone that has a very fast metabolism doesn't put weight on easily. You know, it's naturally lean. Doesn't put fat on very easily. They can handle more carbs. But you can do things to improve that over time. The more muscle you have, training helps, cardio helps. There are supplements that help with carbs sensitivity. So you can improve over time. You know, I would say it's turned someone that's extremely carb sensitive into someone that has a crazy fast metabolism. Like, screech by saved by the bell. You know, you're always kind of limited dictated by your genetics, but you can definitely improve on what you are given. And to follow up on that, you've worked with just a ton of different athletes. What percentages would you say, handle carbs very well? And what percentage does not handle carbs well? And what percentage would be in the middle? And obviously, that probably changes over time the ability to use carbs. Obviously, when someone increases a lot of, they add a lot of muscle size. There's metabolism increases, but does their ability to use carbs increase, or is someone carb resistant always going to be carb resistant? What's your experience telling it? As to what percentage of my clients, you know, like I said, it's not black and white. It's kind of a great scale. It's a lot of gray area. You know, a lot of people end up hiring a diet coach because they have issues with their diet. Like their carbs sensitive, you know, they, they, it's not easy for them to make progress. So, you know, I kind of get a lot of those people. I also get people that have great metabolism and great carb tolerance though that are just, you know, great athletes. And when I take it to the next level. So I get a good mix. I'm not sure it's started to say what percentage is kind of a gray area.

=== FILE: elitefts.com — So You Think You Can Deadlift？ (Part 1) [xS2wLZSdeDg].txt ===

And this series, this is called The So You Think You Can Delive Series. So today we're gonna take Ryan Man... We're going to take Ryan and we're going to teach him how to deadlift from scratch. The deadlift is a very important tool no matter what you're trying to train for, whether it be powerlifting, which is as an actual event, strong man, general fitness, any of those things. The major reason being is every muscle group in your body is utilized when deadlifting. The hamstring arms, especially forearm strength and size, upper back, traps, bomb voids, lats, any muscles connected to the scapula, all of your spinal erectors, glutes and hamstrings. As you can see, we pretty much talked about everything, even including quadriceps. So a lot of your bigger, stronger guys have deadlifts and some form and variation in their programs. Today we're going to go over the conventional deadlift. There is also the sumo deadlift which will get into as well. But I primarily want to use a conventional deadlift because I think it's got a little bit more applyability to general populations and also it's still one of the most popular ways to deadlift even in powerlifting. With that being said, what we're going to do is kind of go over some initial cues. Some of the most important things on the deadlift are to one, always maintain an upright head position. This allows the back to stay straight. Two, you have to keep your back arched. We talked about this and I think you can squat series. It's just as important if not more important in the deadlift because once the back starts to round the mechanics of the lift change drastically and it becomes more of a knee extension exercise while the lower back is in a very precarious position as for as getting hurt and creating much less force. So we talk about the spine arch being, you know, how much is your butt sticking out at the bottom and how much can you hold as you're coming up. As soon as this happens, you're not going to have a whole lot of power. The other thing as well is the stabilizer and muscles that hold your position. The static muscle strength is very important because in general, most people are not built to be world class deadlifters. My self included for me to get to over an 800 pound deadlift took a lot of work above and beyond even what most world class athletes have to do just because of the fact that I'm over six foot tall and I have arms built to bench press. So for me to go down and grab the bar is like a three and a half quarter foot deadlift. With that being said, I learned a lot from the deadlift as far as technical things and muscular weaknesses that help me get that world record squat of 1197. So the deadlift helped the squat but it basically just builds the entire body as a whole. So if you have no deadlift chances are you don't have any back or leg strength or size. With that being said, we're going to go over his technique. We're going to straighten it out and then we're going to watch it break. Besides we did the squats and then we're going to take that technical break as a learning tool and that learning tool is going to be to decide what kind of accessory exercises we do in attack to make sure that heat not only makes positive progress in the lift but also protects himself from injury so he's allowed to be able to lift longer, safer and smarter. So without that being said, we'll coach him through this 135 pound deadlift and get everything perfect and then just take him up to the top and we'll stop and talk about some form breaks that we see along the way and then once we do that we'll take him up to a max until I feel it's unsafe or he can't pick it up and then we should have enough data in order to attack it with all the proper accessory exercises. So the first thing that we're going to do is we're going to set his feet properly. Now foot position on where your feet go on the bar is dictated by upper body size. Okay if you're a big guy you got big core muscles and big pecks and big arms and shoulders it's going to be very hard to set up and not be perfectly put under the bar where the bar is right up against the actual shin here. Most people say you want to choke up to the bar as far as you possibly can. Well if you're a really big guy you're going to have to back that off. My self for example I have to pull with the bar lined up right at my toenails just because I have to be able to create room to sit into the bar and a lot of people don't understand that. So if he comes in too close to the bar he's going to pull against himself. So there's an optimal amount of how close are you to the bar and how far are you waiting to the bar and that's dependent upon how you're a bill. So what I'm going to do is I'm going to watch him pick it up natural I'm not going to coach him and I'll see if I can move his feet in a better position. So since he's not a crazy large guy he's able to get very close to the bar and still maintain a straight up and down bar path. But what I will say is that he almost needs to pull the bar into him closer. So from the side what we'll try to do is we need to try as soon as the bar reaches the ground we need to try to pull the bar into our legs as close as we possibly can to create the most amount of leverage. There's two ways to do this. One you can roll the bar closer to your body or two you can pinch your shoulder blades back farther allowing the bar to come closer into your body. So what we'll do is we'll tweak that. So what I want him to do when he starts is pull his shoulder blades back and together and then pull the bar and the bar should drift right up his leg, especially when it gets to the knee. There's space between the bar and his leg. The farther away you're getting from your midsection the less leverage that you have. So this next one we're going to do we're going to watch him pull it and try to get it up against his legs right off the ground. Much better. So if you saw from the first one to the second one the bar came right into his body and he's able to create more leverage on it. So what we're going to do now is we'll take the bar to 225 and we'll pull a rep there and we'll see if we see anything else that we might need to correct. So we've loaded the bar to 225 where about 50% of his max roughly around that range. You have to go up to close to maximum weights to see technical form changes and breaks. You know going up to max is and seeing bad form is usually an indicator of, you know, this is time to stop or whatever and we will stop once it gets to the point of being slightly dangerous. But you can't see everything that's going on in the body until it goes to maximum. Because I can sit here and tell him how to pull perfectly with 135 and we can get his form dialed in. But he's not going to remember that at 405 455. His body is going to go back to his natural posture and that's where in the later segments we're going to talk about accessory work. Now what we're seeing here at 225 is we're seeing pretty good form. Obviously it really has not a lot wrong with it. And obviously as we go up we're going to see more things change. So if you're fast they're violent and they're perfect. And those those three things have to be utilized when you're warming up because if you're telling your brain to go slow and easy when you're pulling warm ups it's going to go slow and easy on max and that usually indicates you're not going to delifer in much. So when you're warming up on these types of lists you want to make sure you're trying to pull it max velocity so that brain understands that you need to go as fast as possible because a lot of the delifer if you watch Benedict Magnussen or a lot of the other big pullers Andy Bolton when they grab that bar it's it's you know NASA shuttle time that thing is coming off the ground at 100 miles an hour and you know it may stall and it may get slow but the intent off the floor is maximum explosiveness.
