byproduct of delet and correctly is the bar coming off the ground so a deadlift is not in this mindset is not the bar when you go to grab it I do not think about thinking the way up off the ground I think about pushing my hips into the bar so if I think about thinking the bar up off the ground this is what's going to happen my back's going around and my legs are going to try to do all the work and then I'm stuck in this position somewhere in here okay but if I'm thinking about pulling the bar backwards and pushing my hips into the bar the first motion is that my hips are coming into the bar and I'm pulling it backwards that backwards pull allows me to use my hamstrings in my glutes and optimal position and it also keeps the lower back to a minimum so a lot of people in their deadlift think it's almost like a a false image when you're grabbing the bar the byproduct of the exercise is the bar coming off the ground but it shouldn't be what you're thinking of what you should be thinking of is the hips coming into the bar the hips coming into the bar allow you the bar to be pulled backwards and maintain a straighter back so if you talk to a lot of world class deletters are and then is able to rotate the weight through the hips but a lot of people's spine are not as strong as their legs so what ends up happening is the back starts to absorb a lot of the pressure because you know that the weight has to transfer from the hand into the back down to your feet and when that happens if your back is not a solid piece of iron you'll have a lot of absorption of power in your === FILE: elitefts.com — So You Think You Can Deadlift？ (Part 6) [fzwrWqMl-3g].txt ===

Another exercise that is commonly seen in the gyms but not very often used is a 45-year gyms. It is pretty much a staple of any good gyms. We utilize these once if not twice a week with extraordinary results all the way from generalized population all the way up to military personnel and professional photographers. The 45-year-old gyms is a great way to hit all the muscles that we hit on the good morning and it is straight leg of the deadlift without any vertical spine compression. But you can also change the angle so dramatically that you can isolate either tailbone, glutes, hamstrings, depending on where the pad and the foot position is. So right now we have a set up where it is kind of neutral. It is going to hit the hamstrings and glutes and lower back all together and we are going to utilize a band from the bottom which is also going to change resistances. Another key point on this is to make sure that you understand that different resistances are needed to be rotated regularly. There is a lot of programs out right now and a lot of people say well you only need to use real weights and all this and that. It is just not the case. If you want to be around for 20 years and be a good lifter for a long time with that lot of over-use injuries you need to utilize the tools that are offered in today's world which is used chains and bands. I use them all the time and they are just a good tool to have. So we are going to show you instead of holding the medicine ball or dumbbell, we are going to grab a whole pretty pretty stop band and he is going to do his 45-year-old back extension. This is going to focus right through here. He is going to use a little bit of back muscle obviously because you are just going to ignore it but the glutes are going to be firing. So with the band being a little bit sure he is going to have to keep his arms bent but he is pulling on probably 150 pounds of band which could be kind of a pain in the butt to hold on to. So the bands can be justifiable for using other weights and stop good. So 45-year-old back extension, like I said, depending on where your feet and where the position is on your leg allows you to hit muscles in different areas. So what we like to do is we just change the angle of it all the time. I will scoot the feet way up, move the pad, way down, way up and just change the angles constantly. Sometimes we will put chains around our neck, we will hold dumbbells, we will hold bands, anything you can think of, we try all the time. The key is variation.

=== FILE: elitefts.com — So You Think You Can Deadlift？ (Part 9) [zJafk5lcbgo].txt ===

Another exercise that we use is a variation of a shrug. Simple shrug is just staying straight up and down pulling your shoulders through your ears or good for looks and have some validity with athletics. But the real key to the shrug is developing the lower part of the trap and the wrong way. The way to do that is to do a leaned over and focus more through the shoulder blades than you would just pull in your traps up to your ears. So the exercise we're going to use is one that we saw in his deadlift that his shoulder blades were falling forward and needed to pull him back. This is going to teach his brain to have that kind of control over those muscles and build the optimal hypertrophy in those areas. So he's going to do a leaned over kettlebell shrug. He's going to rest him on the ground, pulling from a dead stop, holding for a second and letting it back down slowly. We're developing local hypertrophy in the lower trap area which is going to help his deadlift and his squat and keep his spine in very, very good positioning for all types of straining activities. These are a lot of the accessory exercises that I would utilize for him if I saw what I saw on his deadlift. So if he came into my facility that is exactly what I would have him do. You might want to select an exercise like a good morning or a straight leg of the deadlift but not use both of them in the same day depending on your back's health. Talking up is awesome, isn't it? All right, that's live and man, you chalk up and you go to a bar, that's when shit gets real. All right, your adrenaline's running, you have passion, you love it, you're looking at possibly breaking a PR, getting better. All right, to me that's what you want to strive for in life, you want to strive for getting your hands in the chalk box and moving forward. You can spend all your life in the warm up room, talking about things and trying. But to me, that's not living. Living, talking your hands, getting ready and taking that step from the box to the box because that's that one step. So few people take because that step isn't easy and with that step comes risk. Let's go, three, let's go. You go to list a heavy weight, two or one. I'm sorry, one of three things are going to happen. You're going to make it, you're going to miss it or you're going to get hurt. Two or three are not good. But one is awesome. That's why you want to strive for the chalk box. Get the hell out of the warm up room, find something that empowers you, like that chalk box, to be able to move forward with your career, relationship, family, business, whatever it is. Because that's where life is happening. If you're too afraid to dig in, chalk off, that's fine. You know, that's your choice. And that's the majority of society. === FILE: elitefts.com — UGSS Adam Driggers Interview [yczLNBVTebM].txt ===

Alright, this is day-tate with Adam Djergers. I want to start this interview by asking Adam, you know, why you decided to do the XPC finals? Of originally I did it because I had spent about 18 months doing two things, correcting an issue I was having with my elbows so I could bench and correcting a squat depth. I had evaluated my squat, I was squatting high, I fixed it and the XPC promised tight judging. You'd have to squat the depth and so that's why I did it. That's why I chose it. This particular meat, I'm doing it because I got hurt at the last XPC. And so basically the platform at this XPC is a nemacots, I've got to make it back there. And so that's why I'm doing this year's meat. Now, what's the qualification process for this? You had to do a qualifying meat, then you had the semi-finals, and that's what I did last year to make it to last year's final. I made it to the final, I finished the meat and spied it being hurt and he invited me to this one. Now, with the qualifying meat, do you have to have a qualifying total before you can do a qualifying meat? No, I think you have to get the qualifying total at the meat. Okay, so it is based upon a total first and then the semi-finals, and then making it to the... Yeah, a total put up at a qualifier, then a top two placement, I think, at the semi-s, then the finals. So this will be your, I think you've been in all of them, right? I got hurt before the first one, so this is my second one. And how has your, over the past year, how has your training changed this year, based upon the things that you've said from your prior? I trained a lot less heavy... Well, I trained heavy less often. I originally planned out a three week cycle where I did raw, briefs suited, but because of the way some other things fail, I basically fell into a four week cycle where I'm only in full gear once every four weeks. And that accomplished two things that has helped me recover better between heavy lifts. And it's keep me from just staying so beat up. I was training hurt all the time, aches and pains and whatever, and that was getting old. I was tired of it. And so I've spread out these heavy lifts up to four weeks, and I have felt good all trained in cycle. No, I know you trained with Brian Carroll, and after the last meet was when Brian was diagnosed with all his extensive back injuries, and your back was also trashed as well. You decided to kind of go a little bit different route than what Brian did, you know, not saying that one's better than the other, you know, or that I'm not even saying the diagnosis is rather the same as they were different. But it would have been easy for you to say, okay, here's what Brian's doing. I'm just going to go and follow through and do what he's doing because he's getting this advice from so and so and so and so. But you decided to go a little different path. Why did you decide to do that? Just a piss Brian on. And it did, but that wasn't the reason, but it would have been easy to fall in and just do what he did. I respected what he brought back from McGill. There was no doubt it's good stuff. That's for sure. But after I decided that I was going to continue to lift before he ever came back from McGill, I had a plan that I said, this is what I'm going to do and this is how I'm going to do it and I just didn't want to change it. And you've been competing for how long. I did my first meet December of 2000. Okay, so and lifting you've been lifting. I've been lifting for lifting for 17 years. Okay, and how old are you? I'm 40. Okay. So I guess what I'm trying to to pinpoint down here is your older, you know, you've been doing it longer. Not maybe not longer, but you've been doing it beat up longer. So when you went into making that decision process of A, am I going to continue doing this and B, yes, I am going to continue doing this. I assume you went back on your own experiences with past injuries and things that you've had to contend with and use that to help to develop the plan. Yeah, yeah, basically that's exactly what I did. With a little bit of stubbornness to that's probably been piled up over the course of lifting to over those years originally when I went to the XBC. I was beat up, you know, I was having few health issues and I told my wife after this meet, I'm taking two months off. I just got to give my body a rest. Two months got her spent four days in the hospital, turned 40 in the hospital. And I was out of the gym for a month because in my stubbornness, you know, this is how I plan this, this is how it's going to work. And so instead of taking the original two months off, I was back in the gym. Now I was doing just rehab stuff, you know, just bodyweight lunges and, you know, a little bit of core work and stuff like that. But I was still back in the gym in a month, but that's because in that month I decided I am going to lift again. I am going to compete again and in making that decision, I decided how it was going to happen. And that was part of the process. And training at your level, you know, and, you know, at your age and training age, let's forget age, we'll just say training age. Getting beatups are given, you know, so when this meets over, you're going to beat up again. Hopefully it's going to be less than what it was, you know, years prior. How do you determine when it's time to pull back and when it's time to push down? Because I got beat up before I retired and that was, that was the hardest thing for me to do is you never knew, you know, you know, you're hurt. There's no doubt about that. You know, you're hurt, but you don't know how hurt it really is. And sometimes you can go full throttle, sometimes you get it back off. Most of the time I've made mistakes, you know, ended up going the wrong way. You're making the right decisions. So what, what helps you guide when to push and when to step back? This year's probably the first time I ever, I have ever really followed a program that this is what I'm going to do and no more. And that's the only way I've been able to do it. I designed a program for myself and I stuck to it in spite of the days that I felt good in the past. I would have pushed it. And then in the past, you know, when I, when I, when I space these, these heavy weeks out, getting ready for this meet, you know, on this week, if I felt really good, the number I had in mind didn't matter. I'm going more and then more. And I just have not done that this time. I, this is the program. This is what I'm going to do. I know I'm hurt. And so I know I need to be smart because ultimately, the numbers, although I want to do well. And I want to win, you know, it's not just I want to do, I want to win. But I want to make it there. So being stupid in the gym would possibly prevent me from completing my never one goal, which is making it back to a platform. So if I'm going to do anything stupid, I'm going to do it on the platform. But until then, I'm going to be smart. I've always said, in the bigger meet, it's not always the strongest guy who wins. It's the healthiest and the smartest, you know, and because a lot of times the strongest guy, I would say most of the time in our sport, you know, there's there's exceptions, you know, there's people who just nail it every time. But for the most part, the strongest guy is usually self-destruct, you know, before they get there, or they do stupid things in the meet and leave the door wide open for that. Now, you, I don't want to go through the injury list of all the different things that you've had, but you did mention earlier that after this last meet, you know, you were going to take two months off, but before that, you said something that kind of insinuated that you were kind of thinking about hanging it up. Why didn't you? That's just not how I wanted to go out, you know, being pulled off the platform carried off the platform was just not the way I envisioned walking away, you know, when when I walk away, you know, I'd like to literally walk away, not be carried off the platform. And, yeah, I struggled with explaining that to my family, you know, that that's just not how I'm going to finish. So, I knew, I knew in the back room that I would compete again, unless there was something so wrong with me that I would not be able to. But I had determined that I wanted to. And so when I found out that it, I probably could, then it was convincing everybody to just leave me alone and let me do it. To let me finish on my own terms, you know, let me walk away on my own terms, you know, and if, in all honesty, if it happens to me again on the platform this year, I probably will. But if it happens that way, at least I knew that, you know, I'd determined to make it back to the platform and I did. What would be your ultimate own terms? I'd like to win. You know, I'd like to go out with a PR total and, you know, win. That's what I'd like to do. I'm not saying that I would absolutely completely walk away if that happened, you know, say next month I win, you know, and I just walk away. But that's the way I would like to walk away, yeah. I don't, I'm not going to compete for years in the master, you know, I mean, I'm, you know, if, So how do you think it will end? I mean, if you win and you go out on high note, this is your high note, you know, so why not? Just step out and take a roll of a coach instead of risking another year, you know, and another big me and getting carried out again. I mean, to share a little bit of what I've discussed with my wife, that, that is probably what will happen. That is probably what will happen. And actually, as long as I do well, that's more or less what I've promised. So this me is the most important thing that you've ever done in your list of places you've ever done. You know, because it more than likely is going to be the last straw. So everything that you've done leading up to this has been made with better decisions. Yeah. Would you say better support? Yes. You know, so it should be basically your day to season as long as you stick to your plan and do what you're supposed to do and I do anything stupid. And I guess the the main question to be would be when I was sitting in the office of orthopedic surgeon, which I've been in several of their offices as of have you. I was asked if there were any regrets that I had in the 25 years of competing. And the only answer that could give us I didn't lift enough. I didn't lift as much weight as I wanted to. And the answer back was that's probably the best regret you can have. So walking away, you know, after this one, no one that you did everything right, you put all your eggs in a row. You know, if you go out on a high note, low note, any regrets? The only regret I would have is that I didn't train the way I have this time all the time. I wish I would have trained smarter. I wish I would have listened to the older guys when I was the younger guy who told me what I would tell younger guys now. Train smarter. You're being stupid. That's a dumb decision. You know, you're making a mistake. That's what I tell people now. And that's what I was told when I was that guy. And the only regret I have is not listening to that then I would have been better. I would have been better. Is that really a regretter? Is it a blessing? Because you have a gym. I mean, you got to stable a lifters. Yeah. So had you not learned that over the past year? What kind of coach do you think you would have been without learning that? Yeah, that's a good point. It's a good point. I would have the experience to share. Yeah. === FILE: elitefts.com — Universal Nutrition ⧸ Animal Roundtable (Part 3) [9UzXk5ZHoOc].txt ===

Steve Coltskatt here with the leadfds.com, or we're here for the third of our third of three interviews with our guests from Universal and Animal. And this one is about nutrition, which is where they can bring some knowledge to the table for us. We have with us Josh Holiday, Eric Fankhouser, Marshall Johnson, and Eric Schwartz. Our first question for you guys is going to be just a little bit about the basics of your eating program. Josh, first off, can you tell me how many meals a day do you eat and how did you determine that? So because I said earlier, I'm working with Fuckroom of Arc this year. So this year is my first year. We're going to have him right now. I'm doing six meals, one shake, five solid meals. And so I'm doing, every about two and a half to three hours I'm doing meal. The first meal is egg whites and cream and rice. Then I'm doing two red meat meals and two white meat meals and shake after my workout. And I'm doing all white rice and weight potatoes. And do you find that that you're in metabolism response to the multiple feedings? Yeah, I've previously used brown rice and grains and oats and some of my first year using mostly it's a gluten-free diet and I really seen myself respond to that really well this year. Okay, Eric, okay, you have a bit of the science of background to things. How has that played into the formulation of your eating plan? It has, each, I mean, it's always going to be different in season or off season for me. So it probably depends on what you want to hear. I mean, off season. Let's talk off season off season eating. It comes down to basically how long I'm up. Some days I'm going to be up long, or some days I'm going to sleep a little more. So I mean, I pretty much eat every two to three hours off season. I'm going to be eating more carbs than I would in season. I always pretty much stick to a meal with protein if you want to keep it basic carbs in a green. So I get my fiber in there. Off season wise, obviously my carb intake is going to be a lot higher than it would be in season. Typically when it comes to the off season, I'm like 60 to 75 grams of carbs per meal. And I'll do that from all of my meals. A typical day, I'm going to get like probably five to six solid meals in. And two to three shakes in. === FILE: elitefts.com — Vincent Dizenzo from the Big Seminar (Part 1) [c6L_KINGHA8].txt ===

One of the most fun seminars I did, I think I went to was Jim Wendler was yelling at everybody, you got to have a goal. What's your goal? And he went to every person and asked every person, you audience, what their goal was. And if they didn't have a goal, he's like, you better have one, I'm coming back to you. I'm not going to come to you to you, but you need to have a goal. In anything, whether it's whatever you want to do, there's got to be a goal. And it's got to be observable and measurable. Because otherwise, how are you going to know how you reach that goal? How are you going to track your progress? If you're a trainer, if your goal is to have so many clients a week, you know, if it's for your business, how much money do you want to make a week? How many hours do you want to make a week? You can make anything observable and measurable. And I've learned this from powerlifting. It's very easy. It's like, all right, for me, I want to bench 600 pounds by such and such a date. I set that goal. I put it in motion. I do what I'm supposed to. And then I can measure it. You don't always reach it, but at least you can look back and say, OK, this is what I did wrong. This is what I did right. And it's a learning experience. What does it take to get to your goal is very important also. You have to really think about the investment. And I'm not just talking about the monetary investment. I'm talking about the time, the desire. Do you have what it takes to reach the goal you set for yourself? Something you really think you can attain. If you don't think you can attain, you might have set your goal a little too high. There's always guys who will be training or they'll be at a contest and they're like, I want to take 600 pounds. Do you think you get 600 pounds? I don't know. Well, then I don't die tell them no. Even if they didn't think they were closed, we're like, yeah, I think I got it. I could do it. Like, all right, yeah, if you think you can do it, you're having much better of possibility. So look at your goals, make them measurable, make them tangible, and reassess. But give it time also. You're not going to reach your goals. You know, set short term and long term goals for yourself. OK, I'm going to give you a little bio of myself. My nickname when I was kid was skinny, Vinny. I was rail thin and it was real funny. I don't. For boys, I had my balloon year. Like, thing was like seventh grade where I didn't grow any taller, but I grew a lot wider. And so, you know, people get teased and I was like, I didn't like it at all. So that summer all I did was exercise. I jumped rope. I didn't know what I was doing. I just did stuff. Push up, jumping jacks, calisthenics. Whatever I knew how to do, I mean, you know, I didn't have information as easily available at that age. You know, there wasn't the internet. So I mean, it's hard to believe a year where that didn't exist. But I just did whatever I could. And I got in great shape over that summer. I learned the value of hard work very quickly from that day on. If you're not getting where you want to be, you're not most likely not working hard enough. It's up to you to reach your goals. In anything you do in life. You know, sometimes luck plays a factor in things, but usually it's all predicated upon what you do in the work that you do and the time that you put in. Within the parameters of your life. Sometimes certain goals aren't doable because you got a family, you got a kid, you got a job. You know, again, it's the investment you're willing to make, look at that and see if it fits. So anyway, after that time, I played lots of sports and I got out of school and I really didn't have anything much to do and I missed competing and participating. So I just was lifting and someone said, I should start powerlifting. So I'm like, all right, whatever, I'll start powerlifting. Because I just always wanted to be strong. When I was a kid, everybody wanted to be the quarterback. I wanted to be the big fat lineman. I always wanted to be the big guy. And I think, you know, 5, 7, 5, 8, I was skinny, Vinny. And I'm like, but I wanted to be the lineman with this half shirt with a gut stick. And I'm like, these guys are awesome. They have no shame. So once I started powerlifting, I'm like, good, I found my place in the world. It's a place where you can strive to be big and have an excuse for it. So I embarked on that journey. And I'm like, so what do I want to do? Well, it was 200 pounds. I wanted to be 300 pounds. I did. And it's funny because Matt saw the tail end of where I was getting where I wanted to go. But I looked, I'm like, how am I going to get to my goal? Made very little steps to just keep putting on more weight, keep training, keep putting on more weight. I ended up rupturing my back somewhere along the lines. I was training for a national competition. I was a full meat lifter. And so they told me, you'll never lift again. I'm like, all right, I spent a whole summer on, viking in and Budweiser and realized that was no way I did not want to spend my life that way. You know, feeling sorry for yourself, kind of self-medicating. And so, you know, I'm like, I'm going to prove the doctor's wrong. I'm going to compete again. So I started training again, started bench pressing. I was bench pressing. And I was doing well on the gym, compared to other people. But that was always my worst lift. But now it's all I had left. Couldn't squad or deadlift appreciably. So I have a couple of ruptured discs. So I'm like, well, let me take this to a new level. Let me find some people who really know what they're talking about. Let me go train with them. I was driving six hours round trip every weekend to go train. Because that was a commitment I wanted to make. And I started putting the weight back on. Well, before you know it, you know, over the course of my powerlifting career, I've been a top 10 lifter for well over a decade. I've benched 600 raw on multiple weight classes, benched over 800 in multiple weight classes equipped. And I'm 43 years old and I'm still at the top. And it's because I do the little things. And that's really what I'm here to talk about. The little things add up to the big things. Everything, I'm going to talk about things that get done outside of the gym. Most of the lot of people are going to talk about what happens in the gym. I'm talking about what happens outside of the gym. Because that's made the difference for me. And I'm going to start off with training philosophy. Because training philosophy, your training philosophy doesn't happen in the gym. Most people don't show up at the gym and just start picking stuff up. You have a plan before you get in there.

=== FILE: elitefts.com — Vincent Dizenzo from the Big Seminar (Part 2) [RCRDhcBohDU].txt ===

There are many different training philosophies. Got congeget, concurrent, west side bar about a 5-3-1, periodization, linear, whatever. There are lots of programs. I will tell you, as long as there is a little science that the program is based on, and it's going to work. Look at other people who have done what you want to do, try to follow what they followed, stick with it and be consistent. That's the other thing. You are investment. If someone is doing a training 5 days a week, are you able to invest 5 days a week? My wife is always a great learning experience. We had a come-to-God session, walking our dog, made her cry like a child. She was talking to me about training. I'm like, I'm done talking to you about training. I said, people pay to hear me talk about training to train with me, and I said, I give you free advice all the time and you don't want to listen to it. So I'm done, because I have a trainer hat with my wife. We've been together for over 20 years. Sounds terrible, but I wear the trainer hat. This is it. And I'm like, you can't commit. She'll go 5, 6, 7 days a week for 3 weeks. And then fall apart. And then I said, listen, commit to 3 days a week. Commit to 3 days a week for 6 months. See your progress after 6 months. And then, build on if you want to. After 6 months, I mean, she was up to 5 days a week. And it really had become a lifestyle. She figured out how to make everything fit. Everybody gets super gung-ho, especially when they get a new program. Oh, I'm going to do this 7 days a week. I'm going to look at your investment. Are you willing to make that investment? Are you able to make it consistent? Consistency will get you where you want to go. And that's with every facet I'm going to discuss today. Consistency. And where does it fit? Because if you have this finite amount of time, whether you add in more nutrition, more programming, more days of training, more recovery, it's not going to work anymore. Sometimes you have to take some things out. And the little things that happen outside are just important. Also, you're programming. Sometimes it's fun to trust it to somebody else. Just give it to somebody else. Your body is worth it. I don't know how many people will spend on their phones. People will spend absurd amounts of money. And why I talk to people about nutritionists. And I talk to people about trainers. They'll be like, well, I don't know. I'm like, you're a Tom. I know how much you spent for that phone. And how much you spend every month. But your body is not worth it. You've got to be kidding me. This is the best investment you'll ever have as yourself. There are a number of trainers out there. A lot of great trainers. Some of your trainers, you know. You can't. It's not always a good fit. Look for people that have been where you want to be, that have done what you wanted to do, that you take. Ask other people. The internet's a great thing. A lot of people hate the, I love the internet, because you can find information so readily. You have a trainer that you're interested in. Put their name in Google. Find other people, ask, how was so-and-so? I've worked with good trainers, and I've worked with awful trainers. So find who fits with you. But that one of the best investments that you'll make is sometimes just putting your program into someone else's hands. A lot of you are trainers. You have people put their program into your hands. And for me, I've done my programming a lot, and I'm my own worst critic. So just sometimes someone tell me what to do, and makes it a lot easier. I have no one to blame. I just do what I'm told. And if you get someone else's new program, just do what you're told. Because your trainers, those you were trainers, and must drive you nuts when you have people who won't listen to you, you were paying me. Why aren't you listening to me? So if you're a trainer, and you have someone else do your programming, just do what you're told. Don't procede over programming, either. If you do it yourself, write it down, do it. Look at it every couple of weeks. Again, be consistent. Make sure to take some time to reevaluate. If after two months or I only put five pounds on my bench press in two months, took me three years, put 15 pounds on my bench press, and I was really happy with that. Again, look at your goals. Make a measurable, be honest with yourself. As long as you are making progress, it's a good program. And sometimes, just let it go. Just train hard. Be instinctive also. Sometimes you want to take the extra set, that extra wrap, or you want your person, your trainer, and take the extra. If the mood is right, go with it. And that's one thing that people are talking about a lot. They're prepared this for the day. If you're having a really good day, sometimes it's good to push it. Because you know sometimes, you're not feeling while you need to back down a little too. So always consider those factors in the training. But really, if you're looking at saying, I don't know whether I'm going to do five, three, one, or if I'm going to do starting strength, it's not that much of a difference. The program isn't going to make that much of it. It's the work that you put into it, or the work that you put the client through. Don't perseverate too much on it.

Okay, this question comes to us from a Robert Deventor. And Robert, we hear from a lot of people in the similar situation. Robert is a freshman in college, getting a degree in exercise science and also studying business administration. And he asked if he says, when I graduate, I want to start a gym for athletes. I don't want the soccer moms who want to get into their spring bikini body, which is great, but that is not the people group I am targeting. The gym would be where high school and college athletes can come. Many time of year off season, or in season, and trained to become champions. And they'd be trained by Robert and a team of X-A athletes who are now coaches with college degrees that he wants to assemble. His question is, is it gym like this marketable? And what are some of the steps that he can take to make himself more successful? Anything's marketable. I mean, years ago when I was a kid, people were selling fake shit and pet rocks and making millions. So anything's marketable. So the answer to that question. Yeah, how do you go about accomplishing what he wants to accomplish? He's already got a little bit of a vision established, just keep building on what that vision is, and build on, you know, dude, it's called a SWAT analysis to a SWAT analysis to determine what the strength weakness is opportunities and tendencies are for the market that you're looking at and see what your own personal strength weakness is opportunities and tendencies are as well, and then work from there. So you have a lot of your next-size science major, which is great because that's going to give you the background and the technical aspects and your business minor, which is also great, which is going to give you the basics on how to build on. But you have to start looking at how to pull those all together for what you want to accomplish and better define what you want to accomplish. I heard a lot of what you don't want, you know, you don't want the soccer mob, you don't want the sport, you don't want that. And I only heard a little bit about what you do want, which is, you know, athletes will kind of athletes and what level of athletes and, you know, I heard of the coaches and defined as ex-athletes, well, is that really going to be the coach that you want. You can't define, you can't loosely define who your target market's going to be, you got to tightly define who that's going to be, and you can't loosely define what your staff is going to be, ex-coaches, because that's not going to be the best way to find the best person to fit that role. You have to determine what is that role actually going to be? What are their job responsibilities going to be? What skills are they going to be required that they actually have to have? Not that you want them to have. What do they have to have? Because you can find somebody that has everything that you want, but then I would call that somebody who's overqualified to do the work he need to work and then you're payroll, so high you can't have, it's going to cost you $1,000 an hour for a very athlete. So better to find who that target market's going to be, who the staff is going to be, and what you actually want the business to be. And finally, what you want the business to mean, you know, because it can't just be, you want a business, because you want a business. There's going to be an underlying purpose or aim for what that business is, and it has to be something that's tightly, that's very tight with you and close to you that will be able to help you get through all the adversity that's out there. So determine what that primary aim is and then better defining those other things would be the advice I would give at this stage. I mean, keep studying, even after you graduate, you have to continue to study. Okay, and the soccer mom, Robert, probably be the financially easier route to go. I wouldn't say that's true. There's a lot of people who set up shop that can't get any client, and they'll go after the soccer moms or whoever they can be. And the worst thing that I think that you can do is to try to be, to try to be everything to everybody. And I think a lot of trainers that get into that situation, that's what they try to do. You know, they open shop if they have a gym or however they're doing it, they're going to take everybody because they need the income. I think that's okay if you're working for somebody else and you're working in the club. That way it can help better establish is this who you really want to train. You want to train athletes, you want to train athletes to make them better. Fine, I understand that. Do you also want to deal with the negative components of training athletes, which they're in those naked components are going to not be the same negative components that you would have with the soccer moms and so forth. So there's pros and cons of every target market. So you need to know what they are. So I guess another bit of advice I would give is maybe you want to work for somebody else for a while. So you can feel out what market you really do want to be in. Because what you think you want to be, we're not always what you really desire to be, when you get into the field. Because when you get into the field trust me, it's never what you think it is. Nobody thinks it's going to be great. This is awesome. And that all of a sudden, it's like, man, this sucks. You know, 80% of my clients suck. And typically that's probably the way it's going to be if it's athletes or not. So. Now let me ask you, he talks about the team of coaches and you have more experience with this than me. I can't think of any of any prominent facilities like this that has a bunch of people that you identify with it. Like you think of a different coach and you don't think of, you can't, I can't name any of the other coaches he has. They're I'm sure you ask some people up in them that are good, but it's kind of a Joe de Franco or Faruja. You've got, you know, with the fighters he works with. Sure he has people working with them. So what do you think of the marketing with a team of coaches? Is that a difficult thing to put together? No, I just think it's how you're going to brand your company, how you're going to brand what it is. You know, I, I could have called, you know, the company Dave Tate Sports Equipment or whatever you've got a years ago, but I decided against that. Because I didn't want to have a company that was going to be just me. I wanted a company that was going to be a whole bunch of other people trying to help others. So thus we decided to go with a name that wasn't tied to my name in any way whatsoever. There's advantages and once again disadvantages to having your own name. You know, one advantage is that your name's on the sign. All the customers always know if they should, it's the fan who to go to. You know, that's, that isn't advantage. You could be a disadvantage, but it's an advantage. At the same time it's going to lock you in to the valuation of what that company is, which has some disadvantages. If you ever want to go on to something else, sell the company, grow the company, you know, have a value more than what it is. So there's pros and cons. So if it's a team aspect, then I would brand it as a team aspect. To use another name, it would be, you know, Cosbro with Result Fitness. When Alan was sick, he didn't go to work for a year, you know, the business grew. So that's because it's not Alan Cosbro's training center. You know, it's results fitness. And it's, it's the program. And it's the training that does that. Right now, I think the most popular franchise in the country is Zumba. Well, you don't know who owns that. You don't know who a, and the trainers are. But yet it's the most popular franchise that's out there. So team concept can definitely work. If I personally had to choose one or the other, I would choose a team concept because I think long term that gives you more freedom. And it gives you more creativity because you can utilize your people better. And you're not going to end up with a group of people who may become really good, you know, underneath you. But then everything's associated with your name. But they want to build their name. So they're only resources to leave, you know, to be able to do that. And you'll still run in that and any team concept as well. But it's, it's a lot easier on the trainers underneath you and they're trying to build a brand and it's something that can get behind instead of they're trying to help you build your name, you know. And so it's, it's a personal preference of mine. So it's, it's the individual's choice. You open the business. It's pros and cons. And I would definitely look at both. Okay. Thank you, Robert. And we'd love for that.

They go on with a different sport as soon as a little adversity comes in. So those guys that are fighting and scratching their way to the top, and get pissed off because somebody just flies wild. Don't worry, they're not going to be around long. Trust me. Good question, Bryce.

=== FILE: elitefts.com — You Ask, We Answer (Round 3, Part 4) [jzWTAzKzxl4].txt ===

Okay, we had a big bunch of questions about disk problems and from about, I don't know what is this, like six different people. Peter Rockbach asked how to train with a verniated disk. In this so, RORC asked how to train with and around disk reenations. Ali James Harrison asked about herniated disk rehab. What did they do to get back in the platform post-tourine and dishing his back? Steven Rice asked squatting for people with a compressed disk. And our final one here at Matt Fubare asked, any advice for healing a torn astray and hit flexure tendon? And how often should you get cortisone shots? So you've been experienced seeing the cortisone shots recently. Can you just kind of cover some of your experiences with disk problems and what you've done in any insights that might help these people out? I'm pretty face it, but I say I'm not a doctor, a care factor or a physical therapist, so I can only speak from my own personal opinions and my own personal rehab and how I went about doing the things that I've done in the past. The first thing I'll say is it was a hell of a lot easier to do when I was younger. In my 20s and even the early 30s, if I tore a muscle or if I strain something or it was easy to be able to come back. You just wrap it up and you keep going and you find ways to train around and ways to train through injuries. Not that that was the right thing to do. I wouldn't advise it, but it's what I did. During the years that I competed, I became very, very good at figuring out how to train around and through. Just about every injury you could possibly imagine from a torn muscles torn tendons. The only time I ever get anything fixed is if it just won't be moved. So if a muscle or a torn or a tendon was torn and I couldn't move, you know, my limb then I had a problem. Because if I can't move it, you know, you got to do something to be able to move it. You can't rehab it if you can't move it. So if you got an issue where you can't even move, then you should see a doctor. So then through the injuries that I did train through and around most of the time, if it was something that was, that I knew was more than just a muscle popping or a muscle tearing or a muscle pulling like a hamstring or a quad or something like that sort. If there was any question in my mind, I always did go to an orthopedic or a doctor because the first thing I always went through my mind with anything that I reported or tore was, is this muscle or is this tendon? I have to know that because that's going to determine how I'm going to go about this. If it's tendon, I'm going to be a hell of a lot slower on how I go about it because it takes longer for tendons to recover. And if it's also tendons, I've had them rupture and there's really only one solution to that and that's reattachment which is surgery. If it's a muscle string and a muscle pull, there's ways to work around that to be able to keep moving forward. So that would be the first thing is to determine exactly what the problem is. And I don't mean exactly what the problem is because you got a buddy of a buddy who says that he had the same symptoms and that's what he has or because your chiropractor tells you, you got a herniated disc but yet he's done zero, you know, X-rays are hemorrhaged to be able to know he just knows because it feels like that. Or he does some voodoo and all of a sudden you got a herniated disc or your back hurts and you think that you have a herniated disc. You have to have physical evidence to support what your injury is. That's another important thing especially if you're asking somebody for rehab advice. How did I go through a lot of the things? I trained around them and I trained through them and I made sure that everything that I did was under the eye of, you know, whatever doctor I was seeing at the time. They didn't always agree with what I was doing and was saying that what I was doing would probably create more damage and the future. But let me know what that. You got to find somebody good because if you find somebody good, they're going to know that you're going to do, no matter what they say you're still going to try it. Excuse me, if you can find somebody who understands that, they'll let you know what that top-line limitation the boundaries are. I can't tell you what they are because I don't know what your injuries are and I'm also not a doctor to be able to actually tell you what those are. But if you can find that person that can tell you those then you can play in that range to be able to still make it to the beat. One mistake that I think that I made over the years is I never pulled out of the meat for any reason whatsoever. It didn't matter if it was local, national or what I, if I got hurt, I was going. I would change that. Because there were some injuries that were bad that I should have just said, you know, I would just back it down and gear up for something later on. To me, once you hit that commitment for the meat, that's what you did. I would change that and I changed that when people ask me about it. Now, our sponsors ask, I always look at both options. You know, what is the real benefit here compared to what the negative consequences and does this meat really matter or can we just push it back six months? As far as the court is on, I really can't answer that very well because I've never had a court zone injection until last October. So I really don't know. I'm not the person to ask. === FILE: elitefts.com — You Ask, We Answer (Round 3, Part 5) [Bya3MkQ2W_E].txt ===

Okay, our next question comes to us from Peter William Pergeth. Peter asks, what do you most recommend for someone wanting to improve their grip on the deadlift? Apparently, that's his weak point and he's finding that compared to a squat his deadlift is not up there. He's tried, you know, uses chalk, mixed grip, various things. Do you have any training suggestions that you might throw this way on the grip? The two things that I've seen work better than anything else for deadlift grip are hex dumbbell holes where you use the dumbbells that are hex shapes so they're not the pro-style dumbbells and then you just hold it and make sure that your fingers are not holding where the numbers are because there's a little indentation in there that allows you for a better grip. So, just grab the 30s, 40s or whatever and hold them for as long as you possibly can, standing. That would be the first thing. That's going to help strengthen the fingers. The other thing is, in an office of life story, you'll find those small binder paper clips, not the ones that slip over the paper, it's a little black ones or I guess you can get purple paint, blue, whatever. And they come in different sizes. You just buy a bag of those and then when you're then work if you have a job or bouncing in an eye club, whatever you have. So, if they're just squeeze them with each one of your fingers like you would do the grippers but you're going to squeeze them and what you want to work on the most is going to be the thumb and the pinky. And try to strengthen that bind there. A lot of guys can't even close that. So the first thing is you've got to be able to build that flexibility in your hand to be able to close it. I know it's cool to have strike by hands and all the other kind of stuff. But the first thing that's going to go in a deadlift is your pinky. Once your pinky goes, everything else just rolls from that. So the stronger you can make the pinky stay shut. That's where those binder clips come in. The stronger the grip is going to be. So those are the only two things that I would ever recommend and it's worth for ninety percent, ninety-nine percent of the people that I've ever suggested deadlift and grip training for. Ripped training for other sports, football, wrestling and so forth and then you can get into things like rice and all kinds of other stuff. But specific to the deadlift I would stick with those two. What are your thoughts on the hook grip? Was that prominent earlier in your lifting grip? It's always been around and I tried it a few times and it hurts like hell. I can never get it to work and I try hard and it's. I never really had a grip problem in Louis I said this because my deadlift wasn't big enough to have one. Because it came up easy and he says, well you weren't strong enough until now to have a grip problem. So that's when I started messing around with the hook grip and I know people have a lot of success with it but I just, maybe I'm a plus but I could not get over the pain of doing it. So that's my only experience with it. I can't really give much more than that. Hello, our next question comes from Fred and he's questioning, well actually this entire topic is covering hand position for deadlift. So our first question regarding this comes from Fred. So if you're a really small person the hands might be out a little bit wider than what typically would be necessary, but it's better to do that and have all fingers on the knee than to have just a couple on the knee and the other on the smooth because if you do lose your grip the first finger to go is the pinky finger. So with actually on an off-note with deadlift training that's what needs to be the strongest on the hand is the pinky. All this other stuff doesn't mean anything because once that goes it's just a chain effect and everything else is being ripped out. If you're a power lifter now because you're going to develop imbalances as a power lifter that's part of the sport, it's actually part of any sport. All sports to succeed in the sport requires developing what some would consider an imbalance because of the nature of the sport. Baseball pitcher is obviously going to be more dominant with their throwing arm than they are with their non-throwing arm so that's an imbalance or is it balance for that sport? So I think when you start talking imbalances you need to start talking sports, specificity unless you're just training for general fitness and strength. With that in mind if you're competitive lifter, what's the difference? It's going to be an imbalance anyhow. So no I wouldn't be concerned with that. All right, thank you Jonathan.

=== FILE: elitefts.com—Brian Schwab Video Inquisition (Part 2) [8XFMt_TzlrA].txt ===

Hey everybody, Steve Colskat here for elitefts.com. I'm sending video questions over to Brian Schwab for him to reply back to us. Brian, you've had probably more longevity of anyone that is still competing at such a high level. Can you tell me what type of injuries you've had to overcome? And probably how many meats do you think you've actually done in your career thus far? Steve, I actually haven't really had any serious injuries. I did have a partial pectoral when I first started training, but that was back in around 1995. And at that point, I realized that I had to make adjustments to my training, to prevent that from happening again. I've had the usual shoulder and knee aches and pains, but nothing serious. I've never even had to go in for an MRI. The only I did have a partial bicep tear while I was training for relentless Detroit, but I was able to rehab that enough time to still compete in the meat. So like I said, I've never had any real serious injuries, which I think is a pretty good assignment by training method works. As far as how many meats I've competed in, since I've been competing for almost 20 years at about three months a year, I'd say I've done close to 60 meats. So Brian, how have you managed to avoid any type of career end injury? I think that there are a few reasons why I've been able to avoid injury. One is because I do a very simple cardio warmup before every training session. I do at least a five to ten minute cardio warmup either on the treadmill or a driving the sled, pushing the prowler, any of those just to increase my body temperature, which I think is something that a lot of parlatures tend to avoid. But like I've said in the past a few minutes of that can say you from months or even years of rehab. Secondly, my training method is based off of a gradually increasing range of motion. So you're not continually squatting. To depth or benching off your chest or pulling off the floor every week, you work your way down a box or squatting or use accommodating resistance with bands or chains. Same thing on the bench either. Work your way down the boards or you could use reverse bands or chains accompanying the boards or lastly with the deadlets, you worked your way down blocks down the power rack. And I think that has a lot to do with it. You can overload your CNS through a limited range of motion while reducing the stress on your joints. So that's how I've been able to have such longevity in the sport. And Brian, do you feel that the fact that you are in one of the later weight classes is health-extendure career because there is less strain on your body? No Steve, I really don't think being in a lighter weight class has had anything to do with it. Just for the fact that it's all relative. I've squatted five times body weight. I've benched deadlift at three times body weight. I've totaled almost 13 times body weight. So relatively I'm lifting significant amount over my body weight. So I really don't think that's had anything to do with it. And you do any type of special warm-up or any type of restorative work like foam rolling, massage, active release to help keep your body healthy. Yes, Steve, as I mentioned before, I always perform a minimum of a five-minute cardiovascular warm-up. Usually on the treadmill just because it's the easiest thing to do, but you could also push the parlor or drive the sled, the basic principle of that is just to increase your body temperature before lifting rather than just jumping right into it. Yes, I do foam roll actually. I've graduated the PVC now just because the foam isn't hard enough anymore to loosen me up. Much as I need for it to. I know there's a little bit of controversy around that, but I think that foam rolling is ideal to loosen your muscles without actually stretching them, which will help prevent injury without reducing the stretch reflex. And I also do an isolated warm-up prior to benching with shoulder rotation and prior to squatted and deadlifting with TKE's. And lastly, I do get a massage just a half hour massage every other week, which I think helps to reduce the potential for injury as well.

=== FILE: elitefts.com—Brian Schwab Video Inquisition (Part 3) [POLAqiLYgjs].txt ===

Everybody, Steve Colskat for eLeatfts.com and I'm shooting questions of Brian Swav. The topic today is going to be about Brian's book, the minimalist method. Tell me Brian, what is it that motivated you to write the book and how far back did you begin this process? Steve, I decided to write the minimalist or M2 method ebook. Probably a couple years ago, but the developmental process has been going on for years. I actually worked at the Y for eight years before opening Orlando Barbell from 97 to 2005. And I tried to, I tried a few different parallel thing methods, but I didn't have the options for different bars or bands or chains for accommodating resistance. So the method I developed was a good way to just use straight weight, but through and gradually increasing range of motion. So you didn't necessarily need the accommodating resistance, but you could still use gradually increasing percentages with less chance of potentially overtraining or injury. So I really started developing quite a long time ago. And then I'd say in 2005 when I opened a gym, a lot of the lifters started incorporating my method with really good success. So I'd say probably two or three years ago is when I actually went into the developmental process of narrowing down the percentages and fine tuning everything to actually write the ebook. Brian, the tagline of your book is essential training economy for maximum results. How do you reconcile this with the need for volume and training? Steve, I think there's a misconception with the minimalist method ebook that it's just based strictly on the primary three lifts where it's actually based on the main three lifts and what other accessory exercises are necessary to accomplish the most in the least amount of time. I'm a big believer in intensity over volume. I think that you can accomplish just as much in two or three all-out sets and you could in six to eight. I think a lot of times people don't push themselves as hard on the lighter weight sets and kind of wait till those last couple sets to put forth the most effort. The basic idea of the minimalist method is that you only do a couple warm-up sets followed by two heavy working sets based entirely off percentages so that you can actually benefit just as much from those two sizes you would from six to eight. Okay, the minimalist method, who exactly is this book targeted to? The minimalist method or M2 ebook is geared towards anywhere from novice to advanced lifters. The initial ebook is actually going to be for raw lifters and the basic ideas that you're going to have a set projected max that all the percentages are based off of so you know week by week if you're on track to meet your goal. It's geared towards lifters who are looking for a change in their routine to help prevent injury. Like I said, it's primarily based off of a gradually increasing range of motion so that you're not going through a full range of motion on each week and over taxing your CNS. So like I said, it's really geared for anywhere from the novice to advanced raw lifter.

Everybody, Steve Coltscott for eLeatfts.com. I have questions for Ryan Schwab and the topic today is Brian's coaching. He's kind of guy's, you know, for many different things. But what Brian does is he gets kind of average shows that walk into his gym and he turns them into competitive lift-y lifters, which I have to imagine is a combination of knowing how to do that and inspiring them to want to do that. Brian, can you tell us why that different approach? Do you find that more fulfilling with just working with average people and turning them into power lifters? Steve, I wouldn't necessarily say that's my intent, but since Orlando Barbell isn't just a powerlifting gym, it's essentially a powerlifting friendly gym that allows general members. It's also a 24-hour car to access gym. So we get a lot of people in off the street who may have no interest in powerlifting to begin with, but they see the way that the team trains and they see the benefit that they get from it, so they gain interest from that. And yes, it is very rewarding to see people go from having no interest in powerlifting to achieving PRs and having a different outlook on life because of it. But along with that, Orlando Barbell, in my programming, has produced collegiate level national champions, AAPF, national champions, multiple world record holders. At one point we even won the AAPF national championships as a team. So along with people developing interest from not knowing anything about it, we have produced a significant number of world record holders as well. And Brian, what do you look for when a person walks in on the street to decide if that is someone that you want to turn into a power lifter? Steve, I wouldn't necessarily say that I make the decision to make anyone into a power lifter. They really have to make that decision on their own. But like I said, we do have a lot of people who come in since we do have general members. And they just happen to come in and they see what we're doing. And they decide that they want to incorporate that in their training. And I really think the powerlifting is a sport that really just about anybody can do because the whole idea behind it is that you're able to set an accomplished goals that can actually carry over another aspect of your life. So I would never discourage anyone who has any interest in powerlifting. I think that anyone can actually do it. This is kind of a big question. What are some of the common things? Some of the common mistakes that you see with the genders as you take them from like this you know, casual fitness thing to becoming power lifters? I would say the most common mistakes that I see beginning lifters make is first of all training to heavy too often, which is going to make them more likely to get hurt, which is why a well thought out program such as this can be so beneficial. Secondly, I would say that a lot of times set their goals too high and setting unrealistic goals is going to make them more likely to become discouraged when they're not able to accomplish them. Lastly, I would say that if they plan to compete, not training to competition standards so that if they eventually do get to the meet and they haven't been training to what the rules state, then they're also going to become discouraged if they're not able to make it through the meet or have a very difficult time doing so. And you know, my last little follow up to this is something that you could speak to better than anyone. What are some of the physical and mental traits that make someone a champion? I think one of the most important traits for someone to be able to succeed in parolifting or really any sport or at least to be able to have longevity in it is being able to have balance in their lives. You can't focus on any one aspect of your life and expect to be successful in that as well as other aspects you need to have balance between your family life, your work as well as the sport. And then in order to be successful, specifically in parolifting, just like with anything that if you set a goal, you need to do whatever it takes to accomplish that goal. You need to be able to overcome adversity, you need to be able to overcome negativity and you need to be able to essentially do whatever it takes to accomplish that goal without giving up.

=== FILE: elitefts.com—Coaches Clinic： Overhead Press Progressions [PdpAqy2zJ38].txt ===

Mark Watts, dirt donor, leadfds.com. Today we're going to go over our military press 101, just a basic overhead press progression that we like to use with athletes and it'll just basically go through four different phases of the progression to reinforce some good habits. So any time we get a large group of athletes and we want to do some overhead pressing, we will start off with a behind the neck press. Now this is probably the only time we ever incorporate this while we use some light weight because again we don't want to put the shoulders in a precarious position. So the one reason why we like to do this behind the neck first is because the ball will actually travel in a straight line. So a couple of things we do this when we press the ball up overhead. The one thing we want to do is we want to go from a top down progression so the top really we want to do is make sure again we're going to basically push those hands so I'm trying to break the ball out. I'm trying to push my biceps forward. The other thing that does is add a stability component to that top of the left. It'd be no different than if I'm going to press and I'm going to tuck my elbows and I'm going to go flare at the top. Same thing with the overhead press. I'm going to go ahead and flare those elbows at the top with the elbow foot. I have a little instability. You can test that with your athletes by standing over and pushing down on their fists. If I get those biceps forward it's going to add a little stability with that. So that's the first phase of that progression. So the next one is going to be if we go in front. With in front there's a couple things we have to make sure we're looking at. I want to make sure that my elbows are directly underneath these two fingers. You may have to adjust that depending on the athlete but for the most part that will keep your athletes form in a pretty good line either straight up and down or slightly out. The other component you have to do is again we're going to have with our upper back trying to keep our upper back tight. One thing we'll have to do is to get our athletes to push their elbows forward. Now for some athletes with females or athletes of a lighter structure they'll be able to get those elbows real far forward and still have their hands on their collarbone. Their hands attached to the ball and on their collarbone. The thing is with that the one thing to help with that is make sure again push the elbows forward but make sure again they're pushing the elbows forward and down. That way they won't have that over extension and almost like a Olympic sputcher or push press. One thing about this movement is that again Derek's face is in the way when he presses. It's almost like a good cue to use is you're going to open the window and look through. You're still finishing to the same point. Should be right above the skull, right above that top point, right above the spine. Again, elbows forward again I'll have a slight lean back if I'm doing a strict press. As I press the weight up and I'll end up finishing with a slight lean forward. That's one thing to look at. Make sure the elbows are forward and then make sure again you're in a straight line straight up and down. This form should be pointed where you want the force to go. Third thing is going to be just a basic back to behind the head and we will do a push press with this. With the push press with this it's how we initiate it first and again the same reason we want to start behind the head because the ball goes in a straight line. One less thing to think about. Slight bend in the knees so we'll have a little soft knees or a feet about hip width and again we want to initiate the movement with the dip. So what we call dip-driven stabilize. That's just kind of a diddy that we use. If the dip we want to make sure lift the toes with the knees. So point your toes straight up in the air almost like you're trying to push them through the top of your shoes. That'll make sure that don't ensure that your weight is distributed on your heels. So now when I dip down instead of dipping down my knees forward I'm going to dip down push notes his slightly back. In a little change for a lipic lips or whatnot but this for a basic progression that's what we want to do. Point those toes up. Dip, drive, and stabilize. Again, for behind the neck. And using those hips to initiate that movement that bar doesn't come off the shoulders and to those hips are extended. And we're staying five footed just for this push press progression. The next one is going to be now we'll go to the front and this will be our push press. Same set up as a military press now and again we're just going to do the same thing. Again, Derek's flexibility is going to be a little bit different than some of your athletes. But again, same initial movement. Lift the toes. Dip, drive, stabilize. Same thing. Open the window. Look through. Finish at the top. Those elbows forward and down to start with, drive those elbows out at the top. And again, for a push, for a push jerk or a split jerk and might change. But that's a pretty good progression to use if you have a large group of athletes trying to keep them safe and incorporate and overhead press into your program. So again, feel free to comment and exercise in next. If you have any ideas or any other questions and again, join us next time.

I'm Joe Shalero, team Elite Up TS. I got started with the team a little over a year ago. So I tried to tie in my experiences with my education and the coaches I've learned from the people I've worked for and then my own experiences as I continued through powerlifting to hopefully try and help other people there in similar situations that I've been in and continued to be in right now. After we had talked about that, I went ahead and chose to do APS senior nationals and if you qualify top three in that meat, then you came to WPC World. So I got third place at APS senior nationals, so chose this meat and then train wise, just continue to try and work on some of the weaknesses that I've had that were apparent, just as I'm still fairly new to lifting a multi-plike gear, things with Benchine and especially with swadding. So just try to hit those weaknesses as much in a short time frame as I can, since there was a pretty quick turn over from APS seniors over the summer to now. My train strategy was pretty much like it normally is, we just rotate lifts, use a conjugate system. I tried to, I had gotten some new gear and I had further out from the meat, I had just changed my diet a little bit, so there's a lot of little adjustments, so I probably spent a little more time doing my competition movements than I normally do, because I had also during some of the UGSS train sessions, Bob Youngs and Joe Jordan and some of the guys gave me some technique things to change, so a lot of this train cycle, I got some good strength improvements, but I think a lot of it was trying to work on technique things that I got from some of the other guys, so that was probably my main focus. As I looked at some of the people that I know and one of my other training partners and some of the other team that competed earlier this week, I know it's definitely a tough meat. I know it's very strict with the rules, squat depth, things like that, so I know it's going to move quick, so I tried to prepare for that during training, things like that, so I feel prepared for it, I have conservative openers and then go for basically go for PRs and try and pad my total and then come deadlift time, see where I'm at, and then it could be a little more aggressive from there. I got my squat opener, I opened pretty light, I tried to be conservative just because I knew how tough the judging was going to be today, and I'm glad I did, because there was a lot of people bombing missing a time, so I took a light opener, and then I took a PR meat PR second attempt 716, so I got that, missed my third attempt my little bit, and then I'm bench, I opened with a meat PR, got that, and then got another PR to finish out bench, and then I'm deadlift. At that point I would have to probably pull a little beyond myself to get in the top three, so then I was just focusing on getting a meat to a meat PR total, and then it's a deadlift PR, so opened light again, got a deadlift PR my second, and then on my third, my goal was if I was in reach to get a lead total to 20 with my third, so pulled 644 from my third deadlift and got the total that I wanted, so I finished with squat PR, two bench PRs, two deadlift PRs, a 50 pound total PR, and then my first lead total, so I was happy, definitely have a lot of things to improve on, but I was definitely happy with how things went. Like you mentioned the west side method, for example. That is a gym of elite lifters. Like you're top of a top. In some cases, the best ever ever been in their way class Lifter. I think if the most power lifting gym is you've got a a high-spotch of different lifters. You've got some lifters that are going to be lead athletes. Some could be the best, you know, like ever and a head cone kind of sets of the word. But you're also going to have people that that is their passion, but maybe just genetically, that's not what they're really suited to do. And there's a lot of different training methods. And I think there's merit to all. And what we really try to do really is just pick what part of each of those things were specifically with the deficits that the Lifter we're dealing with has. So for example, with some of our lifters, the friends of the work's great for their deadlift. You know, the is in described in the 10 to man that's a parl thing and the learning friends book. And for some lifters, they respond more to the website conjugate method for their deadlift. So part of that equation is that, you know, when you're dealing not with widgets, but with actual people, what they believe works for them, sometimes works for them. You know, you've got those kind of variables as well. So we have lifters that trained westside completely and fully. We have some that do the westside movements, but it's not so much exact with percentages. And then some that do a friend's method and some that just do different kinds of periodization methods. So it's a hodgepodge, but it's at the most of the gradients, Jim, it's a hodgepodge of lifters too. So for us anyway, it works really well. So there's not that one method that works because they all have merit, I really believe that they do. And that's where so many people, you know, dabble in different kinds of training methods because there's merit to all of them in some way, shape, and form. And so follow up on that Eric. You also believe that role lifters need to train differently. Why is that and how do you adjust their training? Well, let's look at the bench press, for example. You know, with a bench shirt, you're going to get a good amount of kinetic energy that's built up at the bottom of the lift. And you really need to stress the top part of the movement. You know, with a raw lifter, they got to be strong at the bottom because there is no shirt and they need to be strong at the top because that's where you put your breath, you know, that you let your lock out. So it's just a little bit different. I think it's like, you know, the difference between playing the electric guitar and the acoustic guitar. You know, they're both guitar, but you play them very differently because they're in an essence to different instruments, but they're the same as well. Or you could look at that like, you know, indie car versus drag racing. So again, like my earlier answer, I think there is not one tried to train method, but just in general, a little bit more volume does the raw lifter, just in my personal experience. It does it a good benefit for them. And finally, Eric, you had some injuries that you've had to work around. How have you adjusted your training, what's the current state of your training? Sure. No over the years, I've had a number of little minor injuries, but I've also had a couple of duties, these out of bicep rupture. And she definitely have to, you have to train around not only the injury, but the amount of time it takes to heal. So there's the mental healing where you're ready to go again, really quickly, and jump back on the horse, but then there's that biological healing that you can't mess with that otherwise. You've got an injury on top of an injury, and you did it for a very little weight, because you're really not even training yet. But I think just like you train for a competition when you get an injury, you need to come up with a plan to train around that injury otherwise you're just putting around the gym trying to find out what works. So right now I'm dealing with a little sacroiliac joints, which I was not even really familiar with until I got out of alignment, and that makes it difficult when you're squatting to go maximum weight with that kind of a tweak. So I've kind of methodically plotted out what is the plan to train around this. So that way, when you are ready to train, you're as prepared as you can be realizing that you've got a slowly climb back up at numbers, because in addition to just general weakness that you're going to get not training heavy, your tendons, your ligaments have not had that big load on me either. So your mind is willing to go, but you've got to remember that your body's got to be ready for that load too. So you've got to have a plan on how to train around the injury, and then when you come back, what is the plan to get back to your competitive numbers?

=== FILE: elitefts.com—Incline Press 101 [aCCloRZiFZg].txt ===

Mark Watts, Derek Dogue, and our leadFDS.com. Today we're going to talk about the incline press and a couple of quick coaching cues if you have a large group of athletes. Incline press is a little harder to implement into your program. You have a lot of bench press, you have a lot of on horizontal plane. And then you also have a lot of overhead stuff with your Olympic lives and just military stuff. Those are easier to implement. With the incline, you have a couple things that you have to address that are just a little bit different. Everything about the incline press is you can implement that within a couple of different parameters whether it's going to be horizontal presses or vertical presses. So you can put that in or whatever you need to and it's kind of a good change up even for a deal of week. So a couple of things we're thinking about real quick. Again, Derek's going to go ahead and lay down. He's going to, when we set up for the bench press, same basic thing as the bench press for the incline, that bar is going to be directly over the ice. So again, when the athlete goes in, obviously, I would normally be spot him, but when the athlete unraxed away is going to set up now over, over the chest. The difference is, when we tell for someone for a bench press to come down basically in that xi-fort process, that just, you know, blow that sternum area below the pecs up a rab area, it's a little bit different for the incline press. We want to come down higher just below the collarbone depending on the athlete. The key thing is, in the incline press, make sure that basically those that index finger in middle finger are directly above the elbow, right?
